comment: Antonella is a great and energetic teacher and what she taught in class is useful. But her PAs and PSs are really hard and the instructions are super unclear. Her TAs are also not helpful and are tough graders. You will get a lot of stress and a poor grade if you take this course.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: The PAs are really hard, a lot of PS, those are always hard. Exams? They are also hard. Everything in this class is hard except what she taught in class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Just took her COSI10a this semester, such a pleasure to have her in class. I enjoyed every minutes of her lecture as well as her marvelous humor. In class, she has a fascinating character and effective teaching style which always clear up every questions students raised up. Always a great resource even after class. Would love to have her again!
Amazing lecture, but challenging homework.
She is really energetic in class, so you will never feel boring in her class. She go through the data structure in a very clear way.
unclear grading criteria
Really tough grader, but you learn a lot.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Classes are mostly lectures but she is an engaging and effective lecturer. I thought that the programming assignments were challenging but not impossible, especially with the help of the TA's, but I had some additional experience with code so the class may be more challenging to those with less experience.

Antonella is a good person but also a tough grader. You do learn a lot in her class but her TAs will take every possible point away from you with no negotiation. Her PAs are hard and the guidelines are super unclear. Tests are hard to predict.

I've taken every class that Antonella offers, and I attribute my internship/job searching success to her. She wants you to have a solid grasp of the material, but the tradeoff is that grades tend to be low. However, a good grasp of the material will get you much further than an A on a transcript, and will help significantly in later classes.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: The professor is a joke, she teaches "advanced" programming techniques but fails your homework assignment if you use ANY technique not taught in class (i.e basic keywords, built in methods etc.). She believes grades dont matter, so do NOT take her if you dont mind a poor grade

Be prepared to answer questions. Her personality is very straightforward, and mean. Does not check or reply her emails often. The material and assignments can be hard if you are new to coding, but tests are easier. And sometimes she does not show up during office hours and she wasn't very helpful when I asked questions about assignments.

At first glance, students will find Antonella to be an intimidating and, quite frankly, ruthless Professor. However, if you have the guts to stay in her class and follow her ways, youll find that she is one of the most caring and helpful professors there are. She puts in a lot of heart and energy into her lecture to make sure people understand her

Antonella is really funny. The class is a lot of fun. The only critique is that the tests are a bit hard to predict... oftentimes there are some things that were not really focused on as much or that doesn't necessarily seem to be a logical extension of the class... if you go to recitation though, it's all still manageable.
Tough grader
She is so good in lectures. Her homework is hard but interesting. Her exam is hard to predict.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: She made me feel very belittled and continued to call me out in front of the whole class. I left and never returned after the first class due to the extremely disrespectful comments. She was not supportive and made me feel stupid.

PA instructions and TAs are NOT helpful and consistent at all. She did not teach the basic java stuff, like collections, static, packages, etc. Slides are specific and helpful when reviewing for exams, but classes are not. She seemed to focus on students' questions too much while not proceeding the class material.

Not an easy grader, but definitely takes in account a lot of things when determining your final grade. She wants you to succeed, and cares if you learn or not. Her personality can be intimidating, but just remember she's only human there's nothing to be afraid of. Go to class, participate if you can, and keep up with the work load.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Trying very hard to please a specific crowd who have trouble understanding the most basic stuff while ignoring the people who already have a good grasp- Spent all the time on easy stuff while flying through advance details. Her TAs constantly made mistake grading assignments and we need to go for regrade all the time.

Pros: data structure and algorithm is useful and interesting, you will learn a lot. Cons: unfriendly in office hour, nit picky to details and TA varies from people, some being too harsh in grading (0 for minor error). Suggestion: if you can't avoid this class and you want a A, be very careful from the start and get close to a TA( ease for regrade)

Pros: -You learn A LOT. She covers loads of material, which is great if you're majoring. -Her sass makes the class fun. Some see it as "rude" but she has good intentions. Cons: -Lots of work, you have to earn your grade -Material is a bit inconsistent, doesn't care for nit picky details Overall her class is worth the rigor. Best COSI professor imo

Antonella's lectures are the best part about the class. They're well organized, easy to follow, and make the information seem really simple. If you don't like her sense of humor she can come across as somewhat rude, but I found her really funny. She can be intense, especially one-on-one, so beware of that. Overall though, super enjoyable class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: There is a lot of content in this course, but Antonella has evidently put a lot of thought into how she explains things so that her analogies are correct and clear. Although lectures are non-mandatory, they're very worth going to, except she does not do well answering spontaneous questions, so don't ask those in class.
Super rude to students. Made me feel unwelcome. Grading is really harsh and they won't tell you the guidelines for assignments beforehand.
She's so funny and nice and a good teacher
Reads off slides during lecture. Super harsh grader. Not helpful during office hours. If you are planning on taking 21a, take it. Just don't take it with her.

Honestly, I didn't know what I was getting into when I chose to take CS at Brandeis. But I'm glad I did, and much is thanks to Antonella. She is sassy, but I found it quite enjoyable and in the end she truly cared for her students. I feel like I was challenged and learned a lot. Yes, this class is hard - but it's CS, what else would you expect?
Really a tough grader. I got once 100 in an exam but finally a grade B+ because of low homework grade
The most stressful class you can take at this school. Avoid it at all costs.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Awesome professor - the best in the Cosi department... she should make the tests easier though :'(
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Decent professor. Reads off of slides (assignments)  made by textbook. She does not actually grade/see any of your work so grades are all determined by TA's.  Easy class if you have an understanding of JAVA/code. She is VERY sassy and can be condescending. She does care about her students but can be rude/have very little temper. No book needed
Antonella is hilarious. Although she appears to be tough and strict, she is very caring for students and  has great sense of humor.

Fair choice for intro COSI courses. It takes a lot of works to maintain a fair grade, and it absolutely requires u to understand the materials in the lecture. The result is u will have solid intro level knowledge about COSI.
It is hard to get a good grade in her class.

Antonella is a great lecturer. She explains the material well and her slides are very informative and helpful.  Exams are easy. However, the grading for homework is very harsh (they do it on purpose). Antonella is NOT helpful at all in office hours. She does not explain the reason and say that's how it is. She gives extension for homework.

Antonella is amazing, especially for someone who had to handle two class sections of 150+ students each. Her lectures were clear, she'd pause for any question and repeat things as often as necessary, and her homework assignments (while not easy) made us think about the concepts in ways that forced us to develop at least some understanding of them.

Great teacher. Funny, engaging, super european. Its easy to mess up on test which is annoying because you can fully understand what your doing and still not get an A. But the grading is pretty fair. Definitely go to office hours and look at your exams. You can get points back. KEEP UP WITH THE PROGRAMMING ASSIGNMENTS. Don't wait til the last day.

As someone who clearly understood the material, I am quite disappointed in her grading methods. I scored numerically B+/A- on all exams (87-90s) when the average is 70s, got 100s (very few 90s) on all the homework when the average is 80s, and attended every class and sits in the front. When asked about progress, she says I am well off. Boom B+, SMD
She was very harsh with grading and TA's where super hard to meet with. Overall, the class could've been a lot better
Antonella is one of the most devoted, incredible professors. Even though she is really demanding,  I've never learned this much from another teacher.
She does not allow us to use computer in class and she is confusing.

Professor DiLilo, is a great teacher. She cares about her students and makes them think for themselves. Her coursework is challenging but interesting and I look forward to taking more of her classes in the future.
Great lecturer, really knows her stuff. No BS here.

Antonella is one of the most amazing professors that I've had. This was my second class with her, and I plan to take many more. She always takes time to explain things to students out of class, and her in class slides are extremely useful. Truly one of the best professors.

I've had 4 classes with her. By far the best professor in the COSI dept. She's a good, but not necessarily great, lecturer, but she makes up for any shortcomings by always being willing to spend tons of time in office hours, review sessions, you name it. I've never had a professor so willing to spend time out of the classroom helping her students.

She's a great professor!  People complain sometimes about how difficult she is, but I really don't see it; just do the work, and you'll be fine.  Also, she clearly cares about her students, so that's always a plus.

This is the first professor at Brandeis I have actually loved. I will not say the class is easy, but Professor Di Lillo REALLY cares about her students and will do everything she can to help you succeed if you are willing to put in the effort. U dont NEED the textbook but doing the selfcheck problems at the end of each chapter is really helpful!
Awesome. That's it.
Great teacher, sometimes hard to understand but is always available for office hours or scheduled time if you dont understand something. Truly concerned about her students succeeding.
she was nice enough, she was good at covering everything on the powerpoints so the book wasn't even needed, was kinda funny too, tests were pretty easy

He is an amazing professor. Extremely intelligent, eloquent, but also caring and willing to make adjustments for the students in terms of deadlines. Participation is key to an A. These are entry level classes taken by mostly non-philosophy majors. All these narcissistic type of pseudo-intellectuals who didn't find the class difficult enough can GFT

This was the worst class I've taken as Brandeis. It was disorganized and work was returned late. The course is called what does it mean to be a global citizen however 90% of the classes were dedicated to American politics and the election, which was not what I signed up for or what is in the course description.

I absolutely adore his teaching style. He teaches in a highly discursive manner challenging thinking under many different circumstances which makes him an interesting lecturer. His stream of consciousness way of speaking is a testament to his once-great intellect. TA's should standardize their grades if they want this class to be fair to everyone.
easy A class. nice person.

I just don't really know what's going on with this guy. He seems more lost than Joe Biden. I'm sure he used to be brilliant but now just seems like he's enjoying his tenure and free faculty club lunches. Would probably take again under the right circumstances just because his classes are absolute peanuts. Nom nom nom.

Andreas Teuber is one of the kindest professors I've ever had the joy of learning under. He is well-respected and warmly received. He makes lectures exciting and fun. I hope to take other classes with him in the future. I definitely recommend this class if you're looking for a fun course taught by an intelligent and caring professor. The best!

Teuber is the type of guy who probably used to be brilliant, but then sucked glue every night to find his muse and shredded his brain as a result. Take his class if you want an easy A and the nutty professor aesthetic,

I took Intro to Phil with Prof. Teuber t Harvard and thought he was a gem! He is extremely accessible through email and helps his students out when they are stuck/confused. He wanted his students to to be open minded and think of all different types of possibilities to his paper prompts. Overall, he was a great professor and I would take him again!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: A very thoughtful, caring professor that is inspiring to watch and to listen to him speak. He promotes class engagement and values every student's voice and identity!
Teuber is a character. The topics we learn is very interesting. Most days he goes on tangents which makes it difficult to follow what he is talking about.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. This professor is extremely bad at teaching materials. His TA's are not helpful at all. His latte page is a mess. He does not know anything about layout and design and he is just going to throw everything on that page.
Awesome!

I love Philosophy, and Teuber has the sort of "teaching style" that gives the discipline a bad name. He's passive and boring. He doesn't communicate with students, and after the class was over, out of the 4 papers I wrote, only 1 of them and only 2 received any feedback. What an annoying class. Easy A if you write what he wants to hear!
rating_tags: SO MANY PAPERS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Teuber checked out a long time ago. He's a great guy to get to know personally, but he's not a good teacher. I don't know if he ever has been. He mostly lets students talk during class, where he doesn't lecture so much as "hang out." About the essays: writing ability is irrelevant. You need to say something he wants to hear if you want a good grade
Basically, if you want a free A, take a class from Professor Teuber. If you want to learn something about philosophy, take a different class (from literally anyone else).
He teaches at a slow pace and inspires us to think about questions. Maybe I am just not used to it.
rating_tags: SO MANY PAPERS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Best. Professor. Ever. Period.

It's not much about the class, but it's about the professor himself. He is absolutely intellectual and hilarious. I personally don't find the lectures to be helpful; however, the reading materials are so so so mind-blowing. His class definitely improves my thinking ability. Highly recommend.

Andreas's teaching style is to ramble incoherently into a microphone, while reminding his students that his dissertation advisers at Harvard were John Rawls and Robert "Bob" Nozick on a daily basis (as if compensating). The fact that this man has a PhD in anything, let alone philosophy, can only be explained by a clerical error

This man is THE reason that philosophy has a bad reputation. He struggles with discussing the readings, preferring to stand with his back to the class, reading verbatim off of a massive PP on a projector. The poor TAs are the ones who do the actual grading. He mistakenly thinks that his high enrollment numbers indicate that he is "saving" the dept
Gotta love teuber. Read the assigned material before paper topics and you'll pass.

I think Teuber is really bad at giving lectures. I learned most of the material from the readings and TAs stuff that I did outside the lectures. They were super boring. Most intro classes are boring but this was worse. However, I'd rather take intro with him than with anyone else in his department.
rating_tags: Participation matters--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: best professor ever!!! fc k all those people who gave him a low rating. He is hands down the best, nicest, easiest, most amazing human being and professor one can possibly have!
Best professor

Teuber is a nice guy, and he likes philosophy, but his class one of the worst I have taken at Brandeis. There are no required readings, so you can get an A handed to you without doing any work which is cool if you dont want a real class, but if you are in college to learn and you want to be exposed to philosophy this is just too basic.

Andreas isa very inspirational professor. Nice guy and hilarious. Love all the cartoons he used in syllabus and assignments. I did see his intention to get students know things about philosophy and he did try hard to make philosophy interesting. Although his lectures were not very well organized, you still can get something.

Great class in Intro to Philosophy. Useful PowerPoints and interesting lectures.  I found the paper readings and topics usefully difficult--they really made you think.    He lives for his students and for Philosophy. Wants very much for each students to "get it," to get whatever they can out of the coursework and interactions with him and the TAs.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: yeah he's pretty ok i'm a big fan of the topic on gucci shoes
I heard he lost a game of gin rummy to a guy who once knew the father of the Warren G. Harding.
I went in to his office hour to talk about my paper. It ended with him telling me he can bench press 190 lbs. Also, dude loves birthdays. Make sure you tell him it's your birthday.
Funny and inspirational teacher who is very intelligent.

I had trouble paying attention in class. I did all the readings but found that they had no influence over the lectures. The papers however did require the readings to be done. Part of the grade is participation so don't forget to participate. He tended to ramble on and on about unrelated topics. Overall, not horrible but not the best.
Great teacher. Detailed paper topics that will make you think critically and develop reasoning. Guy is a character, makes philosophy inspirational.

How does this guy end up teaching here?  Know somebody?  Acted in a tv production as an undergraduate, waltzes into a great institution and spends the rest of his career meandering through lazy, disorganized lectures.   Easy 'A' though.  Kind of quid pro quo.  He'll give everyone an 'A' with expectation that they'll give him high evaluations.  Gag.
Nice
This guy has acted with Elizabeth Taylor, but he doesn't need to act to be amazing. He's the best!
This class is great

The lectures were a bit dry (and to be honest not very necessary) but the paper topics were very engaging and thought-provoking. I learned a lot from this class and felt I got a good background in philosophy.
He is a very nice and easy-going man, and you get snacks in class.

If you want an easy A, take a Teuber class. 4 papers, one is pass/fail, he's extremely lenient on the grading and presto, there's your A. If you want to learn something about anything, do not take a Teuber class.

Non-philosophy majors will have a hard time grasping the Teuber's true value and what he has to offer. To the philosophy major, his arguments are intricate and thorough. His message is clear. His e-mail responses are long, but everything about life is a philosophical question for this man. Take Teuber if you're serious about being INSPIRED.

Teuber is an example of what tenure can do to a very intelligent but only tenuously organized professor.  His topics are interesting, but the classes are disorganized.  Because the students are never held accountable for doing the reading, the class discussions are  turgid.  However despite his shortcomings, Teuber is smart, helpful, and likable.

Teuber is a smart guy, there is no doubt in that.  However, he's a very difficult one to understand because he speaks gently in a monotone voice and almost mumbles.  The course... I have no idea what the heck they discussed cz I never went, but I got an A- and never had I done any of the readings.  Didn't buy a single textbook and aced it.

Summer O8. 'Lectures aren't meant to teach phil, but rather to inspire ideas for your paper' -TA. Isn't strict on deadlines, grades well, focuses on original thinking rather than memorization of readings, learnt a lot of general knowledge from him (he talked about antigone, putnam, P. singer, kissinger's inability to play piano, etc). Great course!

I had teuber for intro philosophy and the class overall was pretty decent, his lectures are good hearted but most of the time he loses our attention.  He means well, but it's not necessary to show up to every class.  The essay prompts were really intriguing, and he grades fairly.

Professor Teuber is fascinating.  He can be a wonderful professor if the student is interested enough to do the reading and talk to him after class.  Intro with him was amazing, he teaches you to think and to 'do' philosophy rather than just study it from the outside. I also took Aesthetics with him, which was a lot weaker.

I'm not impressed by his classes, but the topics tend to be interesting. I feel like after taking Democracy and Disobedience and now taking Human Rights that the curriculum is very similar. They aren't particularly difficult classes to get an OK grade in, but if you want an A you might have to work a bit harder. Overall average classes.
No Comments
class discussion were very interesting and debates were fun

I enjoy philosophy, but I could not follow most of his lectures because they were tangential and occasionally nonsensical.  He wrote that one of my papers was "interesting and grand" but gave it a B- and could not explain from where the poor grade originated.  He's obviously a brilliant man but his disorganized lectures made it difficult to learn.

I took his Intro to Phil class at Harvard. I must attribute a great portion of my continued interest in the subject to him. His paper topics were, to this day, the most inspirational I have ever had. A bit pompous -- but knows his stuff. Will bring in multiple facets to make the class interesting. Grades a little hard, but appropriately.
Its like if Bob Dylan and Quentin Tarentino were the same guy
makes you think. eccentricity is hot.
Don't get this cat started on Just and Unjust wars. Sometimes he doesn't bathe.  But he's very good at what he does.  Take him and you'll see the world a little differently.

Weird guy. He nice about everything, and has interesting lectures. He's also very helpful outside of class and easily accessable. He's like to see everyone who tries do well. I'm pretty sure he's high a lot of the time, but he's still a good prof.

I took this class as my "fluff" class and Professor Teuber's harsh grading soon made me realize that I'd really have to work for this class. This class taught me how to better prepare a thorough and sound argument. The material covered was very interesting as well and gave me a new appreciation for law. The essay topics were difficult to understand

the class was hard because i had no clue what we were talking about at any given time. discussion was minimal and help with my papers was even more minimal. apparently he used to be an actor, i say he should go back to that and quit screwing up the Phil de

this man taught me how to think. he is an extraordinary individual who truly thinks about anything and everything with such care and passion. a renaissance man. his writing assignments trained me to think in original ways. beyond generous as a person and intellectual. years after college, i still think of him as my idol and mentor. thank you!
Responds to urgent requests for help with "Email me."

Who gives out paper topics that are longer than the papers themselves?  Who comes to class after breaking a rib pushing someone's car?  Who hands out NCAA brackets in philosophy class?  Who thinks there may be a futuristic word for "toile
go to his discussion sections and talk to him yourself... otherwise class is a waste of time
Fun as a person; prolly not the most serious teacher who ever taught.
cracked out
He rambles on for HOURS and at the end of the lecture, you have no idea what he said, or what the point of his talk was.  GOOD:  He extends papers for weeks at at time.  BAD: He's a crackpot.
Good: He doesn't hold your hand, let's you think for yourself. Bad: Doesn't necessarily listen to what you have to say.
He is much MUCH better in a small class than a larger lecture...he is amazing and clear and helpful in a smaller class setting
he's a trip.  and on one.
No Comments
No Comments

He is patient and experienced, although lectures can be confusing at first due to the crammed slides and his accent. He can be nit-picky and likes to ask gotcha questions, but the TAs are familiar with those. His tests include niche things from the lab manual that he posts but doesn't actually explain.

Prof. Dolnik is a very caring individual; however his labs and assignments can be confusing. The pre-lab and post-lab assignments are also confusing and extremely time-consuming. Expect to spend hours on this class, even though it only counts for 2 credits. There are only two exams, but they are entirely memorization. Go to the TA's for help.

Dolnik is a very kind person and I think he's really funny but I don't really understand his teaching/lecture style that well. Some of the stuff he puts in the tests (which we are expected to memorize) do not really make sense and are super random -- long calculations about the most absurd, oddly specific things. It's a lot of work, but manageable.

For a two credit class it felt like it should be 4 credits. TA's do most of the grading on lab reports, tests are relatively straightforward but you have to memorize a bunch of lab equations. His lectures are quite boring and I just end up zoning out so I stopped going to them.

He is a nice guy and knows what he is talking about, but he can also be extremely impatient and has made multiple students cry in the past. In terms of actual classes and labs, he does not grade the labs, and his lectures can be boring unless you are super into chemistry.

His lectures are so boring and most people have no idea what he is talking about. The TA's are who mainly grade everything so getting to know him doesn't even matter. Test are not that bad but its a lot of memorization.

Had Dr. Dolnik for 18A and 18B. He is a very kind person, definitely go to his lectures to understand the material and it will help you complete your pre/post labs. Content could be pretty confusing. Tests are definitely hard but a lot of it is memorization. Magic chemistry is EPIC and the highlight of my Tuesday mornings.

Dr. Dolnik is a very good professor and if you attend the weekly lecture, all the pre/post labs and labs themselves will be much easier. Dolnik is genuinely kind and sympathetic, but is very nit-picky when it comes to grading the TWO tests. Every lecture, Dolnik takes a break to perform a cute little chemical reaction relevant to the topic.

Lectures can drag on. Sometimes we run out of time or have too much time at the end of lecture. Magic chemistry makes up for the Friday morning lectures, though. Attend TA office hours if you want to do well on the lab reports. Make sure you study and memorize content for the exams (they're not difficult but cover so much material).
MAGIC CHEMISTRY!!!!!

Attended his class virtually (COVID-19) and I honestly didn't really listen to him. The TAs go over the same material at the beginning of the lab session, so I didn't have to. There's a steady stream of predictable assignments, keeping the class from feeling too bad loaded, but he's really not engaging (at least for me, a psych/history major).

I really hated Prof Dolnik's lab. Grades depend heavily on the TA grading it, the material on the tests look nothing like what's covered during class, and his lectures are absolutely pointless (he literally just reviews what you already learned in chem11 and the previous lab). Plus, the amount of work is disproportionate to the credits earned.

I took CHEM 18 A & B and got an A in both. The class isn't difficult but requires you to put in work and stay on top of your work. Make sure to try to turn in your lab reports so as not to lose unnecessary points. You can do it!!
Prof. Dolnik's lectures are a bit boring. One lab report per week. The procedures are clear but it still takes time. The tests are easy as long as you listen to his lectures.

Friendly enough, but lectures are pretty boring because they only review the lab procedure. The class is poorly organized and your grade will hinge on your TA, but the TAs don't seem to vetted thoroughly. The one I've had often seem confused by basic assignments and give no directions, and either have a significant language barrier or grade harshly

Lab report grades hinge on your TA. Apparently Dolnik doesn't even write or lay eyes on the lab reports, which I guess explains why the test questions seem totally random. Lectures are an absolute waste of time and consist of him reading slides about basic lab equipment for 90 minutes straight. Made no effort to adapt the class for a remote format.

The professor is nice and I got lucky with a chill TA, but the tests count as way too much! Two tests really destroyed my possibility of an A when I spent so much time on the labs. The lectures are repetitive and there is not a lot to go off of when studying for the tests, even though we got to use a page of notes. Lost time and wasted effort :(

Get ready to lose hours of sleep and days of worktime completing lab reports and getting A's only to end up doing poorly because two tests can cancel out an entire semester's worth of work. Lectures provide no useful information and merely discuss the lab that was preformed the previous week. Exam content is all over the place and hard to study for
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Dolnik is one of the least compassionate people Ive ever met. When I had covid and a 102 degree fever, I told him I physically couldnt take a test that day. Instead of wishing me well and being understanding, he forced me to take the test within 24 hours and got mad that I couldnt take it at a certain time bc I had another class.

He certainly knows the content well but lectures are incredibly boring and difficult to take notes on because he talks continuously for an hour and a half, with little flow. Part of the problem is that chem lab is attached to a second, worse class (gen chem) and as a result half the content overlaps and gets repeated. Has way too many assignments.

Chem lab is way too much work for a 2-credit course. Lab reports take forever to complete and are graded harshly by TAs who fall asleep during "lab" sessions (yes, really). Almost nothing useful is taught in lecturewe spent two weeks going over the details of a project that could have been described in a document but had no concrete expectations.

dolniks magic chemistry is great, but way too many assignments. lab reports take 48 hours to complete and then TAs grade them very harshly and unclear what they want in the report. dolnik only is accessible when convenient to him. tests are unfair as he tests for things he doesnt teach.

Dr Dolnik himself is a nice person, but an extremely tough professor and so are most his TAs. Clear guidelines for grading aren't readily available, and for a 2 credit class you end up doing more work than a 4 credit class. Lab reports are difficult and long and require you to search for answers because many things were not taught.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Lectures are incredibly boring, labs are graded subjectively (You'll breeze by with a good TA), and the exams are hit/miss. He's kind and his 'magic chemistry' segments are a gem, but it is definitely draining and takes a lot of your time for a 2 credit course.

Not very good with many things. No partial credit (linked questions can ruin your grade). Lecture wise it's less of a teaching style and more explanations (essentially learning is mostly from lab manual). Paradigm heavy instead of learning. Odds are you'll get a good grade if you have one of the few good TAs. The class could be better structured :/
Great teacher. Explains difficult concepts in a way that I can understand them.

Nice guy, makes a genuine effort in imparting the core concepts and information. He'll tell you what you're doing wrong and how you can fix it, but isn't mean or judgemental about it. Don't be flippant to him or screw around during the lectures, though, or he'll get frustrated pretty quickly. Overall, good choice, just be willing to work.

Definitely not a good professor. Will not give you an answer when you take the time to go see him and ask for help. Will give you the "I don't know, you tell me" more often than not. TA's are also not helpful, cannot understand them. Can't reach the graders they won't answer your email. Bad grade? He will just tell you you don't know the info.
very tough grader-unnecessarily so
Generally explains things clearly but lectures are extremely boring. Lab grading is harsh.
Terrible professor.
MAGIC CHEMISTRY!  Lab lectures are kind of boring but he knows and tries to keep the interest.
Milks is great, really in depth linking if lab proven knowledge to what we learn in lecture. He is also hilarious.
doesn't seem like he wants to be there; takes forever to explain everything, most of the concepts are covered in Novak's lectures so it doesn't matter that his explanations fall short
Hated the class

The way lab reports are graded is pretty harsh at first, but it gets better once you learn what he is looking for. Tests involve a lot of memorization. He is extremely helpful and friendly if the student tries to get to know him. Lectures are boring.
He speaks veeeeeeery slowly. It gets a bit tedious....

Lectures were painfully boring (I needed facebook to keep me awake) but he did seem to care about his students.  Tests are manageable but be prepared to memorize things that are only relevant to the labs (as in equations that only work in the one way we used them).

Great teacher! He loves chemistry and will meet with you for as long as you need in order to understand the material. Many people mentioned that his tests are ridiculously hard which is not true. Tests are very fair, and consistent with concepts from prelabs, and questions following labs. Go to TA office hours for help understanding the material.
He was extremely helpful. Whenever you need help his office hours were readily available. His tests were a little too difficult for his teaching style however.
Absolutely horrible professor. Talks over you when you ask for help. The class is ridiculously demanding for just half a credit. The effort you put in is NOT worth it at all.

A hard grader no doubt about that, but he will sit with you for 45min. during office hour explaining anything you could remotely find confusing. Practically lives in his office on weekdays. Goes above and beyond to make sure his grading scheme is fair, including controlling for variation btw TAs. Awesome lecturer, cares about his students.

Person below me: he ended up giving everyone minimum 9/12 pts for that typo, so relax. labs are graded pretty hard and are time consuming, and tests are insane, but if you study and work hard you will ace this class. the average on the tests is usually 65, but the curve at the end of the semester is very fair; you get the grade you earn.

Important to attend his lectures; the quizzes really add up. Exams are difficult; average of 45-60%. I took the Honors track; the grading scale is honestly much more rigid than it is for the 18 section. I once worked on the same lab with  a roommate in 18; she got a 98% while I got a 75%. If you are opting for the honors track; brace yourself!
he sucks...lab sucks...killed my interest in science

He's a nice& a very clear lecturer (great PPTs). Make sure you attend lecture (quizzes boost your grade). That having been said, the tests are REALLY hard. You have to literally memorize the lab manual (numbers, data obtained, and all). My beef is that the grade I got =/ the grade I calculated (...?) Anyway, it's cute when he says "thermo-meter."
He is a super nice man and very friendly/funny. His lectures are fine, his quizzes are fine, and even lab is pretty straight forward. However, the lab tests are very difficult.
All I can say...LATTE...HAHA awesome teacher
He's not only a great instructor, but also a great advisor. This man knows his stuff.
Milos is the best. I LOVE magic chemistry. His tests are hard though. But it's ok. There's a curve. I like lab WAY more than lecture. Plus, he's a cute little old eastern european man.
i enjoy it when he says LATTE

His English is clear and understandable, if unique. The lab lectures are sometimes helpful, but painfully uninteresting, and all necessary information is available on the handout. Lab tests are fairly hard, requiring a lot of specific experiment-related memorization.
His English sucks.
Prof. Dolnik is a good guy.  His accent keeps you entertained in class.

Hot stuff! Wait until you hear him say "thermometer," "iron," and "integer." He's a good guy. Lectures can be boring, but he knows what he's doing, and is always willing to help students. Did I mention he's hot? and tall, he's rather tall.
funny man.
His class is indeed saporific [I guess it's his voice].  But on the whole, he's a great professor.
I agree with the review below -- but it's Dr. Dolnik to you.

He has high expectations, but grades (curves the tests) fairly. The lectures weren't very exciting, but that's because they were for chemistry. He cares about his students, so go talk to him if you have a question or concern. Milos is a good prof overall.
Cares about his students
Boring lectures make for a boring class, though as a person he is very nice
I hated lab, but it wasn't his fault.
He helped Dagmar Ringe with her bioinformatics course. He organized the web site, making it very helpful. He is a very nice guy, he treats students as equals.
cool prof

Boring lectures, lab manual is very unclear, expectations are unclear, tests are hard (average usually under 60), expects us to know things we haven't learned in chemistry. Labs are very long and boring and usually pointless.
Great lecturer, very helpful and cool guy.
kind of boring

If you care, he'll care. Professor Flesch is extremely knowledgeable and most of his classes end up being rants on topics that were brought up during class by students. Although these rants seem random, out of all my academic career, they were the moments where I learned the most. If you make an effort and are minimally intelligent, you'll get an A
Both funny and caring, cares about students and literature and wants us to care about the literature
If you like him you like him, if you don't you don't
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: He is a great professor!

He's a really sweet, accommodating, and caring professor. He wants the very best for his students. He is witty, sharp, and funny. He is genuinely interested in his students' lives and their successes. He can get a bit pushy and annoying as he always insists for students to have their cameras on but, other than that he's a great guy!

Amazing lectures - funny, surprising, genuinely inspirational. I would highly recommend taking a class with him. He probably renewed my interest in poetry in many ways. Grading is not bad, pop quizzes are easy, and at least in my class there were a few simple extra credit ops.
Although his lectures sometimes seemed boring and long, he was so funny and sweet and grades papers pretty easily. I really appreciated his knowledge and care towards poetry.

was I bored out of my mind? yes. Did I fall asleep when he'd read poetry in a calming voice? yes. But did I feel like I learned a lot and the grading and writing weren't too bad? also yes. Had one pop quiz but was easy. Easy grader in my opinion. He's pretty nice too!

Professor Flesch is wonderful. His feedback was insightful and he himself was very funny. He was open to being called out and always offered thoughts that questioned or helped expand my own. He's a wellspring of knowledge and could talk about his interests for hours.

I loved taking his Shakespeare class! He has so much knowledge about the subject; someone will mention a line from a play and he'll be able to quote the whole section it comes from off the top of his head. He provides really interesting insight in the works. The quizzes are easy (the extra credit is hard!) and his lectures help a lot with the essay
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Hilarious

comment: I want to be a professor when I grow up inspired by his amazing teaching and breadth of knowledge.

Really funny and interesting lecturer with a lot of great insights into the structure of Shakespeare. Keep up with the readings and try to absorb class discussions and lectures, because they will be helpful when writing the paper.

Professor Flesch is a TEACHER. A real teacher. He cares about conferring knowledge on his students. He wants to see passion in them for learning. If he doesn't, the man knows how to get it sparked. I have never had a teacher like him and never will again. A true scholar.
Hes the best professor I have at Brandeis so far! His lectures blow my mind every single time. Very knowledgeable in many different fields.

Lecture heavy (which I enjoy) but he does take input from the class. Very amusing. He teaches a lot about Shakespeare that you maybe wouldn't learn in a general English course. Lots of tangents but they all are worth it. Take advantage of the resource and participate, he'll basically let you do what you're passionate about and is a great resource.
One of the most brilliant people you will ever meet. Yes, he goes on tangents, but you learn more about life and literature from them than some detail about Shakespeare you'll forget after class.

I liked this Professor as a person, but I learnt more random facts about nothing in particular than I did about Shakespeare from this class. His lectures are just him talking about whatever comes to mind, and he did not post our final grades until well after they were due.

I AGREE WITH THE PERSON WHO IS A 50s BRANDEIS GRADUATE (AS I AM) THAT PROFESSOR FLESCH IS THE BEST PROFESSOR I HAVE EVER HAD (and that includes some great teachers at law school).  IT IS A PLEASURE TO LISTEN TO HIM, TANGENTS OR NOT, AND TO LEAVE THIS 5 DAY SUMMER CLASS WITH A BARRELFUL OF NEW KNOWLEDGE  AND INSIGHTS.
I loved his Shakespeare class. He made every play riveting and interesting. The culture references made me love him even more. I'm an English minor just so I can take classes with him.
Harvard Summer School on Adolescent Literature.  Thoroughly enjoyed it.  Terrifyingly knowledgeable and a gift for teaching - a rare combination!  Absolutely awe-inspiring in every way.
His Shakespeare class is awesome. I wish all my classes were just like it.
soooo pretentious, but some people are into that.
By far the most intelligent and engaging instructor I have had at Brandeis.

I can only compare Prof. Flesch to my Brandeis teachers in the 1950s.  He is the best teacher I have ever had, even though I only get the chance to be with him once a year for a week in an adult ed Shakespeare course.  He is just the best, period!
He's incredible. His Shakespeare class is fantastic.
pretentious as hell--i wish i'd never taken any of his classes.  agrees with students when they say dumb stuff and lets them go on and on...

i didn't find his tangents very helpful.  in fact they didn't add anything to the class, they just made me regret having even tried to figure out what the reading was trying to say.  made the whole course such a waste of time, in class and out.

People seem to either love or despise Professor Flesch.  I happen to love him.  Yes, he goes on tangents and doesn't always focus on what's assigned, but that's when you learn the most.  He's one of the most intelligent people I've met.  I enjoy his smaller classes more than his lectures, where people tend to monopolize conversation.
he never got to the actual reading.  lazy.  made way too many comments about sex during class and didn't guide the discussion with success.  i was disappointed in this professor.
No Comments
Actually you should believe the hype, he really makes things seem like they matter even if they seemd pretty boring when I was doing the reading for class.

Okay, okay, so he's funny and nice. Still, it's a waste of a 40K education to take a poetry class with him. TOO much rambling, not enough focus. I hate his style. For Shakespeare he was funny and had some great insight, for Romanticism he sucks because he just talks circuitously about NOTHING. Plays favorites too. Don't believe the hype!
-brilliant, but disorganized and underproductive
One of my favorite professors at Brandeis.  Disorganized but it doesn't matter, because you'll always learn something interesting in class.
Good lecturer.
I think he is very funny! He certainly knows how to spice up a lecture about an old dead white guy with jokes and personal anecdotes. I really like the TA that I have too. They really seem to care.

i was not interested in the subject matter but had to take it for my major. for books that i had no interest in, he at least made it interesting. i am glad that he was the teacher i took the class with

Fantastic prof. If you're lazy and refuse to bother doing work, he's not going to glare at you, force you to participate or do the reading. But this is really a situation where it comes down to just cheating yourself. Simply attending class is always fun and informative. And if you do put effort into the class, you get a whole lot in return.
Professor Flesch is an absolutely amazingly incomprehensibly brilliant human being.  And yes, he goes on tangents, but I spent all of class just in awe of his greatness, so it all worked out.

Knows subject but lectures are boring and focus on random stuff. He doesn't grade at all so you are at mercy of your TA (mine sucked). Wicked easy final. Do not bother to read or even buy books, it doesn't matter. Prolly would take his class again. He couldn't care less about teaching...is very lazy and shows up late w/ no notes.
Knows his****! take him. he is the man. i like how he comes in with his bike. that's hot.
No Comments

If you r a serious english student, be prepared for some frustration with Billy.  I regularly clocked his tangents at 40 minutes. Not great for a 50 minute class and not great if you are actually interested in the subject.  That said, Flesch is a doll, and I loved his teaching when we actually got to it. So knowledgeable. Easy tester too!

Had him at Harvard Summer School; very knowledgeable, well-versed in the genre, tends to ramble (not always in a way germane to the topic) and get off-subject. Half the class we spent watching movies which seemed to be a waste of time. Still fun for one class and a pleasant guy to boot.
he's the man

He's hands-down an awesome professor.  He's interesting, a great lecturer (his tangents are FUN!), and such a nice person.  One time, I had NO CLUE what I was reading, and was falling behind.  He devoted lots of class time to explaining the text.  Sometimes a lot of work, but he gives good grades.
A very sensitive teacher of poetry.  He taught me how to close read, and he inadvertently gave me a love of David Mamet.

The *only* Brandeis English professor, who friends recommended to me.  He is authentically brilliant and vibrant and kind.  Do get on his good side.  He respects the intelligence of students if you display it.  Can be condescending, but also has tremendous ability to respect students as well.

I took quite a few classes with Prof. Flesch.  He's very intelligent and charismatic, but he can be condescending with students, and he often plays favorites (and lets those favorites take over class discussion).  Overall, I would recommend his classes.
Interesting, engaging, knowledgeable.  All my friends had a crush on him.  And he has a livejournal!  so dork-hip.
He gives interesting lectures and is easy to talk to.  The workload is reasonable and in smaller sections, he creates an atmosphere that breeds open discussion.
All he talked about was SEX.  It was hilarious, but it got a little tedious after a while.  Not ALL of Frost's poetry can be about phallic representation.
No Comments
No Comments
Light workload. Often went off on tangents about topics /films only a fraction of the class could appreciate. Lectures lacked structure and often a point. He seemed personable though.
He's my new favorite professor - everything becomes instantly more fun in his class, and although we learn a lot about Romantic poetry, we tend to have a good time too.
yay hickey cares abt his students
very chill and nice prof, uses mastery-learning system so you basically get a ton of chances to get something right, but it did not equip me for later coursework
Very kind person and respectful to his students. Truly loves what he's teaching. Sometimes a little unorganized but is always asking for feedback

The mastery system is really good - its not very hard to get a good grade if you put some effort in. 
In class, he explains some topics pretty well, but it helps to skim the assigned readings beforehand as he teaches assuming you read them before class. 
He's also pretty easy to reach outside of class and is pretty helpful/

Hickey and his mastery learning are awesome. Don't need to come to lectures, can watch them on your own. Weekly quizzes are worth 95% of your grade, it's not hard at all to get to at least a B+. I also learn a lot of the material with the mastery learning technique. Would highly recommend. He's also really kind, nice, and his OH are good.
Very good! Would take again 100%
Terrible teacher, worst ever! Simple PPT reader, no one could gain any knowledge of computer science. If you don't know Python, maybe you are not suitable for his course.

Hickey is honestly the best cs professor at brandeis. I honestly have learned so much stuff about blender and actually made cool things using it. Really like the mastery system he uses. Very easy going too. But never responds to emails.

The class was not that difficult, but he did not have any slides/structure to most of the classes. The class was just him writing code with little to no explanation. I would still recommend people take it because comp sci is an interesting subject, but his teaching style is not great.

Pretty easy teacher and really nice person, but just kind of does things on his computer and expects you to follow along. Is not good at explaining concepts, briefly goes over lines of code instead of explaining the theory behind what he's doing, and goes at a very fast pace. You'll need to learn a lot of the course content on your own.

I have no experience before and it's a 3-D animation class. It was such a fun class with mostly juniors and seniors in the class. Light work and easy to go get a good score if you do the work. Professor would not make it hard for you to get a good score. Be prepared to teach yourself or ask TAs. He doesn't explain concepts really excellent

He doesn't have any slides for that class and so I found it hard to follow the class as someone with no prior experience with coding before. I would say getting an A in this class with Timothy is very very easy as long as you finish the small assignments (he allows you to retake until you got a good score).

Best professor in brandies cs department. Tim is so nice and has passion with teaching! You can get a good grade with Tim. He give you lots of times to retake each quiz(I pass every quiz one time) to make sure you know how to do every skills. He is busy, and he sometimes will not reply emails but don't worry about grade!
His grading is extremely fair and overall the classes ran smoothly. Open to questions and doesn't make you feel stupid if you get something wrong.

Hickey is alright. More or less, it's a really easy class if you pay attention, and a somewhat easy class if you don't. Group projects are very nice, and you can re-do the tests until you get it right.

Great professor. Course grade is based on participation and 11 short quizzes you can makeup every week. He's slow to respond outside of class, but it's clear that he wants to make sure all of his students understand the material and isn't trying to push hard assignments and tests. TAs are a big help.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Tim is great. His course is definitely not hard.
I've never had a more incompetent teacher than Hickey. He should not be a professor.

Professor Hickey is a nice person. However, he is unorganized about his teaching. 153a is all about mobile app development. Without talking about JavaScript and React, he directly jump into React Native. Then after 2 months, he start talking about JavaScript. Besides, he is not good at React Native. Be prepared for a lot of self-teaching!

In this class, Professor Hickey becomes a better teacher than usual, in that he doesn't really have to go over abstract concepts to teach, but can get away with just running through concrete pieces of software and examples. Most of this class is student-guided and make sure you have a high quality project team. Professor will be happy with effort.

Although Professor Hickey is clearly a great human being, his teaching abilities leave a lot to be desired. He needs to be more in touch with what students know and that err on the side of going over basics rather than complicated and kind of irrelevant computer science topics. Build understanding before intuition in this case please!

Professor Hickey was my first introduction to computer science and I don't think he is a particular good teacher in hindsight. I think he makes some poor assumptions on what we know and talks about mostly irrelevant or unintelligible things. He cares a lot about the students and tries to teach, but most of what I learned was from doing the homework
Kind of unorganized but such a nice person and cares so much about his students.
great professor. really cares about students and cs is about self study

Don't take this class if you plan on majoring. He doesn't really teach you anything. He's nice, but you're better off on learning by yourself, or taking another professor. His group project is okay, but it was more like his CS155B final. His class is live streamed, which is a positive.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Course coists of short programmg assignments  which students are gen very little actual programmg to doImage learng English by dog mad libsYou learn lots of words but not how to write sentencesTo keep grades upall his exa are open book. Work is very easy, but keeping up with his constantly shifting grading system is impossible.

He allowed our class to be live streamed so you could just skip and watch it later (but also graded based on online participation). There is a lot of teaching yourself with the resources he provides you. Over all good class
Great Prof. Echo360 is also really helpful, and super easy on tests.
Sure it's an easy class, but don't take his class if you plan on majoring. He is really sporadic and a lot of what he covers isn't helpful in the long run. You're better off learning on your own.
Amazing professor and person. Approach him for anything, and he will help you! Made a whole web app for his class.
he looks and talks like Frank in Shameless

There were basically no programming assignments. I did nothing and still passed the class. I also learned nothing. If you want to actually learn anything at all, take another Professor. Cant emphasize how little I learned enough.
Tim is a nice guy. He is the best computer science proferssor in Brandeis. Definitely take his class if you have chance.
Really care about our passion to computer science, make programming class interesting, very helpful during office hours. He really care about students' learning and feeling, highly recommended.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Professor Hickey does not explain things in class. AT ALL.  I'm not exactly sure what i've learned from his class.

One of the best professors! I wish I had taken more of his courses. Tim is very caring of his students. He gave us makeup quizzes and homework, not just to give you a GRADE but ensures that you learned the skills. I really appreciate it, more than other professors who just expect students do well on their own. A real educator I would say.
bad professor

Tim is one of the nicest professor and he really cares about his subject matter. He goes a little fast and sometimes assumes students know complicated material ahead of time, which causes confusion. He truly cares about students and their learning. He likes to use technology in class which can be distracting and sometimes ineffective.

Class was disorganized sometimes. Material was pretty easy, but I feel like I largely learned the material on my own. It's not a terrible class by any means, but I think that other teachers probably prepare you better. That being said, I took it a couple of years back, so it's definitely possible that things have improved since!
Best ever! You will learn a lot.

Great prof. Take his class if you want to learn cs11a material and get good grades because he curves generously. After the curve 43 out of 50 is an A. How great is that?  Great guy. Always replies to emails. Uses interesting technology in class.

Tim is an awesome teacher. It's not surprising that he is doing research on education since he uses very modern teaching technology and methods. E.g. everyone logs in and switches between "engaged", "bored", and "confused". Tim sees this backup in real-time, repeats a part if too many are confused, and speeds up if too many are bored.
solid easy A if you do the bare minimum work. Plus you do learn a whole lot. Just was a bit too much repetition.

Professor Hickey is awesome. He's friendly, gives good examples, and is always willing to help his students. He knows and can explain everything from the very basics to the far more complex concepts. I think my only complaint would be that his lectures were a little unstructured, though I still learned a lot from him.
lots of t.a. sessions which are very helpful.
/**Hickey is the man. He is very nice and ALWAYS open to student ideas. Can't get any better than him.**/

I took Tim's Prolog class in 1991. Great teacher with a lot of enthusiasm for the material and challenging and interesting projects for assignments. He's one of the good ones if you're interested in Computer Science, particularly if you are interested in going on to research or grad school.
No Comments
I love this class. Very nice and considerate proffessor
No Comments

Class was a waste of time. Professor spent the entire semester teaching how to do specific details in a rare programming language, while the class was supposed to have a comprehensive introductory curriculum. Homework assignments only taught me how to count parentheses.
Good teacher knows his stuff but would not answer emails. What up with that?
he's so cute!!!
Has NO structure in his class; sometimes you learn absolutely NOTHING.

He is a great lecturer and cares a lot about his students. His class did not have a cumulative final which was nice compared to the other classes. Do know though that there are only 3 tests, that are not as easy as he makes them out to be. Overall he is a fair grader and assesses hw, test scores, and more when picking your grade.
Can Erbil? Yes, yes he can.
Great Professor for economics

Prof. Erbil is the best Prof. I have ever had. He makes a course like Applied Econometrics fun and interesting to a group of MDs! And there is full attendance almost on every Friday afternoon 2-5pm! I would take every class he teaches!

Erbil is good as it gets. Definitely my favorite at Brandeis so far. He can teach the most boring subject and make it clear and fun. I like his real life examples and the fact that he actually listens to us, too.
Best of the best!
Excellent.
Great professor.
You absolutely can't sleep at his classes.

Difficult exam, but fair... He is very energetic in class. Always finds something interesting from "the real life" to relate to the somewhat dry theory. Also like the mtn biking trail recommendations.
Love 8B, love Erbil!
I decided to be an Econ major because of this course. Erbil is the best. He has two car stories :-)
Dynamic and caring prof. His lectures are very up-to-date, entertaining but also demanding. You need to earn your grade, but it is worth. I would take all classes he teaches.
Very creative and thoughtful teacher.
Erbil is the best!!! Ask for his car story!
Best Prof at Brandeis!!!

Best prof at Brandeis. Funny and serious at the same time!!! Keeps you interested. Connects current events to his lectures and makes learning fun. Yet he is tough and makes you work hard (but you somehow love it...).
One of the best professors I have had at Brandeis.  Very devoted to his students.  Keeps classes interesting and a great overall teacher.
hardest econ core course
The hardest class I have taken, but also the best!
Good teacher. Tough grader.
Tough but fair. Works hard for his students.
-devoted, excellent

Became a father last April and actually showed up in class (stayed 2 minutes) while his wife started labor!!! Most pleasant and one of the cutest profs of Brandeis. Enjoys helping his students. Very well connected.
No Comments

Erbil has an unusual approach to his students. You want to study the subject material, because he makes you like him and you don't want to disappoint the guy, who is himself working so hard for the course. He often asks the students to "meet him the half way" and his half way is actully more than "all the way". I would recommend him to everybody.
SOOOOOO HOT I LOVE HIM

I've had two Erbil classes, and I wish he taught more. He's one of the nicest and most helpful teachers you're bound to find in any department. Any of his Erbil's classes are worth taking, because he's simply a great professor.
Thank you for a great semester.
Can loves to teach and it shows.
Excellent prof.
not a good teacher
Best ever. Made me like ECONOMETRICS!!! Unique teaching style. Keeps students on their toes. Tells killer stories. Plays cool music...
dry
Didn't think that I would enjoy stats! Can's lectures were clear and to the point.
I actually wanted to go to class!!!
Best prof I have ever had!!!
his idea of lecturing was to read us the text aloud. i felt like he just went through the motions. people who say that he was into it were just caught up in his 'cool accent'.
Energetic!!!
Thank you for a great semester!
No Comments
he owns chad bown
Lively
He is the man!!!
He is sooooo hot
No Comments
No Comments
he is the best!
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

This professor is a good person but does not know how to teach. The lectures are slow-paced and extremely disorganized. The lectures are filled with so many examples that one does not clearly understand the important point. Overall, the topics are not hard but her inability makes this class way harder than it should be.
very caring and very accessible outside of class, but lectures are a little disorganized. Better to ask follow-up questions!

As most have already said, I agree that Prof. Woodruff is a caring professor. She is very sweet. I do also agree that her lectures are disorganized. Expect to supplement the lectures with your own exploration of the course material and the textbook. I don't think I'd take another class with Prof. Woodruff simply due to the lack of organization.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Very sweet professor but content and class is so beyond disorganized. lectures lack direction and quizzes are poorly written.

NOT good at lecturing or teaching. Talks in a stream of consciousness, which is NOT how teaching should be done. Unclear instructions. Inconsistent grading. Extremely disorganized. Avoid at all costs (except freshman bio students sorry you'll have to suffer through her).

Tough grader and tough exams. Graded on a lot of things so it's tough to fail the class but also tough to do well in the class. Exams often don't fit the material so you have to teach yourself a lot of it. Super sweet and will try to help you do well and is rooting for your success but lectures are tough to follow.

Dr. Woodruff is a caring person. She cares about her students and is very accessible outside class. The lectures are sometimes disorganized but overall you would learn stuff if you keep attending class. Her office hours are really helpful if you are having issue understanding certain concepts.
Professor Woodruff is very kind and compassionate, but her lectures are not organized and get confusing. Her tests are also difficult and she is a tough grader.

Professor Woodruff is an incredibly sweet person and overall the class was fine. I did feel that she went through the slides and material fairly quickly and I didn't find the recitations that useful, However Professor Woodruff was incredibly accommodating and offered test retakes for every exam.

Reading and understanding the textbook chapters assigned before hand is useful, it's hard to learn the material in the lectures as she goes through slides relatively quickly. Her explanations and lectures are great if you already have a basic understanding and are there to deepen the understanding rather than learn. Exam retakes saved my grade.

Professor Woodruff is incredibly kind, intelligent, and cares about her students. I think the common consensus is that she is disorganized, which is true, but the disorganization really only causes some minor inconveniences. If you study the material you will do well.

Dr. Woodruff was a little disorganized lecture wise and felt like I didn't retain much + was pretty confused the last ~1.5 months of the semester. Took 14A Fall 2022 so no final, only 1 in person test, a few take home tests, a paper, and a final presentation. Very nice person and always available for help.

Material seemed easy in lecture and recitation, but the quizzes were always harder than expected imo. She is a nice person. Actually do the practice questions. Attendance was through in class questions that you would turn in.

The material was needlessly confusing due to the disorganized lecture style. She said the final would mostly focus on the last few chapters, but it was almost only stuff from the start (one person started crying during the test). She gave me a 20 on a major project because she "wasn't sure it met the requirements" and I had to completely redo it.

Dr. Woodruff is an extremely intelligent person. However, it appears as though she would be better off teaching a higher level bio course. It is not difficult to be successful in this class, as she gives a plethora of extra credit opportunities, but it is difficult to learn. Much of class time is taken up by complex unrelated questions and answers.

She is a wonderful person but not the best professor. She seems like the type of person who is far too smart to be teaching such an introductory course. Her lectures are boring and I learned almost nothing from them. Almost no practice provided for the material so the test are incredibly difficult.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Someone else described her teaching as "streams of consciousness," and I couldn't agree more. She's a really nice person, and she obviously cares a lot for what she teaches but teaching lacks organization and defined units. It's a class you won't get by without friends or staying on top of class material. Final project boosted my grade though

Prof Woodruff is an absolute sweetheart but is very disorganized. There's no clear units in her course (it feels more like a stream of consciousness). That being said, if you put the work in, you'll be rewarded in the end :)

Dr. Woodruff is such a sweet and caring professor! Her lectures are clear and easy to understand! She really made hard topics understandable for students. Her tests require a bit of thinking but overall it was such a pleasure to be in her class!

The class was fairly easy and monotonous, but prof explained concepts well and was very in tune with her students. She was very available and the grading criteria, while some may say a bit lax, was very predictable.

Dr. Woodruff is a really sweet person and gets easily excited about explaining concepts, so it should be in your interest to ask questions on topics you are confused about. Her lectures have about half an hour just to answer questions. Take thorough notes on her lectures and create connections with classmates to succeed in this course!

Professor Woodruff is a very nice person and a professor. She is always willing to help. If you follow her instructions and watch her preclass videos, you will understand the topics just fine. Her tests are on the content she teaches in the preclass videos so those are very important.
Possible to bring grade up, Dr. Woodruff is highly accomplished and it shows through her passion, TA's and her are both readily available and answer to emails in a timely manner.

Dr. Woodruff uses a flipped classroom, so if you have a hard time learning on your own from prerecorded videos you're out of luck. She never teaches in classlecture time is reserved for Q+A which makes the content very disjointed. Recitation quality varies wildly based on TA, and grading policies and tests are unnecessarily complicated.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Dr. Woodruff is a classic example of a nice person, but horrible professor. Her lectures are extremely disorganized, and she has trouble finishing a concept before moving onto the next. Her class is an easy A if you read the textbook diligently. Final exam is a poster presentation that will bump your grade up for free.
Definitely a manageable class if you stay on top of lectures and textbook readings.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: I took bio14 and bio101 with her and I will say she is really great with upper level classes. She is so smart that she sometimes has trouble conveying simple concepts. However, in more advanced courses, I LOVE HER
She is not the best lecturer but she incredibly nice and she'll explain things well in office hours. The textbook is pretty helpful.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: Professor Woodruff gets a bad reputation by students on here. Anyone who has a good head on their shoulders will do fine. As long as you do the reading, assigned practice problems, and assigned practice tests, and understand the concepts behind those problems, you'll ace the tests and final. Concept-wise, the exams are identical to problems given.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY

comment: After having Dr. Woodruff for bio14 this class was not only interesting, but I know will help my future career. She is clear in this course and you know what you need to do to do well. Exams are mostly open notes and other assignments have clear grading rubrics. She is approachable and wants you to do well. Mix of grad and undergrads in the class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: The lectures are extremely scattered and not clear. The first couple of tests are easy but then the final was absurdly difficult and she made no accommodations.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: I personally love Prof. Woodruff. I got the most out of her lectures when I read beforehand. She knows the materials and is very concerned about her students understanding. The tests were graded fairly and not based on memorization, like most bio classes, but the application of concepts.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: While Professor Woodruff is a good lecturer and makes sure that the entire class understands everything by adding frequent review sections to her lectures, she is not the best at writing Tests. So be sure to get into her way of thinking when it comes to her test questions.

Dr. Woodruff's lecture's weren't great and I didn't get much out of them.. You don't really have to go to them if you can keep up with the material from the textbook or recitation section. The key is in the TA. If you get a good one, the class is a snap but this professor  wasn't great at actually teaching.

Dr. Woodruff is a very nice lady and you can see that she cares about her students. However, her lectures are absolutely horrible. She very disorganized in the way she presents her slides. Go to office hours and get to know her.

Grading is strict and inconsistent.  Llectures are often random and scattered as are her powerpoints.   She is very smart, but has a hard time creating clear class strucutre.  Many assignments are busy work and she makes you do group work in class that is unproductive.  Her quizes are very difficult, but she curves alot. Did not learn much from her

Professor Woodruff doesn't do a good job explaining the material of the course. Her exams sometimes contain material that have been very lightly touched upon or not explained at all in class. The study material she has given for the course isn't the best either.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Horrible experience, do not recommend

Professor Woodruff was pretty much exactly as I expected. her lectures were overall solid, but could drone on at times. She's very sweet though, and clearly cares about the subject and revels in teaching, which makes it worth the slog. she's absolutely delighted if you answer the questions she poses, so being attentive will make the class better.
Dr. Woodruff did a good job of teaching basic biology (genetics). Her classes were entertaining and I enjoyed having her.
The professor is a really good person. She helps me a lot and encourages me to study. I found really good time in this class.

Really nice.  Show up for class and make sure you talk.  Growth & Cancer is all about your presentation skills and participation!!!! Had her for Genetics as well, do the quizzes.  Study them!  At least one question from the quizzes will be on the test.  A lot of people do really well on her tests so those little points really make the difference.

I hate the class, tooooooo much work. I barely learnt anything from the class, she's so random in the class. She gives a lot of homework and the research papers are so tough to read. I hate her style of teaching, if I got a chance I definitely would drop the class.
Too hard, didn't understand anything

Dr. Woodruff is very intelligent - there is no doubt there.  However, her lectures are very unclear and difficult to understand.  All of the material that I learned about genetics throughout the class, I learned from reading the textbook.  Her slides are extremely disorganized.  I do not recommend this course

Tests are extremely hard; problem sets and practice exams are so easy in comparison and do not give an accurate picture of exams. Classes seem like they are being taught in another language altogether. Almost no one understands what she is trying to teach. Would not recommend this class; however it is a requirement for pre-med.

She doesn't phrase things well and its unclear what will be tested. I don't know why but most of the things that come out of her mouth don't make sense. You can not go to class and still get a good grade in this class.

She is awesome! I wish I could take more classes with her. She really cares about her students and will help you if you express interest. If that isn't enough, she is a pretty easy grader.  She is one of my favorite teachers!

She is a little disorganized, and her lectures jump around. Despite this, I think her lectures are fascinating and passionate. She uses class time to answer any question about biology, however unrelated, and she can usually answer obscure questions , but is not afraid to admit when she does not know. Her tests are easy, but sometimes poorly written
She did not explain things clearly and the TA that I had did not know the material well, which made things worse.
just pick someone else honestly

Professor Wright was a pretty good lecturer and a very nice person. If you're taking abnormal psych don't buy the textbook unless you want to waste $40 its really not necessary. She posts a ton of readings but only a few are used for the tests and since they're not timed you can always go back to them during the assessment. Overall it was good! :)
Very funny and sweet professor, but kind of disorganized

This is one of the best professors I have encountered at brandeis so far. She knows her stuff and i like her delivery a lot. She is also a nice person and being in her class just makes me comfortable.
Rude professor
Worst professor

She is a wonderful person and incredibly caring towards her students. the only downfall is that the class was definitely lecture heavy and you should take A LOT OF NOTES. Her exams were open note but took me a while. the subject was very interesting but there can be dull moments. Just make sure to go to class!

A kindhearted prof who is responsive to student questions and values curiosity. Lectures were enjoyable as Prof. W tells her own stories and she uses poll questions on Echo. The exams are weighed a lot but they're not too hard and it's nice that they are open-note/book. Also nice that announcements were made in class to address syllabus confusion.

Professor Wright is very knowledgeable and easy to communicate with. She really does care about her students. Though her class may feel long because of her PowerPoints, as long as you actively take notes and try to pay attention it becomes easy.
