He is a very interesting lecturer, while the class covers a large amount of material it is kept interesting by the way he teaches it. His test cover a lot so it is best to start studying early. But if you do you will be more then fine.

he might be a good historian, but as a teacher, he is very bad. do not take his class. he is so strict about grades, and he expects too much of his students. I was not even a history major! my worst class in brandeis!
his class is super hard, too much info! he also speaks too fast. don't recommend.
Great lecturer, but you will be taking notes the whole time. it's a pleasure to be in his class.  he's great to talk to also
This class is interesting, and there isn't a ton of work except the two tests are very hard.

This class covers too many decades without any detail. He speaks much to fast and allows no time for questions. There were no discussion sessions. The finals are graded on a rubric scale. If you do not give the answer he is looking for, you fail. I came away from the class without learning anything substantial. Worst class I have taken at Brandeis.

He's a great lecturer, but his class is very difficult, especially for freshmen without a large history background. I would recommend this class for sophomore of junior year. He expects a lot of his students, but it's decently manageable...
He is a great professor!
has a strong jawline and is an impeccable dresser
great prof.

I took professor Herzfeld for Thermodynamics. She makes herself available to students practically at any time by e-mail or office hours. She is very kind. Very clear in her explanations. She may be intimidating at first. Do not be put off by this because she has a wealth of knowledge and is forever happy to share it with you.

A very bright person but she caters to the top five kids and leaves it up to the rest to decipher her seemingly incomprehensible textbook. She remains vague as to what she is going to test you on for both quizzes and exams. Overall, I do NOT recommend this professor and regret ever having taken honors Chemistry

I started hating chemistry after this class. I'm glad I only took it for one semeseter and switched to gen. Chem, in which the professor was actually helpful to ALL students, and not just a select few. You have to go through several methods in order to meet up with her and usually it does not end up being helpful with her explanations.
incredibly difficult, and not in a good way. she has ruined my interest in chemistry

Huge mistake on my part for staying in this class. Herzfeld is a professor that highly values unusual teaching methods and students who are receptive to such methodology. However if you are not one of these students this is not the class for you. Her competency at these methods is also questionable. (Terrible explanations, NO lectures ,etc.)
she is mean and never helps er student!!!!!! i should never never never take she class!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!such a bad teacher!!!!!!!!!!!!!

We are using the text book she wrote, and it is not bad, just make sure do the homework questions, they really help!!!! I like her, she is not that bad. If she doesn't know your name, it means you are not impressive enough. And she said she is terrible at names, so don't feel bad about it.

I am a freshman currently in her class for the second semester, and I find her extremely helpful, and approachable. The class is incredibly difficult but worth it. Her teaching method is unusual, but once you get the hang of it, its very manageable. I have learned so much, and she has greatly heightened my interest in chemistry. Highly recommend.

OMG, she justs asks homework questions the whole time instead of lecturing.  She does make an effort to get to know her students, but sometimes she just flies off the handle if somebody doesnt completely understand a chemistry concept.

She's a strict professor that holds very high standards for her students. Her teaching method can be confusing, but only if the student doesn't follow her assignments. Though the class was difficult, if you approach her with a reasonable question, she'll be more than happy to help you. She can be very nice if you get to know her.
I am five years out of college. I took her my 1st year at Brandeis and hated her so much that 9 years later, I am posting about how awful she was
Rude, unhelpful, and failed to realize we were all non-science people just filling a requirement.
very mean person who makes the class very hard. take only if you need a big challenge and have lots of free time
taking her for the second semester was the biggest mistake..she is sooooo mean...
way beyond bad
bah
Her textbook sux, and she makes us use it.  Her class is superficial - she uses them to show off her knowledge rather than helping students understanding the concepts.
No Comments
Do not take her class!
She is the worst teacher I think i've ever had...she also is justa bad person!
Doesn't lecture in class enough.
by far the worst teacher i have had in 17+ years of education
sucky
grr...
No Comments
if you don't agree with her opinion...don't bother sharing yours, it will be wrong...
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
The class was very planned and attention and participation is required all times. It would be good to come to classes with readings completed.

A typical philosophy course in that it leaves your brain fried and your soul searching for the answers to the big questions. Fascinating to learn of historical philosophical connections and influences between Islamic, Greek and Jewish thought. Readings and lectures were superb.
Awesome class! Great professor. He  is a tough grader on papers but if you ask for help he will go out of his way.

As someone without any prior interest in religious studies of any kind, I was introduced to a very complex and fascinating world. It was interesting to note the differences between traditional Qur'anic scholarship of Muslims and the decidedly non-textual and dogmatic "proof" that Islamists to justify their agenda. Intriguing and relevant class!

This is probably one of the easier Lumbard classes. We read many different biographies of Mohammed and it was interesting to compare and contrast Muslim, non-Muslim, Orientalist, modern, traditional, literal, scientific and secular perspectives. We discussed several controversies about Mohammed's life, old and new (like South Park & Bacile film).

The hardest course I ever took and the best course I ever took. The lectures were incredible and Lumbard really went out of his way to help me when I struggled with the material, especially with my paper.

This was a fascinating and beneficial course. Dr. Lumbard taught this course on the life and place of the Prophet Muhammad in Islam from many different angles, from traditional historical to historical critical and philosophical. He did so incredibly well. The class was captivated, even though they came from so many diverse backgrounds.

Amazing course. Really difficult at times, with lots of reading. But wholly worth it. Professor Lumbard condensed the really difficult readings and concepts of Islamic Philosophy well. I am a PhD student focusing on Sufism/Islamic Phil., and I still use my notes from this undergraduate class. Lots of students from diverse backgrounds loved it.

The amount of information was a bit overwhelming at times, but in the end the course proved very helpful and interesting. Dr. Lumbard taught this course mostly on Quran commentary well. He caught the interest of most of us in the class. Bravo to him for making this pretty obscure field really relevant for us. Less readings next time.

Fantastic course taught by an engaging and knowledgeable prof. Dr. Lumbard knew the field well enough to present many different views on issues relating to the Qur'an and its interpretation. He was incredibly thorough yet concise in his presentations. The assignments were rough at times, but fulfilling. One of the best courses at Brandeis.

This professor was one of the best I encountered at Brandeis as an MA student.  This course was vital in the development of my scholarly interests.  He is demanding, but fair and extremely helpful.  His assignments are clearly designed to help students think critically, write better, and learn a variety of approaches to the material. Recommended!

Brilliant professor who  challenges you to think deeply and take intellectual inquiry seriously. He prepares a great deal for his classes and expects you to be fully present and engaged with the material - definition of a real teacher. If you have any confusion about the material, you can easily approach him during office hours, he is really nice.

The class ranged from devout Muslims to those, like myself, who had never read any of the Qur'an.  He was able to keep everyone interested, while making sure those without prior knowledge of the subject were not left in the dark.  Happy to answer questions and clarify stuff.  Approachable, clear, knowledgeable.  If you put in the work: great class.

Without a doubt my favorite professor at Brandeis. IMES-104A with Professor Lumbard was one of the most engaging and informative classes I've ever taken. The manner in which Professor Lumbard presents material in an informative way and empowers students to learn more on their own really helped me through this very dense subject matter.

Professor Lumbard is hands-down one of the best instructors I've come in contact with. Not only is he a master teacher, but he's an excellent resource and mentor to his students. His heart is truly in the right place.

To say that Professor Lumbard is an amazing, incredibly knowledgeable professor would be an understatement. The eloquence in which he speaks and the concepts he so clearly explains, drew me to every course I took with him. He is hands down one of the best professors in the IMES department, if not at Brandeis.

To say that Professor Lumbard is an amazing, incredibly knowledgeable professor would be an understatement. The eloquence in which he speaks and the concepts he so clearly explains, drew me to every course I took with him. He is hands down one of the best professors at Brandeis and definitely the best i the IMES department.

Prof. Lumbard piqued an interest in Islamic studies. For me, as a secular academic, the course illuminated interpretations of the Quran by theologians, historians, and social scientists. It was a valuable supplement to my course of study, directly affecting my larger focus on Human Rights research and the way I view various actors in the field.

Unlike other lecture classes, Lumbard's are well-prepared and well-delivered, he has a "voice of God" thing going for him. He values student contribution so make sure you participate. He is super approachable and happy to sit down and talk about difficult concepts in class or life during his office hours. Easily the best professor ever.

Islamic Philosophy was a hard and rewarding class. Professor Lumbard is an astounding scholar and a real teacher. A clear communicator, he addressed students' concerns and questions thoroughly and willingly. This class pushed students to dive deep into big questions, understand extremely complex and nuanced topics, and relate them to the world.

This class should be on everyone's short list of classes to take before you graduate from Brandeis. You don't need to have much previous knowledge in Islam to benefit tremendously from this class. Professor Lumbard is an excellent teacher and engaging lecturer. He will provide you a solid foundation on the Quran in this class.

Introduction to the Qur'an was INCREDIBLE! I joined the class without much interest in Islamic Studies or the Qur'an, just a mild curiosity as I had heard from someone to "take a Lumbard class." Then I became an Islamic Studies major. This is one of those essential classes you should take before you graduate.

Professor Lumbard is a phenomenal teacher. I have met so few people with the passion and expertise that he has. He is funny and quick witted and doesn't take crap from his students. He will push you to be a better writer and a more critical thinker every day of his class. Take everything you can with him!

This is the third class that I have taken with Professor Lumbard. He is far and away the best professor that I have taken at Brandeis. Not only does he make class interesting and engaging. He is always available outside of class and even invites students to his home. He coud try to be on time more often, but that seems minor.

Professor Lumbard is easily the best professor at Brandeis University. I was interested in religion before I took his classes but by day 2 of his introduction to the Quran class I was hooked. He is so knowledgeable, engaging and clearly cares about his students learning and well-being. He is an great professor and I could not recommend him enough.

I have taken several classes with professor Lumbard, the best professor I have studies with at Brandeis. Extremely knowledgeable, very well prepared and able to distill complex topics into concise digestable points. Even if you are not interested in the material he is teaching, you should take a class with him.

Professor Lumbard is a fantastic prof. He will definitely challenge you, but he's very friendly, approachable, and committed to his students. He's very encouraging and amazing at distilling VERY complex subjects into understandable terms. His classes are really hard, but enjoyable and totally worth it. One of my favorite professors ever.

Lumbard is a very good professor. He is very clear, and concise. Prior biblical and quranic knowledge is highly recommended. He happily makes himself available, and he is really easy to talk to. The Midterms and the short paper assignments are very easy.

Very interesting lecture, really knows his stuff and presents it well. He/the TAs are very tough graders though. Also screwed us over with the final "exam" - an 18 page paper assigned 2.5 weeks before its due is NOT an exam. Make sure you actually read the Quran, and some prior background in Islam is very helpful for understanding the class.

Absolutely brilliant professor. He is passionate about CS and truly wants his students to succeed (but can also easily tell if a student needs to be weeded out of CS). His lectures are very clear and he does a great job explaining every concept. Thanks to him I have done well in all of my job interviews (going FAANG! :)) He will be missed here

Iraklis is clearly experienced in the field but his lectures are hard to understand. The real problem with his class are the TA's who aren't helpful and give very harsh grades. Expect a lot of hard tests, to lose points for weird reasons, or for the grade to be curved a lot.

Worst professor I've had at brandeis so far. His class was going very fast in a sense you could never truly understand a new topic/concept. Didn't care his whether his students learn anything or not. He was just here to make his salary. That's it.

Professor Tsekourakis is a solid lecturer and really cares about his students and wants them to understand the course content and succeed. Coding assignment grades vary based on the TA (no set guidelines for point deductions), midterm was solidly hard but final wasn't as bad. "Aggressive curve" was used which helped my grade pretty substantially.

Professor Tsekourakis is a great person but not a great professor. It's very difficult to follow his lectures and you expect to go over his slides, which are very organized, to learn most of the content.

Professor Tsekourakis is seriously fantastic.  He's the most reasonable/fair CS professor and seriously wants you to succeed.  He packs his classes with difficult content, so make sure to go to every class or you'll fall behind.  Otherwise, he's a great guy.  Northeastern is really lucky to have him next year, we'll miss him!

hard to understand the structure of the lecture
grading criteria is vague and unclear

dont take this course or you can just take a try

The grading criteria is so vague that when you turn in an assignment that you think is perfect, you only get 60 or 70 points due to various formatting errors. I wrote close to 500 algorithm questions, but I think I will only get a B in this class. The assignment has not changed in years, with strange and vague requirements.

Terrible lecturer. Learning all of the materials from Google and lecture slides. Extremely strcit with grading. Instructions for assignments are very unclear. The exam time is tight, and the workload is large. This is the class where I spent the most time, but received the lowest score. Try to avoid taking his class if possible.

The programming assignment is terrible. When i was taking the course i felt so overwhelm because no one gives me help and i could only think everything about a programming assignment and problem set by myself and no one gives me any idea and hint on how to do that. Class content is easy to understand but the assignment is much harder and harder

His classes are just long tiring lectures where he doesn't explain anything well enough for it to be worth it. If you ask him for help outside of class he is rude and condescending and won't actually help. He also is extremely picky with grading and won't even explain directions properly so you won't entirely know what you need to do to do well.
Prepare for inconsistent grading and poorly written instructions

Good lecturer, clearly cares about his students, is very smart, and has a lot of passion for the subject...but refused to give individual accommodations (violating school policies) and mercilessly took off dozens of points for tiny errors. TAs gave wrong answers on discussion forum for the entire semester and we lost points bc of it. Disorganized

He was a pretty good professor and made classes interesting - especially for an intro class. His grading is seriously tough though. I've never had a professor be so tough. All of the PAs were graded focusing on the most minute details and basically any possible way to take away a point. He's a really great guy outside of class though and available.
One of the worst instructors I've had in my academic career. Doesn't consider students as individuals.
If you are concerned about your mental health at all, DO NOT take this class with him.

Professor won't clearly tell you what are you being graded;  you won't get a perfect grade by completed what the assignment tells you. Professor's teaching philosophy is that students won't learn from lessons but from their own mistakes.  The class is curved, so prepare to stress about not knowing your grade during the semester.

Lecture heavy course with lots of menial problem sets. Lectures were pretty boring and generic and didn't go past what information was included in the readings. The textbook isn't considered mandatory for the course but the only real test preparation in the class was doing the exercises from the textbook.

Doesn't publish rubrics for projects or how they will be graded. Will brow beat you for points left and right over things unrelated to program functionality and style. Things that should be written down for students are presented in a crappy giant lecture room recitation; the TAs believe it shouldn't be recorded,won't post completed slides.
Write very organized lecture slides. Breaks down knowledge in a reasonable way. Very good in general.

He is super willing to help and has really well-structured lectures. The directions for homework aren't always super clear, but as long as you're willing to ask questions you'll be able to do well. He is very very nice and I highly recommend taking his class.
I learned a lot in this class and this prof. was super kind about if i didnt understand something!

Grading criteria is absurdly unclear. Even when your code is completely correct, graders take off 10s of points for small details and are often assume greater breadth of knowledge than the (beginner) students have. Beware, most of your classmates comes from private schools and have done coding their entire lives.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Homework is much much harder than anything done in lectures and is up to you to solve it. Most people in the class are a pain to work with because they have huge ego complexes since they already know the material. Homework guidelines are consistently unclear because TAs and prof don’t understand how it’s like for a student with no cs background

If you have no programming background, you are screwed since most who take this class have coding background. You can do an assignment completely correct, but get 20+ points taken off if you make the code “redundant”, even though it’s your first time learning programming. TAs don’t know how to explain problem solving techniques
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Difficult class, not an easy A being that the class is graded intensely. Be wary!

I think Professor Tsekourakis is a great professor who doesn't get bothered by too many questions, and is very willing to help when you are struggling. It is worth noting that this class is on the harder side, especially for just an introduction course.
The only shortcoming of this course, from my perspective, is that the progress is rather slow and I dont feel like learning a lot. The professor is nice, easy going, engaging, ready to help

The lectures are fast, and the workload is gonna make anyone with no programming background work hard. The grading is harsh af. Homework details are vague and you'd easily lose points due to some requirements that are "only mentioned in the recitation".
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: I attended his first few proof classes but stopped because I could not dedicate enough time. It is a shame; he is an excellent and knowledgeable professor who gave me good advice. Professor Pham will take your math foundations to the next level, and you will gain a lot, but he'll only give that to students who will take full advantage of it.
People who give him 5 either are maths genius student or they just want to fail your linear algebra. 95% of normal students should not trust the 5 star comments and avoid him.

The course has a structure that builds on previous topics. Tests are hard, grades are tough but there will be a curve. Office hours are a must: go to them when you have any questions. To conclude, his classes are good but don't take it if you're looking for an introductory level math class that gives you an easy A, this is not one of those classes.

Terrible experience. Hope you never meet him in MATH 15. You don't understand one word in his lecture, and the homework is 4 times more than Brown University. Not helpful at all. Please just avoid him, or you will have nightmares every day.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Although he's a really tough teacher, he definitely cares for his students, and has lots of office hours in order to help you out. You will be confused during the first few weeks, but as you go on his class becomes more clear and sets a great foundation for the future. If you don't want to major in math beware, but otherwise I highly recommend him.

Before taking his class, I also thought it was a bad class. However, you can see your improvement if you put work into it. His lecture notes help build for future classes. He is also happy to help students during his office hours.

He expects you to already have an incredible understanding of mathematics, and for an introductory math class this is incredibly difficult to parse. He always overcomplicates his examples and exam questions well outside the scope of the textbook, making it very hard to understand what he's teaching and study for his exams.

Lectures are incredibly hard to understand--doesn't follow the order of the txtbk. Not kind to his graders/TAs. Doesn't care if students understand. Also incredibly petty with an ego. Doesn't like criticism and is insensitive to students. One class he said most his students drop/fail even in his lower level classes (bc students arent the problem!!)
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Get ready to study. Very difficult proofs in class, but if you can follow them they are very useful. Brilliant professor, wish he would spend more time on solving rather than somewhat unhelpful proofs. Overall very difficult but good class.
He's the most amazing teacher at brandeis IMO. even though he's tough, I've learned a lot from this class, especially how my type is married asian man.

Professor Pham is obviously extremely intelligent, but the people claiming that he is a good professor are simply incorrect. It may be possible to succeed in his class if you are very skilled at math, but those who take the course out of a desire to improve their mathematics will not get anything out of his lectures. Not a good teacher.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Lam gets a really bad rep; mostly by students who don't show up to his lecture, and don't go to his office hours. He repeats over and over again, "this is a difficult class, and you should put in 10 hours a week." His lectures are often quite confusing at the start, but will become clear once you take the time to understand the material. Great guy!
lectures and homework are hard but its not that bad

He's tough but caring. Be warned: the class is hard and he knows that. He is most likely the smartest mathematician in our era. An era is defined as " hundreds of millions of years". Lam Pham is smarter than you and he knows that. Until you acknowledge that, you will not be enlightened. His teaching will leave you enlightened.
ok
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy

comment: Very helpful professor. I will admit his lectures were difficult, but over time the lectures became easier as I put more effort into learning the material.
Get ready to learn linear algebra by yourself. It's almost impossible to understand his lecture.
Be ready to learn by yourself if you take his course. Probably the worst math professor at Brandeis.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: He discourage students in his own way, such as telling you that even though the course is hard(it should not, based on it's position in all linear algebra courses), few students still got perfect score. He told you to read his text book for at least 5 hours a week, and his homework is 6 times the amount of other schools. His lecture is so bad.

He is incredibly smart, but that makes him a lackluster teacher. The speed and order in which he teaches topics of linear algebra make it extremely hard to follow along, especially for people taking the class for the first time. Avoid his class if you care about your GPA.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Very tough grader and very fast pace. However, he builds your work ethic and you get a lot out of his class. If you put in the extra work out of class you will be rewarded. He is also hilarious during office hours and I love talking to him.

Do not take his class. Started the course with such dense unnecessary material and is an extremely hard grader. Would definitely recommend taking another professor or waiting for another class to open up.

There is a reason why most textbooks start with simple topics. He is the only professor I know that insists people should start with arbitary proofs/definitions.

Linear algebra is not an easy topic, and he will make your life even harder because you basically have to learn everything on your own.
The worst teacher I ever had at Brandeis.
I love Brandeis Math Department. Every teacher is great and reachable here. They all have trackable lectures, except this guy. :)
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: They assume you have a higher level of math understanding than required to sign up for the course so following some lectures is very difficult. They move really fast, they're very lecture heavy, and the homework/exams are very unforgiving. Get ready to learn linear algebra on your own :>
Probably the worst math instructor at Brandeis.  Class is very confusing and little motivation/explanation is provided.
I learned more from the textbook than I did from any of his lectures. His teaching is hard to follow. Don't take his class :)

He is a really amazing professor who genuinely cares about what he teaches and about his students. People don't like him because he sticks to his principles, but those principles are just that he tries to teach in a way that will cause people to actually learn. Be prepared to try hard if you want an A. Otherwise, just listen and learn for a B.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: His teacher was fine but it's really unfair how he graded us: No matter how bad you do you will get a B if you attend the class and you have to do literally everything 10 out of 10 to get an A. This means that, if you tried hard, and get a good grade, but not the perfect one, your final grade will be the same as the students who did nothing.

Mairson is a good lecturer–he is always funny and knows how to make people think. He has a unique grading scheme, where as long as you show up you'll automatically get a B. Unfortunately, this makes tests absurdly hard–he never tells you what to study. If you fail 2 tests, you can't get an A, so eventually everyone in the class just gives up.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: While Mairson has given some of my favorite lectures in any computer science class, pretty much everything else about the class is miserable. Inconsistent lecture quality that doesn't translate well to classwork, no written information about what will be on any given test, and a poorly thought-out grading system that demoralizes students.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Harry's class involves no slides and no zoom recordings. He spends ~80% of the class telling stories and the rest trying to teach the subject. No matter how well you do, how attentive you are, if you haven't already been exposed to 90% of the material, you'll get

Don't get the difficulty 4/5s. Could be they changed the curriculum this year. The course is graded within mind of passing, failing everything would result in a B, moderately trying results in a A-. No need to read book despite claiming so, 1.5 hour of homework every week, the last 15 mins of each lecture is rly difficult but never tested --sleep.

Tons of homework and he doesn't really explain how to do it in the lectures. Everyone was always panicking and nobody knew what was going on. Unless you're an outstanding student, you get a B, or a B+ if you're a master's student. Over a third of the class flunked a quiz and he blamed us for not studying hard enough. The others weren't much better.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Lectures are easy in exchange of accuracy so it could get confusing if you don't read the corresponding chapter in the textbook, but textbook reading is supposedly compulsory so you really should read it anyway. Lectures are more like a guideline for you to know what parts are going to be on exams instead of for you to learn everything need to know
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: You will spend so much time and effort slaving away at his homework but at the end of the semester, as long as you genuinely tried, his grading is pretty lenient.

Professor Mairson gives a pretty tough class, so don't be under any impression that it's an easy pass. I've genuinely been confused on how to approach something a few times, but office hours are generally pretty available. However, he also surprised me because when he saw something wasn't working, he took a class to discuss it, taking our input.

He's a good man and he's very intelligent and therefore a bit out of touch with us mortal students. His slides were a mess and were impossible to understand, he also is difficult to follow when speaking. Pretty much had to teach everything to yourself and that's not why I paid to go to college. Avoid if possible, however he is happy with effort .
rating_tags: Respected--Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Harry is one of the nicest professors in the program, and genuinely cares for student growth and success. However, be warned that he believes in challenging students, and gives rather difficult PA/PS's. Despite that, he doesn't believe in punishing students for failing a challenge, and you'll almost certainly pass the class if you do your best.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Never Ever Take This Class Unless You Have To!

Lecture heavy, but you'll have to learn most of the material on your own. Condescending. Did not have the decency to wait for me to leave office hours before mocking my intelligence and reasoning. Avoid him.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Most of the time you show up for lectures, spend 30 minutes listening to a relevant lecture, and 20 minutes listening to one about cello design, then get the feeling you already knew the content of the lecture from 11A, 12B, or 21A, it was just presented in a really weird way here. Don't take this class unless you need to for the BS.

I love this man, he is what a professor should be. He is really a genuine person who loves his job. He cares about his students and always entertains us in class. Don't be fooled this class is extremely difficult and the concepts he teaches is hard but so is life , you will learn so much. As long as you try and learn you will pass. <3

Easy to get a A level if you do your work.70% percent of the lectures is easy to understand and the rest 30% won't be cover in exams. Textbook is good but hard and not necessary (many contents won't be in exam). Just go to lecture to know what would be cover in exam and understand all homework sets, Trust me, you will smash the exams.
Like the guy enough but he change 29a for the worse
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Good guy, terrible teacher. Only reason the class is hard is because you have to teach yourself the subject. He over complicates simple topics, explains things poorly and puts you down for asking questions. Quality of the class was poor. Not that helpful in office hours.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: A nice man who was willing to help you if you put in the work to ask for it. Difficult class though, homework is optional, but not necessary. They call the class 21(Your Grade) because everyone gets B's

He should be a professional cello maker or a stand-up comedian. His typical classes are about 10 minutes for telling jokes, 20 for his cellos, and the rest 20 for rushing through anything related to the course, not to mention he was late sometimes. Instead of explaining things well, he just gave you handouts and let you read them by yourself.

He so deeply cares about student success. I super disliked the class material, but I really enjoyed Mairson. He was amazingly helpful and kind. He managed to sugar coat one of the hardest classes I've ever taken and make it feel significantly less horrible than it was. He is an amazing professor.

Definitely the most interesting comp sci class I've taken at Brandeis. You will need to spend time reading the assigned papers to participate in class, any earnest discussion is welcomed. concepts from scheme are useful to know. Has a joke for every theorem (you will hear each many times)+you will learn more about cellos than you thought you wanted

This class would be both excellent and challenging if the professor weren't a complete jerk. He tells you you won't be able to succeed on the first day of class. He is belittling and uninterested in students. While the lectures are quality, having to interact with this man will make you want to stab yourself in the eye.

An "old school" teacher who needs to upgrade his lectures, which consisted of him verbally tracing lines and lines of code and cracking the occasional joke. Tests consisted of mostly esoteric problems - so do the work and know the material well!
By far the best CS professor I had at Brandeis. Made what could be a dry topic clear and very interesting. He's clearly passionate about what he teaches, and it really makes a difference.

Mairson is one of those guys who's been around a long time. Thus, he has tons of great jokes (which he's told over and over). You can't help liking him after he tells you the one about the lobster. His class wasn't too tough... now if only I could remember what it was about.
Best CS professor.  Always helpful and clear and really funny.
Excellent professor.  Very helpful outside of class, very clear explanations in class.  Makes the class material more accessible by adding jokes to his lectures.
Crazy ****, but great guy and good professor. Just do your work :)

This teacher may be easy if you are an art major but if you are just trying to get your fine arts credit out of the way steer clear of him. Although the course does not require any prerequisites; I promise you that you will not understand anything he says unless you are well informed about fine arts.

He's very knowledgeable so his lectures are amazing and very in-depth. If you are somebody who doesn't love art history or like lecture heavy classes then I would probably advise against one of his classes. But if you're interested in art history his classes are a must, because the amount of detail and analysis provided is mind blowing.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Unglaub's Art History courses are really not that bad. He's a good professor, despite going over the given time slot almost every class. However, he's not a tough grader, and his tests were not hard. If you don't like, or know how, to memorize material then I do not recommend you take this class.

The lectures are dense but super interesting and include everything you need to know for the exams. Notes have to be pretty detailed but he is super flexible with deadlines and also is a pretty generous grader for exams and papers. Clearly very passionate about his work.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Unglaub is very knowledgeable and he teaches very well! I really learned a lot! Love this class!

My favorite professor at Brandeis!! His lectures are so awesome and really engaging. He is also really helpful during office hours and will try his best to help you succeed. Also very very knowledgeable about art history

He rambles in his lectures and starts speaking in an Italian accent for some reason some times. His slides have no content so you have to show up to understand what's going on. He is a very easy grader, but be prepared to memorize 100 paintings and their titles, place, material, and period just for part of the midterm.

Amazing lecturer! Extremely knowledgable of high/late Italian Renaissance. Be prepared to be taking notes all class but his lectures are really interesting and he provides a ton of information. Take good notes and listen in class, you'll do well. One of the most knowledgable profs in the art history department! Also extremely accommodating

Prof. Unglaub is truly amazing. His lectures are very insightful and his passion definitely shows. He tries his best to make the lectures amusing and you'll find yourself more interested in the content than you had anticipated. He is very reasonable and accommodates to your needs if you reach out and talk to him.

A truly amazing professor!! His lectures interweave the social, political and economic milieu into the art topics in a way that makes the information extremely interesting. A class and teacher that can simply not be overstated. He sparked my interest, and made the topics enjoyable. Literally the best teacher I have ever had!!

Excellent teacher! I love his classes! His teaching style may seem unoriginal/boring for some people, but I personally love it. He's very helpful and flexible when it comes to any problems you may be experiencing. The class atmosphere is very comfortable and he makes the information interesting and engaging. I definitely recommend him!

Loved this class. He speaks like a textbook, but it's worth to pay attention because he makes it really interesting and funny too! Tests are a little difficult, but if you study well can definitely get an A.
His lecture about Michelangelo's Last Judgement altar wall in the Sistine Chapel still sends shivers up my spine.  One of the best professors Brandeis (or anyone else for that matter) has to offer.
Prof. Unglaub is amazing! Not only are his lectures crystal clear and so easy to follow, he is hilarious! Definitely one of my favorite classes.

Did my research with professor unglaub. Professor U made me fall in love with art history and love my Brandeis Experience even more...dont miss the high renaissance class - one of the best classes deis has to offer. Rock on professor.
Professor Unglaub is great. He really cares about what he does and he also cares a lot about his students. All around a great professor.
good class and professor
Simply THE BEST.

He has a real passion for his subject and that is definitely reflected in his lectures. I found it infectious. He really knows his stuff. If you're an art lover, I would definitely recommend this class. If not, you might think it's a little too in depth, but you'll learn a lot.
you have to experience the power of unglaub

I found Unglaub's lectures to be esoteric in tone and he expected us to be desperately in love with the topic to an unfair extent, which was definitely reflected in his interaction with students and grading.  And he's not hot.  Foppish, yes, but not hot.
Prof Unglaub is just amazing. And he's hilarious too and he doesn't even know it! He's great:)
So unintentionally funny!!!  Just listen to him speak Italian.  A real cutie, though.
funniest prof ever, though not on purpose. he's fantastic.
No Comments
No Comments
I really enjoyed Prof. Unglaub's class. I really thought the topic would be boring, but he made it really interesting and engaging. Plus, he is mad cute and soooo sweet.
No Comments

I just love this professor so much. She was so sweet in class and genuinely cared about her students, regardless of how they were doing in her class. She wants you to succeed, so ask lots of questions and be an active part of your learning experience! she's funny--she made me laugh and my class was before 10 am, so that is a feat of its own.
Love her so much!! Such a fun and caring professor! One of the bests!

One of the sweetest professors i've ever had. The only class this semester that caused me 0 stress. all the work is manageable and she is a very lenient grader. I was nervous about my spanish ability going into this class since it'd been a while but i ended up having a great time. Overall very fun and engaging professor-take this class with her!

Raysa is perhaps my favorite professor at Brandeis thus far. She is exactly the professor you want to learn Spanish from. She always greets everyone at the start of class and consistently wears a warm smile throughout the class. She is not a very harsh grader but will give incredible feedback if there is anything that sticks out.

One of the best language profs at Brandeis There is a ton of homework, but is very very easy and manageable. There are a total of 4 speaking she tells you exactly what the prompt is and makes it very easy for you Tons of partner and group work. I had a speaking exam one week I was tired and not feeling it she said come back next week and take it :)

Good professor for the most part, but she refused to fulfill my (university mandated) academic accommodations. In addition, her attendance and makeup policies are incredibly strict. You can squeak through the class if you have a rudimentary understanding of Spanish, even though you're "expected to be at a conversational level" by the end of class.

Professor Mederos is a gem! She is caring, encouraging, and made me feel comfortable speaking Spanish despite my issues with grammar. She was always enthusiastic and friendly. You will get a good grade as long as you participate and make an effort. She is a great professor to have and a lovely person as well.
Very sweet, understanding, and considerate. I never really enjoyed learning a foreign language until I took her class. She makes me a very comfortable learning space.

I had Professor Mederos for the fall semester (everything was on zoom). She was incredibly accommodating and super sweet. Despite not being able to be in class, she was always really energetic. Even if you're not amazing at Spanish, as long as you show that you are doing you're best, you will get a good grade. Kindest professor I've had!
Grading isn't very clear and it can be hard to get participation points if you sit next to people who don't know any Spanish.

Prof. Mederos is a wonderful, caring teacher that every student likes. Depending on your previous level of ability, you will have to do a lot of practicing on your own to prepare yourself for oral and listening assessments. There are no vocab quizzes, just homework that usually isn't graded, in-class essays, and a few tests.

Raysa Mederos overall has truly been such an amazing teacher here at Brandeis. Not only is her class on the easier side, but she also does her best to provide extra credit and help when needed. The course itself does require some work but you can honestly get by doing a minimal amount. Overall I would recommend taking this class because of Raysa.

¡Ella era excelente! Mederos provided a perfectly balanced class, from variety in homework assignments, to group projects, to engaging the students during lectures. She really took the time to make sure you were understanding the language. I've taken Spanish many times, but this was the first time I ever felt truly comfortable speaking the language
Really energetic, fun class even at 9 in the morning. Actively tries and succeeds at making the class lively and engaging. Really understanding about any issues you may have. Great class!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: She's an excellent teacher who truly cares about you making progress in the Spanish language. A lot of her focus is on class participation and being able to speak clearly. There were a couple of group projects. Her tests and quizzes are very straight forward. She allows you to take your essays home and correct them for a better grade.

I love this woman. She looks like she's singing or dancing as she teaches sometimes, she's so bright. One of the warmest women/teachers I've met; playful and genuinely interested in her students' lives (I speak from experience!) She even sent me a sweet email about things I've been doing on campus! Let her know if you need extra help and she will.
Amazing teacher and an easier class!

She's so energetic and a pleasure to learn from. Very helpful if you ask for it, and always displays her passion for the subject and for teaching. Can't wait to take the next level of Spanish with her!

She's very energetic and accommodating. Plus she's great at explaining even when she teaches in Spanish. The more you participate, even if your pronunciation and grammar suck, the more likely she is to be forgiving. Take this class to better your listening and speaking skills. She focuses less on strict grammar rules and more on comprehension.

Her enthusiasm made for a great class dynamic, especially for a conversational spanish. One of my favorite classes I've taken at Brandeis (surprisingly). She is very supportive as long as you demonstrate that you put in effort.
She is very energetic.  Always seems to want to help.  If you attend class and participate you should do well in the class.

She's definitely energetic, especially for a 9am class. She may be small, but she is not a woman to be messed with. She believes in mutual respect. Doing the homework and participating in class will pretty much guarantee you a good grade. She's there if you need help, but YOU have to approach HER. My conversation skills have really improved!
She's energetic and all, but not a great professor. She doesnt teach much other than whats in the book. the exercises are all based on conversation and sometimes boring. she's mediocre.
Amazing in class. So much energy and enthusiasm, witty and fun class. Sometimes the energy is overwhelming, especially if you take the class at 9am (which i did).
One of the most enthusiastic Spanish professors that I've met. She really tailored the structure of the class to fit our needs.
She is a ball of energy and so much fun!  She is extremely forgiving with deadlines and takes on an honest interest in all of the lives of her students.
Amazing..favorite professor of all time, passionate, knowledgable, amazing.
Unless your'e a guy, she'll hate you. Most unorganized professor I have ever had. Didn't learn anyting new.
THis class is so unstructured. ANd when I asked her for help all she could say was o well.  What a b****
Fantastic and caring professor. You can write topics that you interested in in her papers, and she will give constructive criticisms to your performance. Wish her good in retirement!
most disorganized professor i've ever had. really nice and interesting person but just does not know how to teach properly. i wish her well in retirement. otherwise a fair grader and good person.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Hilarious--Graded by few things

comment: Love her so much! She knows A LOT about fashion and culture if you talk to her in the office hours. Pretty tough grader on papers, but interesting readings and discussions in class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures--So many papers

comment: An acquired taste, it took me quite a while to get used to her, but I absolutely do not regret taking her class. She has a very strong personality and is not afraid to share her opinion. She is extremely available to help outside of class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Hilarious

comment: She is so narcissistic, rambling about her engagement with her dear Hilary the former SoS.
This professor was abrasive and condescending in lecture unless you suck up to her. Goes on tangents that are 1) inappropriate and 2) nonsense. Beware.

I have had Prof. K for 4 classes and it's all true!  She NEVER uses the books, ask her before you buy.  She always goes off on tangents but they're always funny, you gotta learn to appreciate her.  You'll get an A if you come to class, make an effort to talk to her and don't mind listening to her self-indulge.
useless.
Indifferent, irrelevant, unchallenging, narcissistic. Easy A if you suck up to her. Does not respond well to student opinion.
Superb!
outstanding
she teaches the weird history course. it's fun to learn about more than just treaties and wars!
I liked her stories about trips and clothing. More importantly, she taught me to write well, which I will always appreciate.

Professor Kelikian is nuts, but in the very good way.  She's always willing to talk about her subject and is very helpful.  She does have a tendecy toward tangents, and likes to show strange films in class, but that just makes it more interesting.  The stories and in-jokes are pretty amusing too.
I can hardly even remember her class anymore, only that she spent more time talking about her trips and custom made jeans.

Awesome! Though I felt like the class was tough once in a while (she's a huge grammar/word-usage nazi), I enjoyed myself.  Always willing to help us improve our writing overall and full of unbelieveable (but true)information. The amount of readings on French courtesans, hermaphrodites and the like was amazing.  I recommend her classes to everyone!
terrible, totally crazy but not in a good way, should not be teaching and should be in AA
Professor Kelikian is awesome. Her lectures are fantastic and often entertaining. The subject of her classes are always interesting. Nothing dull or boring here!
Best professor ever!!!
A lot of notes, which has been said before. She also assigns an absurd amount of reading, very little of which is actually essential to the class.
Great Class! Can't wait to take another class of hers.  Very cute too.
She's the best!  So much fun and craziness--in a good way!
Two enthusiastic thumbs up for Prof. Kelikflix
too crazy to teach, needs better class discussions
Brilliant individual, and gifted professor -- in writing as well as history.

She speaks very quickly, but says a lot of interesting stuff.  Sometimes goes off on tangents, which are either useful or funny.  You have to take a ton of notes and be very careful to write correctly in your papers.  Her sense of fashion is incredible.
You must take copious notes in her classes. It seems like she doesn't even take a breath when she lectures. Her course topics are fascinating. Has great taste in footwear!
No Comments

First year of college. Favorite professor ever. Enlightening, captivating lectures. Love how passionate and articulate he is about anthropology. 
Assigns readings for every class, but they aren't graded. I got an A without reading a single one.

He is very knowledgable, professional, and considerable. To students, he is always encouraging and never hesitate to give compliments. Definitely my favorite professor so far in college. Academically, his grading is not that harsh and he does do curves. But ANTH116 is still a class you need to put effects in to do well.

He is the best prof I ever met in university! He gave positive feedback on my papers and answered my questions with patience. It is better to finish all of his reading, then you will be enjoyable in his class!

I love this man! I took Anth5a over the summer online, the first anthropology class I ever took. He is so kind, knowledgeable, and passionate about the material. His lectures could get a bit boring because they were like 3 hours long on zoom. We also had to write like 3 or 4 papers, but they were based on interesting documentaries that we watched.

This Professor is very knowledgeable, and he would like to answer every question that I asked. His ANTH128 is the first anthropology class I took at Brandeis, and he inspired me to explore anthropology deeper. ANTH128 is about meanings of material cultures, and the class is very attractive.

This Professor is very knowledgeable, and he can answer every question that I asked whether these questions are related with the lecture or not. He inspired me to explore anthropology deeper, and he was very patient. ANTH128 is about the meanings of material cultures, and it was enjoyable.
One of my favorite classes at Brandeis. The material can be challenging at times but Prof Urcid made it exciting to engage with. Take a class with him!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Very friendly/wholesome human. Would often go over allotted time period (90 min class). Very passionate, and I would recommend him if interested in Anthropology.

Took 5A+116A with him. He is incredibly knowledgeable, always had an answer for students who asked questions, even if they weren't related to the topic of discussion. As long as you skim through the readings and pay attention to the lectures, you should be ok, but this isn't a class you can slack off in. Gives great feedback on written work.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Gives good feedback--Amazing lectures

comment: Really great guy, very interested in this topic (writing systems and scribal traditions) which makes class and lectures that much more interesting. Definitely LOTS of reading and can be challenging to follow sometimes if you're not familiar with everything (which I wasn't at first). But you definitely learn a lot and it's a cool class.
rating_tags: Respected--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Overall, I found his class and teaching style to be redundant and outdated. I was bored about 90% of time in class because he just doesn't engage. It's crickets when he asks a question. More concerningly to me, though, are his casual sexist and homophobic remarks throughout the semester. It made me uncomfortable to be in the classroom. Never again.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Incredibly passionate and knowledgeable. Super passionate about his students and the topic he teaches. He packs in a lot of information and expects you to know it, but he teaches incredibly well and will go over any information that you need. Be ready to commit a lot of time, but his passion keeps lectures enthralling
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Amazing lectures

comment: I have never seen someone more interested in the material as well as the learning of his students. Also he is a delight to listen to. English isn't even his first language and he speaks it more eloquently than i do.

Meaning/Material Culture. He posts everything on LATTE so no one has to purchase a textbook. This is a READING INTENSIVE course. Don't take it if you're not up for reading long articles every other night. The class discussions are intriguing, but occasionally dull. I recommend taking the course only if you have a FERVENT interest in Anthro.

Javier is great! He can be confusing at times, and the class can seem really hard, but if you stick with it he will stick with you. All he wants is for people to be as excited as he is, and I have loved having him as a teacher in multiple classes! You really can learn a ton from him, and he takes an interest in his students.

He really expects you to do those readings!  He's absolutely wonderful when teaching a small class, he really makes you feel like he's genuinely interested in what you have to say, and when the class is really into the discussion, his joy in teaching is obvious.  This class made me sure that I had chosen the right major for me.
Did I walk into the same room as everybody else? I found him to be incredibly boring and although he gives off the caring feel, I really regret my interactions with him.
Awesome teacher who knows a lot about what he teaches.  He can be boring, but he can also make boring topics interesting.  Very passionate about the subject and genuinely cares about the students.
So so great! Best prof I've had. Seriously cares about the subject and his students
Javier is the man!  He teaches really interesting stuff and often has a thrilling way of presenting it.

I learned very little from this class, we barely had enough field time.  In groups we had no guidance aside from that of the group leaders and the lectures were not very interesting.Prof. Urcid is obviously very passionate about the subject but he was not a good teacher for this class.The syllabus was useless we were assigned stuff at the last min

Prof. Urcid is so nice, and cracks anthro jokes like calling people "sharp as a sacrificial knife". He really cares about students and is deeply passionate about the material. This class is really helpful for learning anatomy later because it gives you literally the skeleton on which to build further anatomy study on.
Didn't learn a single thing from this class. Lectures were boring and not necessary to do well on the papers. Take out other teachers if possible.
Used the word germane a lot. I enjoyed his class and he graded very leniently.

Javy is my hero.  He opened my eyes and cultivated my love for anthro.  I have never seen a professor who was so excited to be teaching about his subject, and that enthusiasm was contagious.  I wish I could take ONLY his classes!
He is the most organized professor I've ever had. The material is hard but he makes it seem a lot easier
I heart Javier
Great professor.  He offers neat classes, so take one.

Professor Greenlee was one of the highlights of my political science career because she was very knowledgeable but she also would randomly email me opportunities and internships and write me paragraphs about why she thought of me and why I would be a good fit.

very vague instructions for papers and assignments 
unclear grading criteria

Professor Greenlee was okay, a decent and clear lecturer (sometimes boring) but I found her condescending and a bit high school like in the way she taught and spoke to students. She isn't always clear what's on her tests but if you take good detailed notes you should be fine! SHE TAKES ATTENDANCE SERIOUSLY so show up to class/discussion section!

super knowledgable, patient, cares about her students, knows her stuff. graded on a few tiny quizzes on terms (u can always choose), midterm, 2 small (pretty informal) papers, and final. always clear about what will be tested. sticks to slides so its easy to catch up and organize notes. love her teaching style and would 100000% take again!!

Professor Greenlee is awesome! Be prepared to take notes, especially regarding vocab. She's not necessarily clear on what is and is not on tests/quizzes, so be sure to read and take thorough notes. If you go to class, take notes, do the readings, and participate, you WILL do well in her class.

I've taken a few classes with Greenlee and she was awesome. She's a pretty tough grader. Tough, but fair. Her feedback helps you improve your writer and her lectures are really good, it keeps the students engaged. She can be a little blunt with her comments or interactions but she is certainly the best.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Take her seminars and you will learn so much. She helps students reach conclusions by themselves instead of lecturing. She definitely makes you work for the grade and there is no guarantee you will do well even after putting in work but that was a rare experience I had at Brandeis because often the professors are too easy.

Just do the work, read and participate and you will be fine. The tets are easy because you can make a group study guide. The essays are interesting and reasonably graded. She has good office hours and will reach out to you to keep you in the class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Solid choice for anyone interested in American Politics. The grading is tough and the tests are hard, but the material was covered relatively clearly and Prof. Greenlee is great at keeping students in-line and preventing class from getting too sidetracked.

Shes a cool teacher but theres long lectures with little discussion. The tests are ridiculously long and theres little prep time. Its a fun class and really interesting with a cool semester long assignment
Prof. Greenlee is really invested in your learning. Put in the work, pay attention, and do your readings and you'll be set!

Professor Greenlee is my favorite professor at Brandeis. I was deterred by negative views I saw, but I found them all to be completely false. She's tough, but if you put in effort, respect her and your classmates, and take the class seriously, you will have no problems with her. She is truly brilliant and cares about students who put in work!
rating_tags: Respected--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: absolutely horrendous professor. Terribly boring and refuses to give definitive guidelines for assignments. gives grades based on how she likes/dislikes you.

Professor Greenlee is great!  She's really knowledgeable and friendly, and she's really patient, too.  Kind of a tough grader, but you just need to pay close attention to the assignment info.  She's really super nice, I highly recommend taking a class of hers.
Great class. One of few classes in politics department which had assignments that served a real purpose.

Deliberately evasive when asking for help in regards to test preparation or writing papers. Very unclear. Knows her stuff but doesn't seem to be a very good teacher; she seems much more focused on her research.

She's obviously compensating for her youth by being incredibly inflexible and assigning too many extras, like long, useless LATTE posts for EVERY class. I think she's mostly interested in her research. She doesn't seem to like teaching.

I greatly enjoyed Professor Greenlee's classes as well as having her as a thesis advisor.  She was patient and a great resource for discussing ideas. I found that her classes did take some work during the semester (dense reading, pop quizzes, research papers) but her tests are straight forward. I also enjoyed the class discussion opportunities.

Clearly more interested in her research than in her students. During lecture, relies on a PowerPoint and under no circumstances will she deviate from it. Assigns the most vague essay prompts you will ever see in your life, and is both distant and deliberately unhelpful is one-on-one conversations. She acts as though she would rather not teach.
Worst professor at Brandeis so far! Egomaniac, only cares about her status, not about her students. I worked my butt off in her class and she didn't recognize any of it. Not helpful, don't take her!
Not Awesome at all.
Awesome.
Great professor.

I really enjoyed the class and her teaching style. She does tend to move fast, but she will go back if asked.I couldn't stand the discussion groups. They were absolutely useless.the readings aren't necessary to keep up, since she sums them up, although you do use some of the readings for the midterms and finals, but she lists them for you.
Attempts to prove herself to the rest of the faculty by being fairly inflexible. And don't even get me started on the lack of the powerpoint posted on LATTE.
No Comments

Her lectures move fast, and she lives off the powerpoint (which she DOESNT post on latte). Notes for each class take up 3 handwritten pages. Expect your hands to hurt. The TA (tim) was good. Grading wasnt too bad, just memorize her "lists" (she loves those) and you can BS the rest on tests. Overall interesting class to learn lots of political terms

Professor Greenlee is very new to teaching and can sometimes move a little fast with her slide show. Lessons she plans for one day tend to take three, but we still seem to get to everything. She also spends a crazy amount of time looking for entertaining pictures for her slideshows.

Takes a while to gain an understanding of what's important in the class as the lectures do not exactly align with the contents of the textbook. Grades not received for work submitted over a month ago. Lots of work which does not really help in exam preparation. Moderately easy class but a little disappointing for students who actually wanna learn.

Rude professor but a wonderful scholar. I asked her questions and she asked me, " do you really listen my course?" She even checked my watching record in front of me and found I really watched. My friends also talked about she looked so dismissive when asking her question. However, she is really good at what she is teaching.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: Unorganized lectures, content from her tangents will show up on exams, dislikes bio majors that are taking her class (even out of genuine interest in ecology).
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: It's not worth it to take this class.

She knows her stuff and I respect her but I disliked the dismissive way she spoke to myself and many other students in the class. Her lectures can also be quite organized and (although I'm generalizing) if you ask questions that aren't praising or flattering her, she will cut you off and answer you pretty rudely. Unbelievably sassy at times.

I learned tremendous amounts in Prof. Hitchcock 's classes and highly recommend them to my peers. She cares deeply about her students and is invested in knowing them personally and guiding them to success both in and out of the classroom. She goes above and beyond in furthering ENVS and BIOL departments and creating opportunities for students.

Took both BIO17 and BIO39 and loved both. She's a delightful person who cares a lot not just about her students' learning but about making science (& research) more accessible, which I've always really appreciated about her. She also has a fantastic story about a bat that I've retold to so many people, so if you take one of her classes, ask her!!

I liked that the format of this class is so different from other courses, even other Colleen courses. You're not really lectured at and instead talk in small groups, which I found engaging. It's reading and discussion heavy so make sure to go to class ready to talk about the readings.

One of my favorite classes at Brandeis. The emphasis on scientific communication was incredible and something I haven't really gotten in my other stem courses here. The content wasn't difficult and my biggest takeaway was practicing accessibility in academia/science. Excellent course that I highly recommend !

There are a lot of readings but they are interesting and relevant to the course. Moreover, it is a discussion-heavy class, so doing the readings allows you to spend class time discussing instead of lecturing. Professor Hitchcock is great at facilitating  these discussions and encouraging students to participate and share what they've learned.

Professor Hitchcock is an amazing lecturer and person. I always looked forward to class because she is extremely passionate about the subject matter and I knew I would learn a lot. She clearly loves to teach and her excitement is infectious. She genuinely cares about her students and wants everyone to succeed. I would highly recommend her courses!
Lectures are somewhat sloppy and seemingly minute details are centric parts of tests for some reason.

Takes a long time to grade. Not a mean person. She is very passionate about her field of studies but her lectures are not very organized/she would go on tangents about other stuff and get off-topic. Exams don't always align with lectures/readings and you get marked wrong even if there are multiple possible correct answers.

Exams are pretty easy if you have a general understanding of the course material. A lot of the material is really simple for people with a biology/ecology background. Homework is interesting and encourages you to go outside and document the plants and animals you see, but be prepared to have to spend time in nature!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment:
I agree w previous review for BIOL39B.
Dr. Hitchcock is very kind, passionate, and caring, but the course format can be boring as most of her classes are discussions on the readings. This gets tiring, as it feels like we aren't learning a lot FROM Dr. H, but rather from her readings, which she assigns A LOT of. Difficult to understand test grading

I hear a lot of bad things about Hitchcock, but honestly she's not bad. I think as a person, she's really nice and caring about her students, she really wants them to learn about science and to do better. However that goes to say that she could be better with how she teaches, as her tests are not usually lining up with what is taught on the slides.

Yes, she is unorganized and a slow grader. Besides that she is a great and passionate person and professor. If you can't get a hold of her over email, stop by after class/office hours. She is friendly and approachable. If you take initiative to meet her, she's helpful. She helped me gain experiences/opportunities that I couldn't have without her.

Professor Hitchcock is one of the worst professors I've encountered, an interesting lecturer, yes, but the most disorganized individual you will ever experience. You have to email her *12* times in order for her to email back. She provides no support to her students. I would never take her class again and I wish I didn't the first time.

Doesn't hold herself to her own deadlines. Takes over a month to grade assignments that we could've used the feedback from to help us on other assignments. Meanwhile, she gives us very little time to complete incredibly long and writing-heavy tests on topics that were never covered in class and with questions that have multiple valid answers.

This woman is clearly very passionate about the subject and is a very good person. As a professor, she's not the best. She did not do a good job of adjusting course load to the Zoom format and I found the hard exceedingly difficult for a basic biology course. She was a mess and was not helpful when I expressed concerns with grades.
The professor is not accountable to her own practices and deadlines, watch out.

Prof. Hitchcock is very knowledgable and passionate, and she really cares about her students. When we were sent home due to COVID, she quickly adapted her syllabus and was very understanding. Her lectures can be a bit hard to follow, and her tests are very difficult, but if you do the readings, take notes in class, and study, you'll be okay.

Prof. Hitchcock is a sweetheart and she is really nice. However, the class is all about reading scientific/ecological research papers. That is all you do. Everything is based on the research papers and the readings are not easy. The class made me hate my major (environmental studies) as well as ecology (something I'm supposed to be good at).

During lectures you should make sure to be well rested because she gets lost in tangents about boring topics that might cause you to fall asleep. She also barely ever responds to emails if you have an issue so you have to hunt her down. If you dont pay attention in class the tests are still relatively easy but you will get no scale with grades.

Was very confused with this class because the lectures were fine and made sense (can be boring though and she rambles a lot), but the tests were confusing and half the time, I didn't even know what she was asking. She won't curve exams, so you get what you get. She is pro-citizen science and makes the class participate in iNaturalist.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Hitchcock is a nice lady, but she is disorganized in her lectures and is not clear a lot of the time. She also gives pop quizzes.

Ecology is a pretty fun subject. Hitchcock is here to fix that! Taught a class of environmental studies kids like she was lecturing pre-meds. 010 do not recommend as a biology elective or as an environmental studies class; take Evolution and Biodiversity (BIOL16A) instead, since Morris is a better lecturer, more fun person, and easier grader.

the professor makes the lectures boring but simple. However, the quizzes and post-lab quizzes are harder than they should be. Furthermore, the professor does not seem to care to explain the questions during the quiz and is rude when asked for help. The class is way more stressful than it should be for an introductory bio lab class.
Dr. P is the best professor I've ever had. The class organized well, carefully thought out, and taught well. Exams are hard but always within reason. Would recommend this class to everyone!

Highly recommend taking the course. The professor provides a great experience during office hours by answering the students' concerns whether it is about the experiment, postlab, prelab, or projects. While the grading for the test might be slightly rough, there are many partial credit opportunities available for the questions.

made stats and learning about math actually really enjoyable, and i highly recommend taking this course over psych stats for psych majors. grading was really fair as long as you take good notes, the PSETS and final will be easy. plus free attendance points if you go to every class. really helpful in office hours and a great professor.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Biostats was a really great class where Dr. P got you to understand the theory behind the math. Caring and helpful during office hours for checking answers and talking through confusing topics. Utilize TA office hours. Problem sets can be tedious/time consuming but easy to do well on them after corrections. Glad I chose biostats over psych stats!

Dr. P is a clear lecturer. Content could get confusing but made more sense after doing lab. Presentation projects had clear rubrics, not too difficult. Never stressed too much since pre + post labs are based on effort and had great TAs that didn't grade harshly. Exams are reasonable, questions sometimes confusing, you need to know material well.

So many projects that were heavily weighed, and graded by TAs so depends if the TA is a tough grader. Had two exams that were challenging but doable. Need to attend lectures (attendance taken but also material covered is important for lab and exams). Recommend going to office hours as well. He can be intimidating but is very knowledgable.

Professor Piasta was a great lecturer this fall. I learned a lot from this class and all the work was very evenly distributed throughout the semester. If you have any questions, or need clarification on assignments, or presentation feedback, he emails with a fairly quick response time. Exams were all based on lecture and lab material.
I like him.

Dr.P is a great professor to have in your corner. He is great at explaining tough concepts and is a great resource for talking about your academic career and success. He is incredibly caring, smart, and overall excited to teach and for you to learn. The class is pretty tough and demanding but at the end of the day you will learn a lot.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment:
Dr. P is a great professor - he's readily available outside class, even for things not directly related to the course.  It's a tough class with a lot of work, but if you keep up with lectures and labs, you'll be fine.

Side note - the cool kids call him Daddy Piasta.  Everyone else calls him Kene.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Literally gives zeros like they are anything, uncaring for students and does not care that students have injuries, causing them to miss an assignment. No makeups no matter what in this class even if you missed an assignment in the lecture due to Covid. According to him its your fault for being sick and injured. Ruthless
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Biostats was not easy and the material is not very "fun" and Dr. Piasta knows this. He's here to help you know what you need to know and did this very effectively. He is very knowledgeable and cares.

By "so many papers" I mean that you should expect to be reading (and writing) for several hours a week in Biolab. Tbh, I hopped on this site to see if I should take biostats with him and reading other reviews made me remember what a G he was. Put in your effort and don't be shy to ask questions. One of my best profs/classes
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--So many papers

comment: I took Piasta for biostats and bio lab, and in both classes, he was super helpful and really good at explaining things. If you are every confused at all go to office hours, it will save you

It was a pain in the butt to get through when I was taking it, almost to a point where I started disliking the class.
