comment: Prof Berhane is AMAZING. She makes Business seem super fun, and believes that her students can succeed, whether or not you've taken a Business class before. She really wants each of her students to do well. BUT, she'll make you work for it.
Worst course I have ever take in Brandeis University

He always miss deadlines. We do not know grade for midterm and homework before final. For midterm and final, only get a score without explanation about where lose points. He does not care students at all. Although he said students can set time discuss exams with him, he never reply to you to confirm the time. The worst professor I met in my life.

Gindi taught straight out of the textbook and was very disorganized.  Consistently five minutes late to class.  He is very bad at answering questions that are asked in class.  He essentially refused to host actual office hours and he rarely responds to emails.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: The professor delivers clear lectures. He knows the material very well. I feel this professor is underrated.
Not supportive and always late for the class. You have to self teach a lot.

It shouldn't be a very challenging topic, but professor Gindi made math 35 the worst class I have ever taken at Brandeis. He does not explain well and skips many induction steps. Also, the midterm exam is not related to homework at all. There is no review exercise since he said our in-class examples could be used as review exercises.

He seems like a really stubborn person, he refuses to use latte to post assignment but uses google classroom just because he thought it was easy to him. He said he wanted people to give him constructive suugestions, but when someone really did, he never took them into consideration. The worst professor/class I've ever met/taken at Brandeis.

Professor Gindi is not accessible outside of class and he refuses to provide any notes or class recordings. He doesn't even have a syllabus so it's difficult to know how we are graded. 

Maybe he's a genius in math and is too good at what he's teaching, he often skips steps without explaining why.

MATH 35 is the worst course I have ever taken. Fourier analysis is not a super hard topic to learn, but Steven's course is making every concept and theorem difficult to follow. He does not explain his steps and makes so many assumptions.

I am taking his MATH 35, and he is the most irresponsible teacher I have ever had. He is does not provide any recording or notes for students to review, and he does not even have office hours. The lactures he gave is unclear and misleading. He is making too many assumptions and skips a lot of steps which make his lecture difficult to understand.
Does not give any study material or anything, does not upload slides/notes/lecture recordings. Refuse to help students

I took 35a with him. Basically repeat what the book says and lecture no more than the book. Often miss key steps in the induction process. Don't say what he wrote on the board, so hard to keep notes. Often late for class. Have health issues so we have to wear masks. Overall, an experienced lecturer compared to other professors in the department.

His lecture is very very boring and not clear about many definitions and proof. 
He didn't want to hold office hours(he said his office is too small,lol.), and even he did, he said he'll give each student five minutes. That's ridiculous since the class is about real analysis.(It's not a big class! We only have around 20 people every lecture)

Mark was a cool guy, I really enjoyed taking his class. If you want to do well you have to meet with him during office hours which is fine if he didn't keep bringing up his mummy collection. However, for the entire month of October he came in wrapped in toiler paper claiming to be a "mummy". Apparently he also did this in the spring too.

He kept mentioning mummies which was very interesting. My favorite reading was chapter 2 from "All about Mummies". I enjoyed our last class where we watched The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008), I cannot wait for the Mummy 101 workshop in the Fall.

He only talked about mummies. I met during office hours, but he was on the phone for 3 out of the 4 meetings while I sat in his office. He graded my paper as 9.2/100, saying it was a typo and supposed to be 92/100. He invited me to dinner at his place; he said he would show me a collection of artifacts from the Michigan state.

good enough. supposed to take attendance but oftentimes it doesn't happen. asks students for their thoughts and participation, but doesn't always let you finish your thought and doesn't always really seem to take it into account, it's more like he's using student comments as tools for his own lecture and to further his own thoughts and points
He is a really, really, really good speaker !!

terrible experience. Lecturing was tedious as another comment says that he has the ability to make interesting content boring. He is super unclear about everything, the syllabus, papers, attendance, web page, you never know what he wants. And makes things extremely confusing. Do not take
Mark has a way of making interesting things boring.  In short, he sucks.
horrible at lecturing, assigns bs readings

The class is very disorganized, there is no connection between the many readings and the class discussions. Topics are cool, but the lack of coherent discussion makes the class boring. Community Engagement idea is interesting but badly mishandled and thus not effective.
Cannot lecture to save his life. assigns too many readings and never discusses them. the class has no real basis..he talks about nothingness most of the time
I'm not impressed at all. He fell asleep in class, still haven't gotten any graded work back (the semester is over) and he never had a lecture planned. Not very engaged with students.

Needs better organization and the professor should attempt to give a good solid lecture every now and then. Winging it doesn't work for this class. A lot of readings and little discussion clarifying them. A lot of outside activities required.
Very good class.  The professor is great!

Someone who will truly be missed, but deserves her retirement more than anyone. She was a gem to the school that we have been lucky to have. So knowledgeable about her field and passes her passion for journalism onto her students. She has the best stories that intertwine with course material that is clear. Fair grader.
She's a great professor that really knows her stuff! She's not an easy grader but gives an opportunities for improvement. The workload is also not too bad.

McNamara was my favorite professor at Brandeis University. I learned more in my two classes with her than the rest of my AMST major combined. She personable, helpful, and genuinely cares about about her students. Do the readings and try to have something interesting to say in class. Brandeis is extremely lucky to have her.

Kind of wish we could do some kind of Zoom for when this class went online since I took the class to have another semester with Mac, but she did her best given these unideal circumstances. Great person, great professor.
Take a class with her and you will see. Brandeis got lucky with this one.
As a STEM student, she made me appreciate the news and what it means to be a good consumer of information. She got me taking another class with her, because she ROCKS!

Eileen is one of the best professors I have ever had at Brandeis, sassy, savage, jovial and kind, she will tell you exactly whats wrong with your writing and how to improve without making you feel stupid. Unless its grammatical in which case shell give you a look and you know youve messed up. Always available to support you, 10/10 great prof.

I would take this class over and over if I could. Professor McNamara is unbelievable and we are so lucky to have her. She is so knowledgeable and really wants to share that passion with her students. We had amazing class discussions and the more you participate the more you learn because you get to hear more of her fascinating experiences.

McNamara is a true expert in her field. She takes the skills she honed for years in the newsroom and brings them to the classroom. Her expert knowledge shows, and she's extremely engaging both in and outside of the classroom. She's a true gem of the highest quality.

She is truly amazing. She won a Pulitzer Prize, but she's down-to-earth and hilarious. She has the most interesting lectures and stories. She is really into class discussion. She brings up complex, controversial ideas. Her feedback is like gold. It's so helpful and on point. She cares a lot about teaching and helping us grow as writers.
The best professor! So helpful and passionate. Genuine care for students. Best in her field.

Prof. McNamara is the BEST. She brings real life experiences to the journalism program and ALWAYS has interesting classes. While they may not be the most academically challenging, they were by far the most rewarding. She is a great mentor and wonderful person!!
She is AWESOME! Amazingly inspiring. Really funny. Allows rewrites. Totally wonderful mentor

Very caring professor and extremely excited to teach about Kant! Kant's Critiques are notoriously difficult (even for Kant scholars), but her lectures are made very accessible without sacrificing the depth of the material.

Professor Moran is a lovely person and knows her material well. Attendance isn't mandatory and she believes in blind grading. Her lectures are helpful, and if you pay at least a little attention, the reading isn't necessary (but they are interesting). I didn't do any of the readings and didn't goto any lectures past week 5, but still got an A.
nice person. grant extensions.

The readings are engaging and class is structured well, but we never answer any of the questions we start with. A lot of questions go responded to but unanswered, and you walk away feeling more confused than when you started. I felt like class was a waste of time, and there are other professors that are more clear.

The readings are hard to sit through mostly, but once you understand them they are incredibly interesting and worthy of obsession. She has a monotone voice so don't take one of her classes too early or else you might fall asleep.

knows the material well and knows what she's talking about, but doesn't convey that information well. rambles a bit and speaks unclearly. down to earth and relatable, not pretentious. very patient and accommodating of different learning styles. the 2 exams are open note. very friendly and approachable  a good person but not a great professor

material is tough, though she tries to make it understandable. weird curriculum that doesn't build a great foundation; doesn't really go over major movements, instead focuses on philosophers who contested the dominant thinking of their time. rambles, which makes lectures confusing and boring. nice person with good intentions but not great execution

Lots of dense readings, but she covers them in her lectures each class. She's a really chill person and that comes off in her teaching style (which is a plus in my opinion). Mid-term and final are both open note for Intro to Philosophy.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Took her Kant course on moral theory. Interesting material and down to earth professor. Very helpful in thinking about/planning essay topics. Would definitely recommend for anyone into philosophy.

Philosophy is not my subject, but Prof. Moran made it a little more interesting.  The class is environmental ethics, but it's much more philosophy. A little boring at times, but a good class. Fair grader, she'll give you as much help as you need. Reading semi-mandatory. Attendance not taken.
I didnt buy the book and I only did about half the readings and I still got an A. Class is terribly boring but you have to go incase of quiz.
the topics were all interesting, but she was just pretty boring. it is not uncommon for students to doze off a little during class. but she is very nice and enthusiastic about what she is teaching.
She is awesome.

I learned a lot from Prof. Habibi's class though it's a little boring. Very lecture heavy, 2 exams and a paper. Workload isn't too heavy but you have to be really prepared for the exams. Pay attention in class and write down notes. Habibi is very knowledgeable about the Middle East so make sure to go to his office hours. They help a lot!
Great Professor and you will learn from his lessons a lot!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: This is a great professor very nice, and you will learn a lot from this class!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Habibi is great, especially if you meet with him outside of class. He is very helpful, gives good feedback, and is knowledgeable on a range of topics related to the Middle East. Definitely recommend

If you try to participate, engage, and meet with him outside of class, Professor Habibi can give you so much beneficial advice and feedback. He is truly one of the most caring professors at Brandeis and although his classes are lecture heavy, theyre interesting if you pay attention.

Professor Habibi is the best professor I've had at Brandeis. He is accessible, wants you to succeed, and is very knowledgeable. If you meet with him and get to know him, you'll understand he is one of the kindest people.

Professor Habibi is clearly a very nice person and his teaching abilities are fine. The subject matter is not very difficult at all, and you probably need to be considerably bad at Economics if you do poorly in this course given his lax nature and easy to fair exams.

Attendance is mandatory - but I personally don't learn anything in the class. Don't even try to take note - you can't. No homework. Self-studying is expected. Make sure you read all the textbooks and homework and memorize any graphs or concepts that seem important. You can squeeze all the studying for the subject one week before the exam.

Professor Habibi is clearly an expert on the economics of the Middle East. However, that doesnt mean he can teach. He reads right off of his slides which he posts online, yet attendance is mandatory. There really is no need to go to class or do any readings. You dont really learn anything in the class. All you do is memorize a bunch of stuff.

Great Professor. A very knowledgable person who can have discussions with you on a range of topics and not just economics. Try to get to know professor Habibi and you will realize you get to meet very few people like him. One of those professors who really make you think out of the box. Have high respect for professor Habibi

By far the best professor at Brandeis University. He is an extremely intelligent person and you have to take economy of the middle east with Professor Habibi, a great great, great learning experience. Do all the readings and make sure you are interested in the economy of the Middle East. Professor Habibi is a specialist in this field. Cheer*
Boring class. A lot of essays. Don't recommend.

He's a nice guy, but his lectures are dry. Granted it's nice that he gives you a five minute break. He does post his notes after the lecture which is also a huge help. Very knowledgable about the topic though (Economics of the Middle East)

Only group projects and grades are assigned by ranking of model performance in assignments, meaning only so many people can get an A however well everybody does. The projects are also not that interesting or enlightening. Practically gained no insight from this class and the worst grade I've received in the whole 4 years I spent at Brandeis.
Good person! Very nice!

Prof. Peng is the first Professor at Brandeis I know that curves the grades down. No syllabus or grading components whatsoever. Students should have an expectation of what kind of work will earn them an A.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Hong was entirely ineffective as a teacher. Worst class I have taken at Brandeis. There were only group projects, with the same group every time. He gave two weeks of extremely complex lectures on the math behind machine learning, and then expected us to be able to use massive machine learning frameworks without explaining them AT ALL.

Prof. Hong is a dude who is passionate about what he teaches, though the material can be dense or dull at times he does a good job of making you feel the joy and curiosity he so obviously does. His slides are impossible to understand w/out the accompanying lecture so go to class. Homework is not too bad. His stories and jokes are great :)
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: His lectures are a necessary evil, extraordinarily dull, but informative. Miss class? You can read the slides and be left with a looking sense that you just understood nothing. The difficulty can creep up on you. Half way through the homeworks go from easy to staggering. Office hours are a huge help - if only he were like that in class.

Professor Hong is a nice guy. The material covered in this class is interesting but difficult. The good thing is that the homework assignments are not very difficult and there is no mid-terms and finals.

Bad lecturer. He always said, "Feel free to ask any questions." But usually, I was so lost in his lecture that I could not ask any question since I cannot catch anything from him. His final project gave similar outputs from most of the groups, how could he tell which group did a better job?
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: He is a terrible speaker. He grades students by personal preference. Very unfair.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Bad lecturer. If you don't understand what he talked before the lecture, you won't understand after listening to his lecture. I have to take several online courses in order to finish his homework since I don't understand what he said in class. His powerpoints are simple and not helpful. He needs to learn how to deliver knowledge.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Hot topic recently, need a lot of math background, but really useful, professor Hong is super helpful during office hours, and the programming assignment is very interesting.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Pengyu is not a bad guy, but his classes are pretty painful. His lectures tend to be really confusing and difficult, while the homework assignments tend to be incredibly easy. The class subjects are really interesting, but he isn't great at communicating how cool the stuff is. Overall, would not recommend as a professor.

Pengyu is one of the best professors that I've had. Very gracious in character. Encourages student to be learningdevelopment oriented rather than grade oriented. Passionate about anything related to the topics taught, so had useful discussions on my research interests outside his discipline. Highly supportive. (No grade received).

Worst teacher I've ever had in a university. Almost each class was just a waste of time. If the regular pattern is: professor explains something, asks a related question, and nobody is able to answer - something is wrong. And assignments are hard. A friend just switched to another PhD adviser. Never heard anything good about Pengyu as a professor.

Took the last history 80A class he taught at Brandeis. I was so sad when he retired. Amazing lectures and no homework at all. He is so knowledgable in his field, and he really cares about his students.

Brilliant professor! Easy class and he explains the material thoroughly. Everything in his class is arranged perfectly. Generous grader and a nice guy. Lectures are a bit hard to follow though, because his presentation slides are filled with one words only. But other than that, one of the BEST professors in the history department!

Very generous grader - if you just attend the lectures and prep decently for the 2 tests (short essay & a few IDs), you're all but guaranteed an A. James is really passionate about what he teaches - to the point that he'll go on the occasional tangent - and is 100% down to chat with students about the material. Two thumbs up.

Professor James isn't the best at organizing lectures or powerpoint slides. Most slides have only one word or just a picture, so if you need visuals to take notes, this class isn't for you. Also he has something against technology so you can't use a laptop. It doesn't matter much if you just show up to tests and use wikipedia to pass.
Superb!

This professor is knowledgeable and friendly. He respects students' ideas, so be sure to go to his office and ask questions, and you'll benefit a lot. Textbooks are a good source of preparing for the exams. There are only two exams and they are not challenging. Coming to class guarentees an easy A.

I like professor James - he's sweet, especially if you go to his office hours. But if you actually want to really learn anything, I would recommend another class. His lectures are extremely disorganized, and he has very distracting mannerisms. He really wants his students to do well though. Just do the readings and pay attention for an A.
Awesome professor, awesome person! Highly recommend

Overall, prof. James is a very enthusiastic, helpful, and dedicated teacher. Wonderful knowledge of his subjects and quite impartial about interpreting history. His lectures don't always correspond with the text book readings, but they're always poignant and interesting.

Best Experience I've ever had at Brandeis!  I am a Biology major, yet I found myself much more interested in attending Professor James's classes. I took three of his classes Personally I liked history of Modern Japan the best, actually went to Japan this year because of him.  does not follow the textbook he makes the class more interesting that way

I have taken three classes with H. Parker James. He is a great man, extremely nice, helpful, and smart. However, he does tend to organize his lectures in a slightly confusing way. Exams are easy, but you will learn a lot anyways. Love the class, wish he was my advisor =[

Professor James will make you fall in love with Asian history! He approaches Asian civilization as a whole, Central Asia and the Indian subcontinent included. I would have regretted coming to an LAC if it wasn't for this amazing class.

First history class at Brandeis and thought he was very passionate about the subject. Tests were comprehensive. Sometimes classes seemed tangental and strayed from readings in an unhelpful way. All in all, an experience would undertake again if I were interested in East Asian Studies!

I've taken a slew of classes from a number of professors having graduated college and gone on to earn a doctorate in my field. I've also taught college as an adjunct several times. In my entire life, I've never had a worse professor or more capricious one. As noted, she plays favorites to an extreme and I remember her years later and not fondly.
Jane changed my life.  Taught me to be a better thinker, a better French speaker, and a better person.  I will be indebted to her forever, and she is my inspiration as I teach French now.
Very nice person and extremely interested and passionate about subjects. Although tends to say you're wrong when you disagree with her and requires tons of class participation
I found her to be an excellent professor. She was friendly, smart, and cared about her students. Highly recommended!

Jane surprised me.  I thought I would hate her class for what I perceived was its touchy-feeliness.  But if you spend time in her office, you realize that she is a sharply critical thinker who can help you improve your writing and thinking quite a bit.  If you are willing to invest, she will support you in caring and intelligent ways. Recommended
yeah, seriously...god help you if you aren't among the "chosen"

She is not very smart and has a problem if you don't actively help her mask it. She is generally not a very strong thinker, and is very flustered when a student's ideas take her off the track of her monological mind. She's nice though, and some students can learn from her.
Worst teacher ever--only cares for the ones she favors, cannot speak the language she teaches!

A professor who grades you by how much you learn from her class instead of how good you are compared to other students in the class.  She understands her students' individual strength and weakness.  Teaches with great passion, although sometimes she can be cold.
She has her favorite students and if you're not one of them then don't expect anything good from her.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

Really interesting professor. I felt like I came out of this class with a good understanding of sociology. There are a few papers, but you are able to choose your topic and the options are interesting. He provides good feedback on papers. You have to show up for discussion sections.

Sirianni is very knowledgable and enjoys imparting his knowledge and experiences, but he's unorganized and isn't great at encouraging class conversations. When he allows students to add to his lectures with questions or insights, he tends to interrupt them with a long personal story. There is very little room for students to learn from one another.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: He is a very tangential professor and I honestly don't feel that I learned very much from his lectures. Some of the reading that he assigned was informative but I didn't like that he repeatedly assigned his own books. This class was not what I thought it would be.

He is a great guy and is super knowledgeable about the material. Sometimes can be dry and he talks a lot (more like a lecture than a seminar). He likes when people participate in class and ask questions. Nice organization of course materials / topics. Need to read the material if you want to participate. Overall good class.

I loved his class! Great topic really smart professor. Lectures can be a bit long at times but the information is very interesting. Very nice person and fairly easy grader. Minimal homework assignments but be prepared to do essays.

Very good teacher, although his lectures can be a bit long. Easy grader as long as you show up to class, participate, and write the papers. Be ready to write two long papers and do multiple readings. Overall enjoyed the course and would recommend it.
Mostly an essay based class. Lectures are kinda boring, but a really caring professor!
Very nice guy, and very smart, but gives very boring lectures. Lectures are not relevant to the essays. If you do the reading, that's all you need.
Good guy, good class, but man, I couldn't stay awake. Very discussion-y lecture style, likes to ask questions and get participation. Probably would be better in a smaller setting.
he is great :)very kind awesome man. good professor
Amazing prof! Clear and concise, easy to follow and an easy grader...All you have to do is show up to class, listen to him, go to the sessions & the T.As are very helpful when needed.

He is a prof who is fascinated with what he is teaching. He loves Obama, and community development. He is great teacher who has written a ton of books and worked on the Obama campaign. Sometimes he can come off as an idealist, but challenge him and he has stuff to back it up. Smart man. If you don't understand what he's talking about, ask him.
Boring.  Can't understand what he is saying.  Interesting books and ideas, but he is so boring and hard to understand.  Class is great...he's just bad.

She is a good teacher, but sometimes had no patience. Especially if you aren't the type of student who gets things quickly or if you are quiet/anxious. I didn't enjoy the class a lot of the time for this reason, but besides that I'd say she's a good teacher. But you'll be forced to do a lot of participation stuff that's just embarrassing & not fun.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Absolutely incredible professor. She makes the russian language more fun and engaging than I ever thought it could be, and she clearly cares about all of her students (even when they no longer take her class!) I could not recommend her enough, please take a class with her if you can.

Incredibly kind, thoughtful, and understanding. Highly recommend to anyone who either speaks the language already or just wants to learn something new while completing the language requirement. The small class size is great too especially as a freshman taking many intro science courses.
Stumbled into taking russian as an upperclassman for no good reason. Irina is 100% the best professor in any field at Brandeis. Could not recommend her enough.
Great professor. Show up and do the work and she'll help you all along the way
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Very passionate and cares about the progress of the students. She is incredibly helpful and patient with those willing to seek help/learn more.

Irina is hands down my favorite professor at Brandeis. Coming to college with absolutely no knowledge of the Russian language, she made the daunting task of teaching non-native speakers Russian seem so easy. She is an amazing lecturer and a genuinely caring and approachable person. Check out her class and maybe you'll fall in love with Russian!

Prof. Dubinina is an incredible instructor. Teaching Russian to non-native speakers is no easy thing, but she does it so unbelievably well. She is super accessible outside class, and she is very good about uploading powerpoints from lecture just after class lets out to help you study. All in all she is by far my favorite professor.

Professor Dubinina is the kind of Professor that makes Brandeis special. She has a tremendous commitment to the success of her students, and will always go out of her way to ensure her students' wellbeing. Fortunately, there are a lot of deeply dedicated instructors at Brandeis, but Professor Dubinina stands head and shoulders above them all.
Best professor, one I will definitely stay in contact with after graduating!
Irina Evgenina is by far one of the best professors out there. Any class she teaches - take it. You'll be glad you did.

Irina Evgenyevna is the kind of professor that everyone dreams of when they come to college. She is an excellent lecturer and a real pleasure to listen to. She is an extremely talented lecturer and is always available to meet students outside of class. She won a teaching award this year and nobody could have deserved it more.

Professor Dubinina is an extremely talented teacher. She had to work with students who had a wide range of experience with the Russian language and she tailored the class to each one of them. She very available to meet outside of class, very friendly, and eager to dedicate her time to her students. She is the Prof every college student dreams of.

Isaacowitz did a great job teaching a highly interesting Social Psych course. His lectures were always fascinating and he was very knowledgable about the material. Tests were difficult, but as long as you work hard, not too hard to manage an A-/A. He could've had more discussion though instead of just lecturing. Overall, solid class!

Love him! A very engaging lecturer, enthusiastic and funny. Definitely one of the best professors at Brandeis. He doesn't make eye contact when he talks though, closes his eyes, that's the only odd thing.
Best lecturer I have ever had! I would recommend this guy to everyone who does anything related to psychology!

Extremely engaging as a lecturer, enthusiastic about his subject. Very dorky but cute. And his tests have improved since he first started. Because he doesn't rely much on the textbook, coming to the lectures is very important. Overall one of my favorite teachers ever.

He's a wonderful professor.  His tests, if you pay attention to every study, are a breeze.  There will be a multiple choice question or two you'll miss, but it's fine.  Top 20% of the class gets an A no matter what, so just beat everybody else and you're fine.
Best lecturer I've had so far.  He's incredibly interested in what he's teaching and gives very clear and interesting lectures.

I loved this class! His lectures are a tad fast but they are so interesting. He's very funny, and he makes the lectures very clear and fascinating. I look forward to going to class. Hilarious, nice, and a great professor. The tests are not easy, though- they're not hard if you study.

lectures were interesting, he's a funny guy. the tests were much harder than i thought they would be. also, i had to reschedule some tests b/c of being on medical leave and he wasn't very understanding/nice about that..
super fun and interesting. not a lot of work. tests are haaaaard!
Just a great guy and awesome lecturer

The class was interesting, but the tests were very hard.  He words questions very confusingly and asks about very specific details that are difficult to remember.  Definitely not the easy A that people said it would be!
Such a fun class! Not that hard and really interesting
No Comments

Jordy is your garden-variety narcissist and routinely ridicules his students for not being as knowledgeable as he is. Perhaps he's nicer to students in his upper-level courses? When you combine his spite for young students, his 35 years of terror at Brandeis, and his dystonic tremor, he becomes a perfect candidate for retirement.

I stopped showing up to lecture after about 3 weeks because all he did was read off his slides that he would post to the class. From him I learned nothing. It is clear that he is very knowledgeable in his field but he has little patient or care for actually teaching. Do not take his class unless you have to.

As a professor in his field he is very respected and I think he's very smart and knowledgeable. However, he's just not fit to teach an intro class. Ik its a CS class but damn, it's so un-interactive and tedious. he reads off the slides.I

I'm heading into the midterm completely unprepared despite going to every lecture and completing all the homework.

The professor only reads off the slides during lecture, and most of the time it doesn't have anything to do with the homework problems assigned or Program Assignments (which are 30% of your grade). I had to pass/fail the class.

This is my first time learning python and Jordan is probably the worst teacher to learn from. Just reads off slides the whole class for 80 min straight where we learn nothing. I do take notes but they are meaningless when I don't know what I am taking notes on.  good luck unless you have learned Python before.

Today is my 6th lecture in this class. I to this day, have absolutely, positively, no idea: what is going on. Today, half of the lecture was spent looking for Mr. Pollack's mouse. On his computer. Attendance isn't mandatory, but for the record: I have been to each and every single lecture so far. I have taken notes on each lecture. I'm still lost.

I would probably rate Prof Pollack a 5 in a normal year, but zoom is a rough format to listen to programming lectures in. Still, appreciated his humor and patience. Some of the assignments were challenging and required skimming ahead in textbook, but they were pretty fun, and using code step by step as a learning aid really helped get practice in.

This is Professor Pollack's first semester teaching a lower-level CS course. Professor Pollack is knowledgeable on the higher-level CS courses. However, don't take a lower-level CS course with him. His lecture is boring and the textbook is more useful and easier to understand than his lecture. I would not recommend Professor Pollack for beginners.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Honestly, only take this course if you need to. Professor's boring and confusing, so I just turn off the video and do something else while half-listening to the textbook. At the beginning of the course, he said he "teaches by the book", so I've been teaching myself by reading the textbook. It's more informative and more interesting.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: I'm going to be honest about professor Pollack: Don't take his CS10 class! He is definitely a smart person and he usually teaches higher level CS courses. However, he is not prepared for an intro-level class. Lectures are hard to follow and assignments are usually difficult.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: First day of class he disclosed that he doesn't know how to teach an intro class, and that was probably the only thing I learned from him. Lectures consist of him either reading off slides way too quickly or sitting in silence for long periods of time as he tries to fix his codes. Expects us to do hw that require material we haven't covered. Awful

professor pollack does NOT know how to teach this class - his quizzes and exams are much too difficult, he barely teaches (just reads off slides), is rude to students, doesn't provide extra help, and is just in general insensitive of students and their needs. don't take cosi10a with pollack!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: pollack usually teaches advanced cosi classes at brandeis - but he's terrible at teaching the intro class. his lectures are boring, read-off-a-slide, yet too quick for intro students - the textbook is better than he is. the TAs barely know anything / let anyone into their office hours. pollack is very smart, but should NOT be teaching intro.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Tough grader

comment: Professor Kimelman is, hands down, the best professor at Brandeis. I've taken several of his classes. His big secret is that despite his best attempts at being intimidating, he's actually quite nice and very funny. Plenty of terrible puns. Be prepared to work very hard - you definitely earn your grade!

He's amazing. He's a very good teacher but he moves fast and if you don't follow, he gets cranky. He's at his best when talking about the Bible, and if you can get a Bible class with him then you definitely should! He can be moody old man but he's adorable. I think he just really needs a hug!

Kimelman's class is not for the faint-hearted. He expects excellence, and gets cranky when he doesn't get it. I found him extremely intimidating at first. But Kimelman can also be quite funny, and he's not nearly as scary as he seems. He's fantastic, and if you want a challenge, take one of his classes.
He is a great professor and know what he is talking about, but a tough grader. Like the other rates- the class was AMAZING & you won't regret it!

I was intimidated in those days because of his brilliance and he is "hot".  But the secret is that he is a teddy bear inside and he loves and believes in his carefully selected texts, topics, and methodology.

Kimelman builds character. You'll learn everything you need to succeed in college from about a week in this guy's class. Yeah, he's probably going to make you cry at some point, but he's brilliant and pretty hilarious from time to time. Hang in there; it's worth it.
I learned a lot in his class, but preparing for papers and tests wasn't the most pleasant experience of my life.

Prof Kimelman is a brilliant, but very tough guy.  He intimidates the hell out of his students and makes fun of them if they try to ask questions.  If you can't commit to spending hours preparing for each class session, don't take the class!!  I'll never set foot in a room with him again, but I don't regret the experience-- once.
a truly brilliant, well-read, and thought-provoking man.  it made this science nerd an analytical reader.

This guy actually pushed some of the other students to tears he can be so scary.  He teaches using the socratic method so if you try to B-S in class, he'll totally call you on it.  Tears aside, I thought the guy was AWESOME.  I'm not jewish, but if youre interested at all in theology take a class with him.  He's a charecter, if a bit old school.
If you can get over the INTENSE intimidation of this man, you may learn somthing. However, he is somewhat set in his opinions and is not alway responsive to student ideas. I'd avoid him.
Everyone should take at least one course with Prof. Kimelman!  Yeah, he can be scary, but it's well worth the fright.  ;-)  He's incredibly knowledgeable and you'll learn a TON!
He is amazing!!  Everyone should take a class with him.  He seems intimidating at first, but show no fear and his nice side comes out.

Professor Abusch is wonderful. He is a serious professor and scholar, and definitely an expert in his field. His lectures are interesting and very detailed; you can tell he puts quite a lot of work into them. He is very compassionate and helpful to disabled students.

To the students who think that NEJS 142b was "boring:" you were in the wrong class. Basketweaving 101 is down the hall, buddy. Abusch is one of THE living masters of the field, and his enthusiasm is contagious. Attendance is mandatory because folks who don't get it tend to skip. Forcing you to drop the class is his way of keeping out the riff-raff.

I took his ancient Babylonian witchcraft and demonology class a few years ago; the students who didn't get it were expecting Jewish theology, not Babylonian magic. Prof. Abusch assigned some of the best texts in the field, and he was able to bring that material to vivid life and enhance the texts with original reserach and a unique insight.

His class on Genesis was very text/grammar oriented.  His syllabus left something to be desired and we never really knew what he was grading us on.  We had one "midterm" (but it wasn't really graded) and a final paper.
No Comments

His lectures are scattered, he takes peoples' own opinions as offensive and can be very disrespectful to them.  Though the class size is small, he waves students hands down when they would like to comment, which seems to cause people to want to speak less.  Then he complains that the class doesn't do enough discussion.

He can be a bit tedious as a lecturer, but he knows this about himself, and really does his best to keep his students engaged, such as by encouraging class discussion. He is basically a really nice, interesting guy.
He knows a lot about his subject, gives good lectures, gives a lot of material to read. Interesting class. He's a nice guy. His TAs are very helpful.
No Comments
No Comments
I took a course on dealing with evil in the ancient world, which turned out to be boring.  He lectures on and on...*yawn*

I took Dealing With Evil in Ancient Babylonia.  I purchased less than half of the books for the class, and read less than half of the required readings.  He's a tedious lecturer, but attendance is required.  His TA's grade EVERYTHING!

One of the best professors ive had at brandeis, very smart guy and definitely should take a class with him at somepoint before graduating.  He is sometimes late and can go on tangents but he is well worth it.  Make sure to get down the main points he makes
He's interesting and knowledgeable, but his eccentricity is too much/his standards too low for you to get anything out of his class except a good grade.

The guy clearly does not care at all about his students. He gives out A's like candy for very poor work and is routinely 20+ minutes late to a 50 minute class. If you want an easy A, this is your guy, if you care about learning from your college experience then you should find someone who respects your time and effort.

I've taken two classes with him, and he's amazing. Probably the most interesting, eccentric professor at Brandeis. Write the essays based off of what he says in class and he'll give you a decent grade.

Best professor at brandeis. Brilliant as hell, but doesn't have the slightest clue what his current geographical location is. Make sure you have a notebook just so you can write down the hilarious stuff he says. Produces about 4-5 gems per class. Write the papers using your best judgement and you'll get an A with no problem.

Awesome class I was sad when the semester ended.  I am still fascinated by the amazing reading list the professor put together engaging and thought provokıng ın every way.  Professor Levin is truly brıllıant, he does not need a coherent syllabus because the class relıes on discussion and participation and he always knew wha
I love Marty...he talks about the same thing everyday but he's funny and sweet. As long as you write good papers you will get an A. And by good papers I mean write what you talked about in class.

Levin is pretty old, but is a genius. His lectures can be a bit boring and he is often repetitive. But his grading is easy. I read only one book out of the 6 we were supposed to, and I got A-'s on all my papers. Take good notes in class, and write about the themes he reiterates in class and you'll do fine. Participation not graded papers 4-5 pgs

Awesome professor, really challenging and cares about students. Was an amazing thesis advisor. Genuinely brilliant. Has that whole absent-minded professor thing going on but can recite anything from memory.
Space Cadet demeanor is a front...he knows exactly what you are doing and will make fun of you mercilessly if you are not paying attention...which you should be because he is a (mad) genius.
Can't lecture coherently or maintain any type of syllabus.  Painful course.
Interesting subject matter, but lectures are vague and repetitive.  We talk about the same thing everyday, never getting into depth.  Really nice guy though- takes the class out to dinner!
very caring and sweet, fair grader as well. make sure you participate and she Is a little unoganized but love her!

very sweet women and an easy grader, but quite organized and honestly not that great at teaching the material. the kind of person i'd love to be my grandma, but not my professor. if you actually want to learn the language, i wouldn't recommend unless you're prepared to do a lot of self-study outside of class.
Lovely teacher. She has been my teacher in multiple Hebrew classes and she has done her best to make sure that I am successful. Such a nice and caring woman, 100% recommend.

She was a great professor! The class required a lot of participation, but as long as you went to class and did the work, you did well. She was a super easy grader and would barely take any points off of quizzes for mistakes. She also really liked to sing in class and try to make it fun for everyone.

She was a really nice professor. Definitely wanted students to know the language and participate. Loved to sing hebrew songs in class and have students sing. Some ppl hated that, I didnt mind it. Pretty easy as long as u do your work, shes a fair grader too
when my dad asked me what i wanted for graduation,"another semester with Esther"!
shes very nice but its an irritating class to wake up to in the morning
Very approachable, will help with anything, makes sure everyone understands the language.

A very nice woman, but i don't like her teaching method.  She basically will make you read from the book in groups for most of the class time, every class.  She does very little actual "teaching" and also uses methods that can be confusing for students first learning hebrew.
nice lady kinda disorganized
Sweet woman. Loves to sing in class, and engage students during class. Quizzes and tests are easy if you understand what you do in class.

Esther is an excellent Hebrew teacher and a nice woman. She often uses music to help develop vocab. She grades very fairly, she's out to get you to learn, not to fail you. Homework was only occassionally collected. Course included a midterm, final, and several quizes.

Prof. Berger is a nice guy and obviously cares about his students.  His lectures were a bit scattered and he isn't very well organized... things seemed more confusing after his lectures.  Still, he compensates in the grading process and gives a great study guide.
Really first-rate if you are interested in going on to Graduate School.  Makes the subject exciting if you are majoring in the subject and want to get a PhD
A very good teacher for serious students.  Good to study with if you are planning on going on to Grad. School.  Average, but helpfula and friendly teacher otherwise.

Intelligent, Kind, Helpful, Absentminded, Easily Distracted. When your a kid and you imange a college prof, this is the guy. He does everything he can to help you learn the materal, listens to students, knows his stuff, and is a leanient grader. He can also forget what he's talking about, get off topic, or become very enamored with a certain topic. You either love or hate this guy. You either go, ah this is what college is suppose to be, or you say, isn't that only in movies? I loved this prof.

He was a very kind, gentle teacher, but I can't say I learned very much in his class.  His lectures were hard to follow.  I would have preferred to have dinner with him and chat rather than sit through his three-hour lecture.
Easy grader.  Kind of easy to confuse.  Complained a lot about how useless the Usem requirement was.

true story.  one day he comes to class and talks for about 10 minutes, and then completely forgets what he was going to talk about for the 90 minute period.  so he cancels class.  which is cool... sorta...

Took class philosophy of time and space with him. He is a weird guy, a bit absent minded, but he's a nice person. I learned a lot of neat things about spacetime, i never thought i would be able to take such a cool class.He listens to students,
Funniest Laugh EVER! do ANYTHING you can to make this man laugh!!!!! Supernice, really quirky, loves to LAUGH!
The man is simply ineffective as an intellectual of any sort.

he's out of his mind. and granted, mathematical logic is not the most interesting topic in the universe, but he didn't do much to make it more interesting. His handwritten book on the topic was helpful, though; I got an A despite scarce attendance.
The man is a bumbling self-centered boob.  Not so much a bad guy, just horribly misguided.  On the bright side, he's an easy grader.

on god's green earth's i will not take Professor mitchell's class ever again. not in undergraduate school, not in graduate school, not even a seminar after. her lecture is extremely dry and boring. it does not relate to the class (i am taking childhood disorders). she should not be teaching this class. it is a major mistake. Please . i am desperate
honestly regardless what class u pick of hers , the syllabus will probably be extensive but she is one of the best at Brandeis and a very down to earth person , rarely offers extra credit though

Genuinely my favorite professor in my entire college experience. She is an amazing and extremely effective educator. Brandeis has a lot of professors that have PhDs but don't necessarily know how to teach. But Dr. Mitchell both knows exactly what she is talking about and knows how to teach it WELL.

Great Professor. You don't need to read the textbook, just go to lecture and take notes. Most of the stuff she tests is on the slides. Her tests are easy if you know whats going on in class. No other work than a few online open notes quizzes and online open note tests. Very chill class but also super interesting and she's great at teaching. 10/10 !

Interesting material, however, I did not find the majority of lectures to be engaging. There is a lot of material covered and I felt like the way the class was organized made it hard to absorb or relate to the information we were given. Professor Mitchell seems very caring and I enjoy her personality. The class itself was pretty easy to do well in.

She's an excellent professor. This is the second class I have taken with her and I absolutely loved learning from her. She's really nice, accommodating, and encouraging. She's very lenient. She is transparent about expectations. She cares about student success but she won't spoonfeed you. She has very high expectations so be prepared to work hard.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--So many papers

comment: She's an excellent professor as well as a really nice, caring, and accessible lady. She can explain challenging concepts to a 5-year-old with ease. That being said, her tests are immensely challenging and she has high expectations. Her TA's are easy graders but very slow in grading. She's encouraging but she won't spoonfeed you.

She is pretty nice, but do not take her class for an easy A. You need to work for the grades in her class, and it's important that you pay attention to what she says during her lectures. The grade is dependent on a few things (just exams and quizzes), and there isn't a participation or homework grade to soften the blow of a bad test grade.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Mitchell is REALLY REALLY REALLY a nice professor.
One of my favorite professors. She made the lectures very clear and super interesting. She's clearly an expert in the field. Gold star!
Really good/solid professor. Teaches well.

Just easy A. The number seems to be a high level course, but in fact it's just introductory. Easy test (as long as you watch lectures and check the slides), very little workloads, just nice gradings. Everyone I know in that class got an A. Best class for psych major students to fulfill group A requirement.

I took Prof Mitchell's Human Neuropsych course and found the content interesting, easy to understand, and well-taught. Your grade relies heavily on your exam performance but you get some leeway with textbook work. You do have to purchase a textbook, but overall, I'd recommend this class to any neuro or psych majors.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Great teacher

Dr. Wijendran is super nice and knowledgeable and is always accessible outside of class. She triggered my interest in nutrition and this class will be very helpful for people interested in the science of a healthy lifestyle. Great professor, easy grading, the materials are easy to read and the instructions are clear.

Professor Wijendran is one of the best professors I've had at Brandeis! She goes out of her way to make time for each and every one of her students. She truly cares about her students and supports them in any way that she can. The content is thought-provoking and interesting, and her teaching style is engaging and inspiring.

Dr. Wijendran is an amazing professor. She cares about her students so much, & it really shows. She always makes herself available to meet with you about any questions (related to life or the course). There are 5 take-home tests in this course, & they are application based questions. As long as you put in the work, you will in succeed this course.
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: An amazing professor & talented educator; She works really hard to make sure students are feel supported without holding their hands. Her lectures are dense, & through the semester I was re-watching them to catch all the information she was saying, but regardless, its nice to know everything she says is what I need & there is no fish in a textbook.

She's really sweet and forgiving of students' mistakes. She is genuinely invested in a student's success and is a very easy grader. I highly recommend this class as an elective for the Biology major and it is a fun class. Her tests and quizzes require critical thinking but, if you understand the concepts, you will be fine. This class is an easy A.

Dr. Wijendran did a great job teaching BIOL42, considering it was her first time teaching this course. She really cares about her student's performance in class, and is always available to answer any questions you have through emails or office hours. She's clearly passionate about physiology, and is overall a very caring and understanding person.

Genuinely one of the most caring and sweetest professors! You can tell she is very knowledgeable and passionate about teaching diet and nutrition. I found the course material extremely helpful and also applicable to my everyday life, and thought the professor did a great job with pacing and content. Highly recommend!!

A sweet lady who visibly cares about her students' success and values curiosity. The lectures, however, can be a bit tedious to sit through as Prof. W spends too much time waffling about future or past assignments, and both her handwriting and speech can be difficult to make out. As long as you organize well when taking tests, you should be okay :)

She is a very sweet and understanding woman. She switched from timed tests to no time limit halfway through the tests, so they became easier. Group project and discussion posts can be annoying if your group doesn't do any work. Her lectures can be a bit dense and boring.
The professor is very nice in terms of personality! She must be a very knowledgeable person, but the accent and the writing are really hard to understand.

I'm sure the professor is a nice person. However, even as a person who came from a public high school with 3000+ kids and more than 30% Indian population, I can only understand about 70% of the lecture due to her accent. She doesn't use the textbook, so I can only study by reading the PowerPoint, which makes her existence optional.

She is really nice and the class was pretty interesting. On the down side, lectures were a bit boring and unorganized. Additionally I had difficulty understanding her sometimes because of her accent. However, she demonstrates great enthusiasm for the subject (nutrition) and has lots of experience working as an RD, so this made for a great class.
whether in class or not , tends to be disorganized and very nonchalant about her approach to everything , lectures are wayy too long and usually are not engaging

While Professor Gutsell is very nice, and she does put a decent amount of thought into her lectures, her tests are extremely difficult. It seems there are multiple answers to each question that could be right. Beware of this and make sure you study hard for her exams.

She's a solid professor. She teaches well. She can be a bit disorganized, and unclear at times but when she finds her rhythm she is terrific. She does give a lot of work but is very reasonable and a big believer in fairness. She is really nice and approachable as well. Very fair grader but you have to work hard to get good grades.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: The content of the lectures was interesting. There are 3 tests that make up most of your grade. The tests are hard but some questions are usually dropped when it is graded. She did not respond to any of my emails this semester, but she was helpful in office hours. Overall, I enjoyed the course content but the lectures were a bit long.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Lectures are way too long and hard to pay attention to. Her multiple choice questions on her tests are always ambiguous so no matter how much you study the material, the questions will mess you up by the way the answers are worded. On top of that, I sent her emails regarding very important information with no response and it's just unprofessional.

Gives good lectures, if a bit lengthy due to over explaining. Encourages group participation and sets expectations accurately. We had a textbook and were assigned readings from it, but I never opened it and still earned an A-. Overall, a good, solid professor, but nothing spectacular.

Do not take a class with this professor. For such an interesting topic, she really killed it and not in a good way. Her tests are very hard and each question has numerous answers that are all correct. When I went to talk to my TA about the test, he literally couldnt tell me why I was wrong about a few of them because I explained my answers so well.
Gutsell is a really good lecturer. I felt like I had a decent grasp of the material after each lecture, before I even opened the textbook. She also gives good study guides for the tests!!!!

Anything Above saying that it is an easy A is a lie... She makes many of the multiple choice questions on her tests have multiple possible correct answers, and even if you know the material really well, it is hard to do well on the test... She requires participation through Learning Catalytics (another $12 charge)... It is hard to do well!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Professor Gutsell is a really young and nice person. Her lecture is amazing. She introduces many interesting psychology researches in her lectures. Take notes in class and get the participation grade, you will get firm A. There are two papers; the longer one is only 5 pages.

Did not expect much from an introductory, lecture-based class, but Professor Gutsell is very engaging and is clearly passionate about teaching. She does try to foster discussion during lectures since she is genuinely interested in the ideas of her students, which is evident in the mini-experiments or surveys in class. Wish she taught more classes!

Prof Gutsell is a great lecturer, she really engages her students and wants you to learn. That said, her grading criteria isn't always super clear and it's hard to give her exactly what she's looking for in your written assignments. There aren't any exams in her seminar which means your grade relies very heavily on a couple big assignments.

Professor Gutsell is a good lecturer and very much knows her stuff, which shows in her presentations. The best part of this class, however, was far and away the debates and "spotlight presentations", which are all student-led.  While I liked the subject material in this class, the grading expectations were so unclear it made it difficult to prepare

Muellner is the best professor imaginable. He is brilliant and passionate and cares about his students. He makes everything you read together more beautiful and interesting. Take his class if you can!
Wonderful, soft spoken and passionate about subject matter.  Extremely knowledgable, available to help and guide students

Lenny was one of my best professors at Brandeis. I took two semesters of Ancient Greek with him, which was very hard and very rewarding. I also took the Western Cannon- it was a pleasure to learn from him.

Lenny made me feel like the lowest rung on the food chain during my thesis...and that's exactly what I needed. He's brilliant and he clearly cares about you if you show even the slightest interest in him. Be prepared: YOU NEED TO EARN HIS RESPECT1

Lenny is a brilliant and devoted professor who is willing to take you to new heights if you're willing to meet him half-way. For a man of his erudition, he is shockingly humble. He only wants the best for all his students. I would definitely recommend trying Greek with him or Mythology.
No Comments
I hated this course.  The teacher was not clear in class.  The assignments were also not clear.
Muellner was awful.  His lectures were so boring, irrelevant, and he couldn't care less about his students

The essays assigned had nothing to do with what we learned in class and he expected you to come up with answers to questions only scholars would even think about.  Do not take this class unless you already have a background in ancient mythology!!

Lenny is the best professor at Deis.  He is intelligient, constructively critical, personable, challenging, friendly, extremely helpful, and resourceful.  He is an amazing authority and a wonderful man.
Best professor I've ever had.  Brilliant.  Challenging.  Personable.  Encouraging.  Open to new ideas, but with a (constructively) critical mind.
Muellner was wonderful.  He has a wide knowledge of texts and their origins, and was very pleasant

Years ago, I attended the graduate history program with Engerman as my advisor. At first, he was all smiles. As the semester progressed, he failed to learn my name, mocked my research in front of colleagues, and belittled me in one-on-one interactions. He was a cruel and unhelpful man and the reason I left academia. Avoid at all costs.

Professor Engerman is no doubt a good lecturer. However, he does not seem to be bothered about student learning. If you seek his help, he is often not helpful, and instead when you go to him the next time with difficulties, his response is usually that that issue has already been discussed multiple times before. So, it is always the student's fault
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: While the course material was often dry, Professor Engerman's style of lecturing and engagement of class discussion both greatly helped to make the subject material understandable. He is also an incredibly nice person and is a good person to chat with.
Excellent Professor. All history majors should take a class with him. Very clear, interesting, and helpful.
Liked the class, lecture did get boring at times.

interesting class/materials...terrible professor...does not help with rewriting, has favorites, thinks all his students know just as much as he does on each topic (if we did, why would we take the class?!)... do not take this class.
Engerman is very passionate and energetic in the classroom, and very respectful of student ideas. His lesson plans are always innovative and intriguing, as well.
No Comments

he's so creative with his use of materials, like using music, video, photos in his lectures to get a deeper understanding of a time period than one can get from books alone. he looks at history as a set of paradoxes, very interesting way to think about it
Good guy, weak class.  I got an A- because I can't write for ****.  Simple memorization for the tests: just bull**** and name-drop.
His lectures were so dry it was like you were sucking on sand.
No Comments

This course was so disorganized that it made it impossible to enjoy or learn anything. It made this difficult semester even more difficult than it should've been. Assignments were returned a month after they were submitted at which point the feedback was essentially useless. The last minute changes made it impossible to keep track of anything.
Awesome professor! She gives lots of insights into the real estate industry. Very interesting class.
Enjoyed her class, learned a lot.

She truly cares about her students. She wants them to truly learn and enjoy accounting and is always relating the textbook to current events. She is certainly knowledgeable, having been in the field. Overall, an outstanding professor.

Extremely nice and caring, acts like a mom and is basically a life coach; highly recommend getting to know her. Very accessible outside of class and even gives out her phone number to students. You will need to teach a lot of the material to yourself, keep up with the chapter readings and HW's to do well. Challenging, but she makes it bearable.

Stoller is a great professor. She is very helpful outside of class, she even gives out her personal phone number! The class builds upon itself. It is difficult only to those who skipped classes or didn't pay attention when doing homework. If you keep up with the material and stay diligent the class is a breeze.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: Don't be fooled by others. This class isn't hard, but you do have to grind. Stoller really encourages all students to always ask questions, until everything clicks. She is like a caring mom - you'll pass if she likes you, but you do have to put in the work for everything to make sense.

Professor Stoller goes out of her way to help her students, and even gives them her phone number so they can contact her. She tries her best to make the lectures interesting, and is a wonderful Professor and person. Would recommend, especially if Financial Accounting isn't your strongest skill-set.

While accounting may not be the most interesting subject to talk about first thing in the morning, Stoller does *try* to make it somewhat tolerable. She is extremely knowledgeable of the subject and really does care about her students. You will have to spend time outside of the class, but if you do all your work, you should be fine. Need eText

She really cares about her students and wants everyone to do well. She always tries to make the material easiest to understand and will do examples several different ways in case that's how a student will learn better. It's hard material but her curves and helpfulness make it an overall good class.

She's not great at explaining things in general, but if you do the work and read the textbook, you'll be fine. She is always there to answer questions (even gives her cell number to students) and is a fair grader (when it comes to curves, etc.)

Charlie is awesome! He makes environmental policy engaging somehow and is clearly passionate and knowledgeable on the topics he teaches. This course has lots of readings, but you can get away with skimming. The course is also very beginner friendly for people who have no background in policy or environmental studies.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Charlie is incredibly kind and passionate what hes teaching. He listens to his students and takes the time to thoughtfully respond to every comment. Be prepared to hear about bats. My biggest regret is not taking more time to chat with him in office hours.

Prof. Chester does like to talk a lot during his lectures, but he's clearly passionate about the environment and teaching it to students. He's a really sweet professor and he tries his hardest to make connections. Additionally he's been nothing but kind with our class and this semester with COVID.

Charlie is the best! He really cares about his students and if you're falling behind he will make sure you catch up. Classes are very lecture heavy. You get reading hw every day about 60 pages each class. You need to analyze them and submit the highlighted PDFs which is a PAIN! If you submit them and the papers you won't get anything less than a B+
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--So many papers

comment: Charlie is an amazing person and a great professor. He is always open to new ideas and is very respectful of different cultures and traditions. The classes are lecture heavy but the exams aren't hard at all. There are a lot of assignments but they aren't difficult. I usually go to Charlie's office chat with him for 45mins- 1hour. He's the best!
The best class I have taken. An AMAZING and caring professor who inspires all of his students to love environmental studies. Everyone should take a class from Charlie!!

Amazing professor, amazing class. Such a caring person, so passionate about what he teaches. Professor Chester's passion will make you passionate about environmental studies. Just an all around amazing professor!

He is a funny guy, give nice lectures. Except final (a paper) you will not have any texts. You will have memos instead. 1 short one and 1 long one. Both are submitted 3 times. You will have a chance to play the role of countries' representatives and debate on treaties and convention.
So easy- guest lecturers stink so I didn't go to class and still got an A+. So easy
too many guest lecturers- they suck
Very helpful, albeit a little disorganized. Great class.
Really knowledgable professor
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy

comment: Thaxton usually lectures the full class, leaving little time for discussion or questions.  Reading books is not necessary because his lectures are direct summaries of the readings.  We spent two classes watching the film Braveheart, two classes analyzing the film, and five pages regurgitating what he said about Braveheart.  Would not recommend.

Thaxton has to be the biggest beauty to ever teach at a college.  The guy brings an encyclopedic knowledge about China to class, and is extremely fair when it comes to grading assignments.  Class time is also one of his greatest strengths, as students remain unbelievably engaged throughout the entirety of his lectures.

It has been several years since I took his class. I'm beginning to see his work referenced on Wikipedia etc, I'm happy his work is published. However, he is an embarassingly self-obsessed type. Above all I remember him assigning a book that contradicted his world view, assigning us to write a paper on either side. And then ranting for weeks about h

They are not lying when they say he has no respect for student's ideas. He does not put in any effort to make sure students understand what he's talking about. Lectures are terribly disorganized. If you don't agree with him on everything in the papers you write, you will not do well. Not a good professor.

Great teacher. Can go on a bit of a tangent, but managed to keep me interested for 3 hour lectures when usually i'm asleep in 50 minute long ones. A bit disorganized sometimes, most of his assignments come at the end of the semester, but very interesting.

While I agree that Prof. Thaxton knows his history, I found his lectures to be like the ravings of a mad man. He's convinced that the Chinese peasants are going to revolt again and uses interviews with a handful of Chinese folks in his own unpublished manuscript to back up his assertions. He also told a story about falling off his roof many times.
Just wanted to pad his rating with a smiley. He's one of the most entertaining psycho professors you'll ever have! The readings are usually pretty good too.

I spent more than a year in rural China after graduation, and learned that Thaxton is almost entirely full of****. His delusions are so amazingly fascinating though, that it doesn't matter how much they're contradicted by reality. Thaxton's world is just plain better! The peasants are not going to rise up again against the govt. anytime soon, but if Thaxton didn't believe it, he wouldn't yell in students' faces with the urgency of a dying diabetic grasping for that last sugar high. In short, Thaxton rocks!

Ramblin' Ralph. Brilliant, but absolutely insane.  Knows everything there is to know about Asian politics, culture, and history, but can't organize his thoughts worth a damn.  Tells wildly off-yopic anecdotes for half the class and never lets his students say anything.
Good Ole Thaxie.  Has a superb understanding of Chinese politics and history after spending years in rural Chinese villages.  His stories are funny as hell too.  Definitely check him out.

If you are having trouble deciding between language courses, take Italian with Servino. She is so energetic and truly cares for her students, yet she is also an amazing teacher. I have been with her for three semesters taking Italian and I am nearly fluent, as are my fellow classmates. Take Italian!

Professor Servino is an excellent professor that really cares for student's needs and accommodations. If you need accommodations, communication with Professor Servino is always respected. She is inspiration and hilarious but she never cut corners when it comes to teaching you the Italian language.

Soooo energetic, considering that the classes I had with her are in the late afternoon. Be prepared to talk because what else would you do in a language class if not speak? I learned so much about Italian culture and life with Prof. Servino. It's hard work but it's fine if you put in the effort. Highly recommended!
Very sweet, a bit tough in the classroom (I'm not good with languages), but very nice and understanding one-on-one.  Also, she's funny.
One of the best professors I have ever had, Paola Servino is a wonderful teacher who has inspired me to continue my study of Italian.
AMAZING...I continued with Italian because of her. She's the best :-)
With a wacky sense of humor, Professoressa Servino really brings character to her style of teaching. The only requirement is a lot of energy and a good sense of humor.

She is a wonderful teacher. She has "molto energia" and encourages her student to be engaged with the work. She is always understanding and very caring. Her class does require a lot of work but the grade definitely reflects how much effort you put into the class. Her class was easily my favorite class. She also bought us pizza. She is molto bene!

very fun ALWAYS encouraging, even to the students who really don't want to be there, VERY PATIENT, staying on top of the work and studying before class helps. she makes you appreciate the language, she is very involving and understanding.. i became a italian minor bc of servino!
Great professor! If you're taking Italian, make sure it's with her. She's full of energy and is very sweet.
Amazing- funny, rigorous, caring. It is worth taking Italian only to have her as a professor- and you _will_ speak Italian by the end.
The best language teacher I've ever had. energetic, funny, genuine--truly passionate. never a dull class. ever. and she's stylish, too;)

He gives students a free pdf of the textbook and solving the problems in the textbook really helped my grade. The homework is a completion grade, and he is accessible outside of class to go through the questions.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things

comment: He has a really good sense of humor and makes the class fly by.

This guy is great. He's funny, willing to answer any and all questions, explains the material well. At times his lectures can be a bit of a bore, since what he covers in class was essentially exactly the same as in the readings, but for the most part this class was a nice, relaxing break from the super-hard class I had right before.

Not impressed with the professor. Learned to let my attention drift during class.  However, the text is great and is free online for everyone with Internet access.  People told me it was the hardest class they ever took. Actually, just keep up with the readings more-or-less and do the exercises (not graded), and you're golden.
Top porfessor. He is a true professional and always arrives to class on time. Loves cats.
Great classes.  Very helpful, kind, reasonable.

Samet is the man. Gives great essay feedback, and is especially cool to students who take interest in the class and bring material from outside of the course into their work. The work is moderate, but not overbearing. He was also very understanding when I had to drop one of his other classes. If you like cognitive philosophy, take Prof. Samet.

Samet is the man. Very helpful teacher, and takes extra time to guide students with essays. Is especially nice to students who take an outside interest in the course, or bring material that is not directly from the class into the class itself. Was also very kind and understanding when I had to drop one of his other classes.

Very kind man, obviously knows a lot about the subject and is generous to his students with essay help. Quick and helpful e-mail response. Not always the most exciting lecturer, but his subjects themselves aren't always the most exciting. If you're interested in philosophy, try to take one of his classes.
No Comments
No Comments

After many years studying Japanese in college, graduate school, professional institutions, and in Japan, I can honestly say that Sekino Sensei is the best, most dedicated and caring teacher that I've ever had.
