I spent more time studying for her class than all other classes combined.  But with time and with her guidance, I became fluent.

Sekino-Sensei is the best Japanese teacher I've ever had. She's totally devoted to her students, and makes classes fun and comprehensible. She expects a lot from her students, but there's no other way to learn Japanese!!

Sekino-sensei is one of the best professors since she makes an extremely difficult subject comprehensible. I spent more time studying for her class (five semesters!) than for all other classes combined.  Japanese classes at graduate schools in the U.S. and in Japan were much easier.

Prof. Sekino expects nothing less than complete devotion to Japanese. There is TONS of work in this class- quizzes, homework, reading, speeches, essays, and for her video class, tons of outside work watching all Japanese movies. She is a terrifying woman. You will learn, but you absolutely need to do your work. She is very willing to offer you help

The amount of work, the level of quality she expects from you, and her energy are all amazing (we joked that she was probably a cyborg). If you have issues daily hw or languages aren't your bag, prepare to WORK. I thought it was easy, but a lot didn't. Still, your classmates become your friends quickly -- like war buddies :D

I was a student of Sekino-sensei for three years. Her classes are pretty difficult and require A LOT of work, with homework every night and frequent quizzes. However, if you do all that's expected of you, you will learn a lot. You just have to make sure to do all your work and kiss up so you don't end up on her bad side (she can be quite harsh!).

She is very sweet, but very intense.  She does play favorites some-- but you become her favorite by talking to her out of class and proving your interest in the subject.  If you need help she's more than willing to provide it.  Just be willing to work your heiny off.

Too much work. I spend more time working for this class and in this class than any other.  She is tough, plays favorites, and doesn't always grade fairly. You learn alot of Japanese, but be prepared to spend hours every day working for your grade. She's actually nice when you know her out of class.
hard, bases grades on class favorites, unclear.  Burdens her students with too much work.  You learn alot of japanese, but there's TONS of bookwork, just tons.
Very nice person, but her English is only so-so.  It is a very hard class, many in the intro had already had some Japanese.
She's very enthusiastic and encouraging, but makes you *work* for your grade!

Aliza is literally the sweetest person and one of my favourite profs of all time. As someone with no background in Hebrew, I could not have passed this class without her. She's so supportive and understanding and I can't recommend her enough. Taken Spring 2019.
She is really caring for students and passionate about teaching.
GREAT professor.  One of the best in the department.  Shame that she's part-time.

Like all of the other Hebrew professors at Brandeis, she is a fantastic professor.  Always starts class with a cute way to get the students speaking in Hebrew and is great about going over things if they aren't understood.

The BEST prof. I had had in three years. Becasue of her I understand a language. Knew exactly what my interests were and how to draw me into the material individually, and did so with each other student in a different way. Knew how to speak my language. Very sad she was part time.
A real sweetheart-- an excellent teacher, caring and responsible.
Aliza is very kind.  She is very helpful with explaining grammar, but gives relatively hard quizzes (although I think they are the same for all 20-level classes).
one of the best hebrew teachers i've ever had! i'm taking another class with her right now.
No Comments
It's a very easy course if you know a little Hebrew already...and she's very sweet.

Professor Walker cares about her students tremendously. This class is difficult, but if you go to her office hours and demonstrate that you care she will grade more leniently. Do the drills in the workbook because there is not enough class time for you to master the material.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: I took a class with Ms Walker 36 years ago. She's an engaging lecturer, encourages discussion, is available outside of class and gives excellent feedback on assignments. All the things you expect of a prof. More importantly, she taught me how to think, to question, and to write effectively. Take her class - any class - you will not be disappointed.

Walker is my favorite professor.  I enjoy going to USEM and listening to her wacky and crude comments. Never boring. Very helpful- I was having trouble writing a paper and she helped get things on track. I would like to take another class of hers.
-Walker is witty and fun with a real knack for teaching history. You will enjoy virtually any class you take with her. Very respectful of student ideas.

Best prof I had at Brandeis.  Always friendly, always leading interesting class discussions, always open to different ideas.  Hard grader, but detailed comments on every paper.  You want Walker if you want to actually learn anything, but not for an easy A.
She was boring, and didn't like student's opinions.

A wonderful teacher. I am male, but my good friend, who is female, was with me in the same class, and also loved her. Encouraging, stimulating and, yes, a bit kooky, but in a wonderful way. One of the best profs I've had here.
I have to agree with the egotist. Intimidating too.

Egotist? Favors males?  You are obviously talking about a different prof.  I'm female, and the Cheryl Walker I knew was the best mentor I had in my four years at Brandeis... and I was lucky enough to have several very good mentors.
First class was boring but she let me research my own topics.  Always has food for the class!  Took time out of her sched. to help & tutor.  A little kooky, but always kindhearted & willing to help.
Very unfair.  Favored males.  Egotist.
On average 30% of the lecture time is spent discussing a topic unrelated to the course curriculum and it somehow absolutely works. Easily one of the best history classes I've taken.
He is a very informative and engaging professor.
A very silly prof. who loves to talk about Taylor Swift and play Justin Bieber music videos in class. Clearly cares about his work as well and is a good lecturer.

Prof. Singh is a really great and compelling lecturer and you will learn in the class, but it's not always clear what he wants. He communicates almost exclusively through the TAs, who regularly send out emails with either super vague instructions or just info that they have to correct later. Great professor, poor communication.

Professor Singh played a really pivotal role in my first year at Brandies, making an intro class something engaging to an extent larger than the content content itself. He gives great lectures where his personality and anecdotes shine through. He is super approachable outside of class too if you need any help.

Professor Singh was a dynamic lecturer who fostered a strong understanding of IGS. His lectures were generally engaging and humorous. Sharing the news every day was my favorite part. Tests are graded easily but are in essay form and take a while. Quizzes are hard and require studying but they do not affect your grade too much.

Singh is a very inspirational professor. His IGS160 talked about Asian crime movies, and he knew a lot about Asian societies, entertainment, and film directors. His lectures are very clear and organized, and combined films with the society behind films, which gave me a broader understanding beyond movies themselves.

Did an excellent job of explaining something almost completely outside of western civilization to a very westernized audience. Relied a little too heavily on his TA for grading and answering questions outside of class time IMO, but that's a minor complaint.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--So many papers

comment: Amazing professor! Easy to make a connection with him as well he is very nice and passionate about his course.

He is a lovely and sweet professor who really loves film. However, he assigns too many films a week in my opinion. I had to watch on 2x speed. Also we had to take notes while watching, which in my opinion ruins the film. He also did not provide enough warning for graphic content in the films or provide alternate options for students for the unit.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--So many papers

comment: Class discussions are very fun, although sometimes they go slightly off-topic. In my experience he's a fair grader: even if you haven't spent hours planning out your paper, you can expect to do well as long as you present strong evidence (both textual and logical) for your arguments. Attendance is supposedly mandatory but I skipped frequently.
Mark Hulliung is the human equivalent of dry toast.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: one of the smartest and best professors at Brandeis.  He makes the material interesting and he lectures even the class can be on the smaller side.  He does expect you to read a lot but you dont have to.  very fair grader
Brilliant. He can go off on witty tangents sometimes, but his classes are very interesting. Is extremely helpful and a fair grader.

One of my favorite professors. I'll take any class he offers because he's so interesting and funny, and he makes me want to learn the material. Not the easiest grader but he likes any solid argument and is fair.

Professor Hulliung is well-suited to students who are, above all, self-motivated. He is far less interested than most professors in your questions or difficulties. That said, his class is extremely straightforward, provided that you do the reading, attend, and pay attention. You would be hard pressed to find a funnier prof, too.

I was extremely interested in the Enlightenment before taking this class. However, Prof Hulliung's babbling and complete disregard for student participation made it easy to spend time on ratemyprofessors.com during class. He is a very intelligent man and knows his stuff, but that is where it ends.
I liked the class. I didn't do that great in it, but I liked the class!  He is interesting to listen too!  Enjoy
excellent professor.  great mind.  maks his subject very interesting.
This class is the worst!  He doesn't know anything about existentialism, and if he doesn't like you, he gives your papers bad grades without fully reading them!
A brilliant man! Likes the 70s, and doesn't need new retro clothes--he's still got the original outfit! Best of all, you learn a lot!
Cool! It was just cool. All those French thinkers just rock. And he does too. Finds meaning in The Plague although he insists that there isn't any.
Got out of class early almost every day. Fun, easy class to explore art and creativity with a nice prof who was very supportive of all artistic levels.
Good teacher, fun class if you want to do stuff with your hands
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: If you're reading this post, you are now required to take a class with Prof Fair. She is the absolute best!! I've been recommending her class to anyone who will listen. It's a super easy course, but I learned so much about art and the waste stream on campus, really changed my perspective.
Such a wonderful professor.

Ms. Fair is amazing. She respects every student in class, treats each student as artists even though we know we are not (yet). Her class is engaging so if you want straight A you have to show effort. Great professor!
I am far from being artistic, but even though I only came into the studio a few times outside of class, I still managed an A. She's nice and as long as you put in some effort, you'll be fine.

Took 3-D II with her. she is laid back...you have to work hard for a good grade, but it pays off b/c you end up with some great art pieces for your portfolio! :-) It is all good and plus she is kinda really hot so that does not hurt a bit! ;D
great class. challenging but fun. fair is very patient and helpful.
Tory is really laid back. This class is interesting but relaxing, and she was always available to help or listen.
Amazing and very encouraging. Demands you put in a lot of work... and rewards you if you do.
Single best class ever!! Tory is soo cool and totally hot. My gf and I both had crushes on her

Professor Lignos is easily the best in the CS department. Super clear grading criteria, interesting lectures, and not too much work for a CS class. He really wants you to succeed and is accessible outside of class, I highly recommend taking his courses.

Professor lignos is really good. Don't have much to say other than grades are super fair, lecture is interesting, and he's super accessible outside of class. He really wants you to succeed, and is easily the best prof I've had in the CS department.
Legend. I hope all the cosi prof in the department can be like Lignos

The lectures matched really well with the assignments. He did a good job of adding humor and storytelling to lectures. All the information we were given was very well organized and he was very down-to-earth and caring when it came to deadlines and assignments.

He is an absolute legend. You can tell he knows so much about the subject and genuinely wants you to succeed. He has your best interest at heart and will respond instantly to emails. Lectures can sometimes get a tiny bit boring but generally very interesting and enticing. I wish he taught more classes. Best prof at brandeis by far. :)
One of the best professors in the department. Genuinely cares about what a student will get from the course.
He is a great professor and cares about the students.
He taught his course well and gives a lot of free late days for homework but I do hope he can teach more contents in his class. The course materials are too easy.
Model teacher. Cares way more about students understand everything than just grades, super funny, accessible, and explains everything well
Amazing lectures. Always cares about students. Excellent assignment design. Clear grading criteria. Strong sense of humor. Outstanding professor!

Professor Lignos is far and away the best prof. at Brandeis, the class was interesting, the assignments didn't require enormous effort and were set up so you could check your progress, the quizzes covered lecture topics and were simple checks of our understanding. Lignos is hilarious, a memer, and most of all incredibly caring and wholesome.

Prof. Lignos is literally the best professor in Computer Science department. He is so considerate and care about students. He is the one who really think from the students point of view, and would never burden on students. His lecturers are clear and useful, and I think since he's a young professor, so he really know students very well!

Professor Lignos is probably my favorite professor in the department. He takes great care to be accommodating as possible to every student, and truly wants to see everyone succeed. He emphasizes avoiding the negative traits that make other professors so unlikable (e.g. the idea that many students failing a class doesn't reflect on the lecturer).

Oh my god, WOW. Like, seriously, this has got to be one of the absolute worst teachers I've ever had, and I'm not just talking about Brandeis—| mean, in my whole entire life. How is someone THIS bad at teaching?! It's honestly beyond me. Couldn't be me.
You will never know what meeting expectations, and exceeding expectations really mean.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: Pitt only gives out two grades - "meets expectations" and "exceeds expectations". He only tells you how to get the former, and never hot to get the latter. The result is unclear and often unexplained grading, and you never know exactly how much work he wants you to put in. Will explicitly tell you not to "game the system" by trying to get an A.

The grading criteria were very arbitrary and changed many times during the semester. His grading is binary, which can easily undermine students' efforts. He does not have a strong grasp of the basic knowledge of many OSs, but he can still be a teacher in this course.

Ridiculous amounts of homework, lecture topics without rhyme or reason, doesn't seem to care about students as individuals (don't expect much sympathy for circumstantial issues). Fulfilling all the requirements perfectly will only get you a B. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Avoid him. lack of clear grading criteria. never clarify why you get a certain grade for each assignment. Tells students if they meet all the requirements, they will get a B and they have to go surpass their limit to get an A. but, does not clarify how they can improve to get an A. does not involve any coding even though it's a CS course.

I loved Pito. He's infamous for giving a l lot of homework and forcing people to participate in class but he makes sure you learn your stuff. He's witty and coherent which made the lectures engaging.... He cares deeply about his students and if you meet with him one on one he should prove that.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: as a brandeis senior, I worked with him to design a new robotics course in school, and will be the TA of this course this fall. I think he's cool, both as a person, a co-worker, and a professor. He is the very few of CS prof in Brandeis that isn't too "nerd" .   P.S. "for independent study course, a person with impulse should basically get an A"
Avoid him at all cost... Too much work.

Great hands-on experience to start up a software based project, finding the right team members is very important, this course could be helpful for the university start up competition and the outside ones like MassChallenge.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Teacher isn't always clear. Assignments do not reflect the material taught in class. Gave us a pop quiz and one exam.

Pito's lectures didn't help you learn the material at all. At the end of the semester, he curved down the grade. There is inconsistency of his cutoff line. BTW, if you get 92.97%, you get a B+. Avoid him if possible

His lectures are not as helpful as programming assignments when I learned the course material. His lecture and programming assignments could be more synchronized so that I don't feel like "I don't know anything about this!" when doing PAs(But he definitely has his own justification for doing this, and I agree with him) Had to work hard on PA (50%)

Pito cares deeply about teaching and his students. Go to office hours and he will be more than happy to help clear up any confusion you might have. Very intelligent and inspiring teacher, might be the best in the Cosi department.

He is an incredible teacher in a sense that he is very knowledgeable about what he is teaching but a lot of the material is repeated over the class so he will try his hardest to make sure you understand... Many say that he is confusing--which is true--but if one takes this class as a pass/fail course, I definitely recommend it to others.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: One of the best teachers I've had, making a difficult subject simpler to understand. I recommend this class for the easiest class you will ever take if you can handle long lectures.

Very unclear and boring. Lectures are impossible to follow because the text, which in its own was difficult to understand, was just regurgitated and nothing was clarified. Didn't learn the names of probably about 80% of the students in a 30 person class.
By far one of the worst classes i've ever taken. expected intro to ethics to be a good class but any interest i had in the subject was destroyed by this guy. rude and unorganized to say the least

really boring and monotone. he's not good at wording material so it takes away from the fun of philosophy. would only take him if you absolutely love him or if you're a grad student. he doesn't really care about students as much as he does about getting through his agenda.

Very nice and fun-loving guy. Goes off topic quite often and quizzes (4 quizzes solely determine your grade for the semester!!) very in structure. This gets frustrating at times and his wording is VERY confusing. I ended up with a fairly good grade but im probably done with philosophy. Don't go in with super high hopes, but overall he was decent.
Really awesome guy, so smart and knowledgeable. Some thought he was boring, but he was truly hilarious.
Brilliant, funny, interesting. Tough material, maybe too tough. But well worth taking the class.
Took Philosophy of Identity with Prof. Greenberg. He put most of us to sleep, he talks in monotone, and he doesn't really want to hear what students think. He's a nice guy, just not a good professor.
-brilliant, engaging, classic professor.
Great professor! Very smart and very nice. He explains concepts very well. Prioritizes reasoning over content for papers. The class was so much more fun and interesting than I had expected.
Have to completely rely on the textbook because his lectures are pretty scattered and lousy.
He seems friendly enough, but the class is very challenging. They could totally make it better but they are more concerned with weeding people out than anything else.

He's kind of rude, and by kind of rude, this guy is overly pretentious and hardly as intelligible as his degrees and qualifications make him appear.  He doesn't seem to genuinely care about his students succeeding in his class but primarily cares about weeding people out prior to the "W" deadline.
I thought he was a very poor teacher. make sure you study the book because he takes a lot of his problems from the text.
He doesn't really explain things very well, but at least he tries.

Does not teach well. Every test question taken from the text book and tries to trick you.  You can ace the class and not go to lectures just by memorizing answers from the back of the book.   Bad teacher.

actually, he's not that bad.  i think that he can be harsh sometimes, but that's just his stern professor/this is a serious class, do work thing.  because his class can be really hard for a lot of people...  he's just trying to make us do work by being mean...
He's a nasty little man.  Don't talk to him after class.
Irv is the man. The test were easy and he reminds me of a professor from high school.
He says "uh" a lot... you should count... we counted 268 in one class. Tests are hard, but he curves fairly. Lectures are boring, but overall they are clear and organized.

awful. on tests he gets so caught up in ridiculously hard and irrelevent algebra and logic problems, enough to make you forget you're taking a chem class. wouldnt be so bad if he was a halfway decent lecturer, but he makes everything convoluted.
He's great, one of the best philosophy professors at Brandeis!

I have no idea how Beri doesn't have a 5.0 which is why I'm writing this. Great guy, great class, will definitely try to take another. Participation matters but you don't need to do the readings to keep up with the discussion since he summarizes well, but you should read a few eventually. Also has cute kids, convince him to bring them to class!!

He is extremely passionate about what he teaches. He makes everything really clear and systematic even tho Sartre's works r usually really difficult to understand. Humorous, easy-going as a person. Definitely the sort of person who r cute without even realizing how much they r...
He was just bad. If you have the chance don't take it with him.

Beri is the best professor I've taken a philosophy class with! Lectures are extremely fun, and he's super funny. Tries to take deep concepts and issues, and relate to them in a way that makes them exciting to learn. He's very accessible outside of the class, and gives really good feedback. He gives me hope for the Philosophy Department at Brandeis!

Professor Berislav is an incredible professor and a great person. His classes were engaging and he really generated interest in philosophy. He grades his midterms (and I assume his finals) kinda harshly but if you know what you're talking he will give you credit for the most part.
BEST TEACHER!
If you're at all interested in Philosophy, then I highly recommend this class. The professor makes clear and often hilarious analogies to make topics clear. Would highly recommend this teacher

He's a really great professor, always clear, very fair grade-wise and just generally engaging.  You can tell he enjoys his subject matter and it definitely rubs off.  If you're interested in metaphysics/epistemology he's your guy.
Fantastic professor. Young, smart, engaging and clear. Nice and personable in and out of class.
No Comments

He's the best professor I've ever had. I still reflect on concepts he talks about and I graduated years ago. Brilliant and caring man. I only regret I didn't seek out his office hours more. He's available despite being on another intellectual level. Take his classes if you want to understand philosophy.

As a philosophy major, I can tell you he is the most boring professor in the Brandeis Phil department. Talks too fast, assumes students know everything about Aristotle going into the class, and goes on tangents 90% of the class time. Also, his papers are based on readings the class never discussed, so you teach yourself - no need to do readings.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Palle gave the promptest responses to students' emails. Although he talked really fast in class, you can get his wits and jokes if you listen carefully. He is such a smart and nice person.

Palle is sometimes too smart to teach, thus students - including myself - can often get lost.. but his wit and composure nevertheless make his classes very fascinating. The subject matters he teaches are themselves already very interesting and challenging, but his passion make everything even more mind bogglingly intriguing. He's a fair grader.

Palle is a great professor and absolutely brlliant, but his lectures are a bit difficult to follow. He tends to get sidetracked speaks very quickly. He's an excellent teacher, and very good at answering questions. If you just need a distribution requirement, don't take his class. If you really want to learn something, I *highly* recommend it.
Best class in the Brandeis philosophy department.

Prepare to have your mind blown when you enter this class.  I once rated him before (mediocre), but back then, I never went to class nor paid attention.  As a graduating senior, now I pay attention to him and he is AMAZING.  He will change your life.  Metaphysics of Death is the BEST!  350 letters aren't enough to describe his amazing

Yourgrau is brilliant and hilarious.  However, he's very hard to lose track of because he talks so fast and does not articulate his words well at all.  Content is interesting, but if you're lazy like me, there is no need to read the books.  I got an A reading maybe 50 pages out of the 300+ we got assigned.

Palle Yourgrau is by far the best professor I have ever had, and I have one and a half undergraduate degrees, lol. Compassionate, down to earth and brilliant, he gives education a good name and made my Brandeis experience worth the money and time.

i took his philosophy of math and dangerous beauty- AMAZING professor. It is challenging in an inspirational way. Really worth taking his class. Not the easiest class, but not hard either. But his ideas and what he makes you think/question are so so deep
Is known as one of Brandeis' finest teachers.  Is not easy but will make you think hard and learn more than you imagined.

Fantastic professor. I've taken a class with him every semester since my first one for 3 years and he is amazing. Super informed, well read, and creative. Cares about you if you care him. Office hours are treasured moments and he comes up to chat as a friend. He really teaches you to read and write thoughtfully, which is rare.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Love him!

Professor Mandrell is hilarious. At first I got a little put off that a non-native speaker was teaching a high level class, but I got over it pretty quickly & enjoyed the level of discussion he brought to class! He also bakes us cookies. Win. He is a really hard grader but is super approachable so go talk to him about it!
His class was interesting but he was a very difficult grader.  He is extremely picky about grammar and less picky about content.

He is very unclear about his expectations for papers and assignments and grades hard.  Also, he is an extremely difficult grader in terms of Spanish, although he is not a native speaker himself. Class discussions were interesting, though.

Dr. Mandrell is a good instructor but he is quite disorganize.  His grading is far but his expectations are unclear. The readings itself are interesting but at times dry however he does manage to engage the class in the day's readings.  Overall, Mandrell is a good instructor who is approachable.  However, he is simply unorganized!
Ok professor.  Challenging but sometimes not as clear as he should be.  Expects ridiculously perfect Spanish even though he himself is not a native speaker.
No Comments
TAKE HIS USEM. Prof. Mandrell will push you and your writing; his class consistently suprised me by how much it all came together when you never imagined it could.
THE BEST BRANDEIS PROFESSOR!
Probably the best teacher I've ever had.  Demanding but helpful, thoughtful and clear.  His class makes you think.

I wish there were more assignments to give you a better fighting chance because if you mess up it's going to be very hard to come back. She's nice but I can't shake the feeling that she doesn't rlly care about her students. The exams are terribly organized, every single one has had multiple issues of being graded wrong. AVOID IF POSSIBLE.

This class was just a true struggle. I was excited to take the course and learn more about Java but Prof Papaemmanouil's teaching style took away my interests in programming. Things were unclear throughout the semester and felt set up to fail.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: The class material is actually not too too terrible. If you attempt to learn the stuff on your own, you can learn it on the internet! However, the professor is not helpful, the TAs seem to be obsessed with docking points, and the lectures only teach theory- they then give out massive programming assignments even though they do not teach any coding
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: I have heard a lot of bad things about this course and it has been all confirmed. The slides are fine but the lectures are very bad and the programming assignments are silly. Your grade will be determined based off of what TA grades your Programming assignments (2 assignments are about 40% of your grade even though they teach 0 coding).

There's nothing good about this prof and the TAs, from their way of teaching to grading of assignments. The grading takes years and they seemed to want to take as many points off as possible. Had to spend days upon days on assignments only to get awful grades.

Syllabus was incorrect: we ended up not doing one of the PAs that is worth 15% of your grade and then she reached out to everyone during finals week saying that they may not pass. My understanding is this was the first time anyone was reached out to. Had nothing but unpleasant experiences when interacting with the professor. Very rude.
Her lectures were very clear and she was pretty nice. The coding projects varied a lot in difficulty, but if you put in the work you should do well.
easy
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: She is okay, but okay is all she is. She goes through every slide of her PowerPoint and reiterates everything soullessly. Assignments take a lot of effort and time.

Tests inconsistent with given material. Hard to listen to, hard to work with. Graders in the class are inconsistent and will either give you full credit or dock you as many points as they feel like they can get away with. Terrible class.

Tests inconsistent with classes. Unlimited homework point deduction. Sometimes provide misleading information about homework and test. Situation can be better if you are upperclass men, but if you are freshman, it's not wise to take this class.

She is a good person and clearly cares about students, but she is not a great professor. The lectures are often rushed and lab manuals are sometimes published late/after the lab. Also, the midterms and finals are very difficult. The class being graded on a curve helps with this.
Go to office hours!

TAs definitely rly run the class. dunno why some ppl were so hard on her. talk to her one-on-one if need be, it helps. lab reports took lots of time but then  switched to short form worksheets. knowing basics of partial derivatives gives a v helpful advantage. honestly a stats class. used excel. first lab oddly hard.

Loved Professor Sciolla. She is very kind. The TA's run most of the class and determine your grade so if you have a bad TA you may be out of luck. The material is simple. Lab reports take forever to write so make sure to have a good work flow setup early.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Professor Sciolla created an amazingly useful class by using Physics to teach data analysis in Python. Some TAs seems to grade way harder than others... Start lab reports ASAP, go to office hours, and complete all on time. For tests know your data analysis and theoretical knowledge very well. She curves nicely!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: I cannot stress enough how awful of a teacher she is. Rude, unhelpful, and and a poor teacher. If you can avoid taking this class do it!

She's nice, but can be confusing when explaining. This is more of a statistical analysis class than a traditional physics lab might be. They say no prior coding experience necessary, but you can save time for yourself during the semester by brushing up on Python for stats analysis before taking this class. Some TAs grade harsher than others.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: This is the worst class I have ever taken. Her slides make no sense and she is surprised when people dont understand. The test have NOTHING to do with what is taught in class. She is unorganized and generally unkind when you dont understand. I will never take a class with her again
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Sciolla is a great professor! Just beware this is not your traditional physics lab class. It will teach you how to analyze your data using Python, an incredibly useful tool for any scientist! But the learning curve if you have never coded before is steep! Be prepared to spend the time of a full credit course! Some TAs grade harsher than others.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: All I can say is avoid this class if possible. The tests have nothing to do with what is taught in class, she gives no review or prep for the test and is shocked when people are unhappy. Everything has to do with coding and they claim that no prior coding experience is needed but then they don't teach coding. Don't take this class and save yourself
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Do not have words to describe how awful this class is. Her powerpoint slides make no sense, there is no logical flow to the course. She seems surprised every time the next slide appeared, she does not know what she is teaching. tests have nothing to do with physics. It is super coding heavy and the coding is taught poorly. I should have dropped it
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: The class is SUPER coding heavy and very poorly taught so if you aren't ready to spend an exhausting number of hours a week coding your assignments it is not worth the time or trouble. Her tests also have nothing to do with physics.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: Game theory homework is time consuming, especially the book problems are terrible, but the problems Graddy creates herself are fine and much more understandable. She is a great professor and classes would be very enjoyable if they weren't 8am on Tuesdays and FRIDAYS!!! Tests are fair, you can even choose which questions to answer. Go Graddy!

She is very helpful outside of class and always receptive to student concerns, even though some of her lectures seem rushed. Her tests are easy if you understand the concepts and put in effort on the homework.
nice
I had Graddy for Industrial Organization. She's sweet and while I sometimes did zone out in lectures, they were interesting when I did pay attention. Be prepared to do the work, but it's worth it.

Honestly, a sweet lady who is just too smart to teach an intro level.  She was not clear and did examples wrong in front of the class. Seemed nervous to be in front of us. Kind of like an awkward teenager.  Bored to tears in class, powerpoints were helpful however.
Relied too heavily on aplia and too little on in class lectures
I really enjoyed this class. The lectures were very clear. She has a lot of enthusiasm and made the subject interesting.

She is a very nice person, and a good teacher. The problem sets really help you understand the material, and if you ever have an issue with a problem you can go to her office hours and she will explain it more clearly. She is very helpful, and the book is very straight forward and useful.

worst lecturer ever! I fall asleep almost everytime I go to this class. She is a nice person, but not a great teacher. Her tests are easy, but you have to study the book +online materials yourself to do well in this class

I'm sorry, but while this woman is a nice person. She just isn't able to make me understand Econ. Not to mention she relies way to heavily on online problem sets. I feel more like I am teaching myself. She also seems to care more about the Business School classes than undergrad

Here's the thing: whenever you have a science class with 250 students, you're going to get about half of those who aren't happy with their grade. This doesn't mean that sciences classes can't be taught well, and Professor Nicastro's was by no means perfect. You can tell that she's really nice, knowledgeable, and cares about her subject.

Her tests were absolutely ridiculous and even if you knew the material, questions were worded in a way that must be translated to be answered properly.  Her graduate TAs even said they were worried for us when they saw our tests because some of them wouldn't be able to do well on them and they work in a lab with her!
probably the worst professor ive ever had. extremely unclear and impatient. her tests from year to year get progressively worse and need translation from german. she has no patience for students.
professor should stick to research, not teaching. impossible to determine what small details will be asked on the test, lecture nearly ruined my interest in biology. avoid if possible.

Her accent makes understanding her lectures difficult on a good day. She essentially only tests on small details that she's mentioned once over the course of the semester. She also doesn't give a cumulative final, which makes actually learning the material an exercise in futility, and discourages any understanding beyond straight up memorization.
shes better than people give her credit for. memorize the slides, the book isnt really even necessary. and she curves it to a B+, how can you complain about that

The material is not too hard, as long as you commit time to reading the text book to supplement the lectures. Exams are alright - they test you on your ability to memorize details and facts rather than understanding entire concepts.  Make sure you know your vocab.

A lot of power point slides and she moves through them quickly which doesn't help you to absorb material. I wish details like this were left to the textbook and that professors would just help you to grasp general concept. Anyway, mandatory attendance for i-clicker Qs. Exams are not too hard but a poor representation of class concepts.

Horribly boring; unclear; assumes we've already taken the class; idiotic i-clicker questions (if it wasn't for that, wouldn't go to class); tests easy q's but difficult to answer, since each class was slept through

I didn't really like the way Prof. Nicastro taught her classes. For one thing, she tended to read in a monotone off her slides and her style didn't help us connect the concepts taught. She also instituted some draconian measures to keep cheating down. Her tests didn't necessarily test material well, and some of it didn't appear in class materials.

Silvia Monteleone has been the best teacher I have ever had. I took her for all three semesters of Italian, and truly wish I could fit more of her classes into my schedule. She cares so much about her students, both in and out of the classroom. She is always available to help students, and truly only cares about them trying their best. I love her!

Prof. Monteleone is a fantastic professor who truly cares about all of her students. Her lessons are always interesting and ensure that you learn not only the language but also about Italian history and culture. She makes class fun and engaging, even with serious topics. She is very encouraging and really inspired me to continue my Italian studies.

If you put in the effort and review outside of class you'll be much better off. She sometimes randomly calls on students and that can be a little scary, but she won't get mad she's so sweet. Again just review vocab and grammar and you'll be fine. If you're unsure which language to study, I'd pick Italian because the profs are great.

She is the sweetest! Very easy grader and told us she cares most about students learning not what grade they earn. Took her for Italian 10 and will have her for Italian 30 next semester. Just be respectful and follow instructions. As long as you put in effort you'll be fine.
She is so sweet and caring. I've taken her for three semesters, and I plan on keeping in touch afterwards.
She cares so much about her students and really cares more about whether or not you learn something than whether you have perfect language skills. An easy grader, but all the assignments count

I loved her class so much. She was so caring about all the students, and if she noticed that a student was doing poorly she would speak with them to make sure that everything was okay (mental health, outside pressures, etc). She really cared about the subject and she was so quirky and fun that it made the class enjoyable!

(Italian 10-30) She is incredibly sweet and is always there for any form of help; do not be afraid to ask for anything because she loves her students. Homework should be done because she wants us to succeed but doesn't mind if its late; just get it done. The work load is definitely manageable and her classes are always interesting.

Super sweet and very chill about things like late work. Her class was interesting and fun to be in. If you don't know something she is happy to help you and provide you with extra support. Papers in this class were sometimes a bit tricky to read since a lot of them included dialectal language, but she provides translations and additional help.

She is so sweet and really cares about her students! After level one she speaks only in Italian, which is a blessing and a curse. Sometimes I do not know what she is saying, but it is okay to admit that. It is so important to be is class always and to try to speak in the language as much as possible! Lots of tests to regularly check fluency! Great!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Prof. Slodden was incredible. She's very intelligent, caring, and accessible. Her ppts are super thorough and she gives a lot of grade protection so it's not hard to get an A. The readings are really interesting and Prof. Slodden shows a lot of care and compassion esp. when discussing hard topics. Regular journals (not hard), midterm, paper & final

Professor Slodden is AMAZING! This was my first sociology class ever and I loved it. Her lectures are very interesting and she is totally fine with going a little bit off-topic to answer questions. She was super helpful during her office hours and very understanding.The midterm was not bad if you studied the course content well.

Professor Slodden is a great teacher. Her lesson are well-structured, her slide includes every concept and lecture note. She also tries to answer every question in the class and hold good discussions. The in-class exam is tricky, but you just need to study concepts carefully. There are some shorts journal, completion grading, and take-home essays.

Caitlin changed the way that I viewed the field of sociology as well as the issues that face our world. I now know how I want to use the degree that I get at Brandeis to help work toward solutions to the systemic issues that plague our society. I look forward to taking more Soc classes in the rest of my college career.

Professor Slodden is one of the greatest professors I've had. She is insanely caring and accommodating. Her lectures are amazing. You can tell she is so passionate and well-versed in what she teaches. 100% would take again. Take notes, do the readings, and you'll do great.

Prof. Slodden is one of the best professors I've had. She engaged the whole class and was professional, organized, and empathetic, especially when we were sent home due to the pandemic. Soc 1a includes a good amount of readings, a short documentary reaction paper, a long-term group research project, a midterm, and a final. Great class.

With COVID I expected such a large class to get really disorganized, but that was not at all what I experienced. Caitlin tried her very best to make us know we are all in this together and that we would get through it. Which was so true, and I still learned so much in the class and gained alot from it.
Nothing bad to say. She is really great at making us appreciate other thought processes and ways to view the world. I really appreciated this class alot.

I came into Brandeis undecided for my major, and took this class the spring of my first year. Caitlin opened my eyes to the injustices of the world and how we can make an impact. She had us analyze the different aspects of our world from many perspectives. For an introductory class we touched on a wide variety of topics which was amazing.

As a Biology major, this class gave me a greater approciation of the problems facing our world that will help me in my career, even though I will not be majoring in Soc or pursuing it. She makes the material accessible to all and connects all aspects anf theories to the rea world. Amazing class if you are entering this field or not.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Mayorga is really passionate about the work she does and in making sure that students does well. Everything is clearly laid out in the syllabus, there's many extra credit opportunities for you so that you succeed in that class. 10/10 recommend!
I loved Professor Mayorga, she is very passionate about her work and very caring for her students.  Sweetest person you will ever meet
She is very passionate about her lessons so she is disappointed when students don't reciprocate it.
This is the worst professor I have ever known. Never take this class.

Her course is very interesting, with lots of fun. She gave some basic ideas of sociology, and her assignments are not hard. She also encouraged students to participate, although it is a big lecture wiz around 90 people, you still have chance to speak if you want!

Professor Mayorga was a good professor to have for my first semester at college. Her lectures are interesting and the workload is very manageable. There are things you can skip or do and earn extra credit for, and the writing assignments are pretty straightforward. It's an intro class, though, so you won't go super in depth.
I love the professor, and I love the class. Take it only with prof. Sarah

Professor Mayorga is literally one of the best teachers at Brandeis. She is so kind and truly loves her students. Be prepared to be challenged but not necessarily crazy stressed. She truly made SOC 1A incredible!

Professor Mayorga is not just a great professor, but also an amazing human. Super clear that she cares a lot about her students and classes and puts a lot of effort into her classes. Really interesting topics and a great glimpse into Sociology.
One of the best professors I've ever had. So sweet and easy to work with. Her passion for the material and the students is obvious

This is a demanding class, but if you do the work it expects, you will definitely succeed. He is a very intelligent person. KSR structures his lectures so that they are always very rushed. O2 is a high energy molecule.

O2 is a high energy molecule. Klaus is a great professor who cares about student's learning and chemistry, but his lecture is a bit boring, and the structure of this class is a bit rush. You will learn a lot if you love chemistry. Check out his review document before exams and you'll be fine. O2 is a high energy molecule.

Friendly, helpful, and accommodating in finding times to meet outside of office hours. Lecture's are a little bit boring and hard to follow along in. You will probably need to work with others in the class in order to do well on the homework assignments. O2 is high energy.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: KSR was an amazing professor that displayed genuine passion for Chemistry. The class content itself is moderately difficult. However, it is super easy to get good grades on quizzes, exams, and final exam if you do the homework, read the chapter and review guidances, and the practice exams. Lectures are dull at times but loved them anyway.

schmidt-rohr made me feel comfortable in chem and was not condescending when i asked for help. i walked away with a good understanding of difficult concepts and highly recommend going to office hours and going over homework and exams with him. he is a little intimidating at first but warms up the more you see him. highly recommend.

KSR is very intelligent and hilarious. I am personally horrible at chemistry so I didn't do that well, but he cares deeply about his students, and will always make time to discuss your progress in the class. His class was difficult because the grade was completely reliant on tests and quizzes, but manageable with hard work.

KSR is knowledgeable and well-meaning, but his feedback can be blunt. He spends 99.9% of lecture time talking while writing on the chalkboard. You are graded on four exams (90%) and a bunch of quizzes (10%). He is very accessible in office hours and exam reviews, and is open to questions. If you don't have background chem, KSR's class might be hard
Professor Schmidt-Rohr doesn't make your life easy, but I love his class and I find his lectures engaging and decently understandable.

CHEM 15B is a rigorous class. Lectures are initially difficult to understand, but doing the optional homework and regularly going to office hours helps a lot. Professor SR is very intelligent, so he sometimes skims over certain details. However, he's very good at explaining once you ask a question. He is a fair grader, but wording matters.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Great professor and course! He's right when he says anyone can do well if they put in enough work: the quizzes are just questions from the homeworks, and the exams are just quiz questions, so if you do the homeworks you'll receive a satisfactory grade. His teaching style might be different than what you're used to, but it's easy to adapt to it.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment:
KSR is a great chemist, very clearly passionate. 
KSR struggles with communicating the chemistry to undergraduates a bit, but after a few weeks it becomes more clear what is needed to do well in his class.

Professor Klaus Schmidt-Rohr is an amazing chemist that knows in-depth the topics he is teaching. Because of his knowledge, he focused his lectures and tests on topics he considers important to know. A good grade is not hard in this class: 1) Complete ALL the homework problems 2) Do the practice exams 3) Complete your cheat sheet carefully

Luis is a very caring, passionate professor who clearly has a lot of experience with the topic. She is a fair grader and her feedback is clear and easy to understand. Her lectures and readings are a little boring; however, the films she showed in class were fun to watch.
Super chill and caring. Don't be afraid to ask for an extension, she's super flexible and understanding with students. Would take again!

She's very nice but not an exciting or inspirational lecturer, I found myself dozing off and I stopped doing the readings because they were often irrelevant to the class. She did not provide much feedback in her grading but she was easy to talk to.
Wonderful lecturer and caring professor, take a class with her if you can. Flexible with students and cares about their wellbeing.

One of the best professors I have had at Brandeis. So understanding and has such great lectures. The assignments for this class were a 5 page essay, forum posts, and a research paper at the end. There are a lot of readings but their interesting and are explained in class so don't worry too much if you don't do all. You won't regret taking her!!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: very approachable  makes her class as accessible as possible. we read a lot of dense theory, but there's no gatekeeping: she unpacks it well and always has insightful comments, and she also loves student participation and validates what you contribute. the course will open your eyes! a few short papers with clear rubrics, so it's easy to do well
This woman walks on water.

The class was mostly fueled by student participation and discussion, but when Professor Luis lectured, she had extremely interesting, knowledgeable, and thought provoking things to say. She definitely engages you in the topic and makes you interested. A lot of reading, but it's not hard to get an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Inspirational--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: A lot of reading. Not the best grader. Participation is definitely a plus. You need to have your citations straight.

LOTS of readings, but there are three essays and a few in-class responses (which she gave you more prompts at the end of the semester in case you did poorly on one of them). As long as you write a good essay with proper citation and using the readings, you will get an a-/a. She doesn't sound excited but has really, really interesting stuff to say

Professor Nyangoni is the most knowledgeable and most qualified professor I've ever had. His lectures are long, but taking good notes is a great way to stay focused and a great way to get out of doing all the readings assigned, as he covers the most important topics in class.

Go to his office hours, he is a huge help and extremely knowledgeable. You will learn just by going. He is easy to talk to and funny. I cannot talk enough about how smart and accomplished he is, yet he also thinks he has something to learn from his students.
Extrememly unhelpful when I went to ask him for feedback and chooses favorites early on

Professor Nyangoni is really interesting, but unless you are majoring in AAAS and can handle classes that have no structure I advise against taking his classes. I personally love him and think he is great but he is definitely not for everyone.

Prof Nyangoni is the best-bottom line.  Go to class and take great notes.  His exams are all papers so incorporate your notes, text reading, and grab some other books from the library to add a bit and you will undoubtedly get an A.  Most importantly-talk to him outside of class.  You're cheating yourself if you do not.

Professor Nyangoni is an excellent professor.  Go to take, take great notes and stay a minute or two after to share your thoughts with him.  He is open and willing and ready to share his knowledge with anyone who expresses interest.  His class is intense but rewarding. One piece of advice:  Take good notes, write down everything he says.

Wellington Nyangoni is one of the most interesting men I have ever taken a class with. he knows Nelson Mandela, he has amazing stories and he is such a nice, friendly guy. it is a pleasure to take a class with him. Although his class can be boring and he is a bit disorganized, attendance is not mandatory and he is so helpful and a wonderful profeso

Nyangoni is a wonderful main with the most amazing stories.  However, his lectures are disorganized and usually tough to follow ... and he lectures the entire class.  You won't necessarily learn concrete material, but he'll definitely get you to look at things differently.
Talks down to students. Forgets his own assignments. Should not be teacher but rather continue working in World Bank.
-Nyangoni is willing to give all the time in the world to students. He is, however, somewhat disorganized in his lectures and often comes off sketchy.

So, the course material is very helpful and clear. This class is lecture based, so having great course material really helps you get through the class.  Not only that, the professor is a great lecturer. I really like her lecturing style. You can ask her anything during class or after class and she'd be willing answer you.  10 out of 10.

Professor Lee is not the best lecturer, in fact I often times got very confused in class. However, she is always available outside of class during office hours or via email. You can tell she cares a ton about her students and wants you to learn the material for future research and other applications rather than to simply pass her class. Super nice.

Professor Lee wasn't that great of a lecturer, but her caring attitude and dedication to her students more than made up for it. I went to her office hours and review sessions and she was so incredibly helpful. Statistics is hard, but with her help I got an A. It's hard to do badly in this class because she cares so much about her students wellbeing

I really like how Professor Lee tells stories from her own life. She also shows how statistics is connected to psychology and research in general. I learned so much more than just statistics in her life. Would absolutely recommend! Be sure to go to her office hours - she has so much to offer

Professor Lee is so sweet and really cares about her students. She gives lots of opportunities for students to improve, and makes herself very available to students outside of class. You can really tell that she wants her students to do well.

Professor Lee is one of the most dedicated and caring professors I have ever had. Statistics can be a dry subject, but a lot of work is put into trying to make lectures engaging. She is approachable and willing to do whatever it takes to help her students learn the material and succeed. I learned a lot from her class and highly recommend her!
She is great! Extremely helpful, caring, and understanding!

Excellent course quality. She gives clear guidelines in the syllabus. Her slides and lectures are very comprehensive, so I didn't need the textbook so much.  All materials in exams can be found in the slides and practice quizzes. Take advantage of her accessibility outside of class. Don't hesitate to go to office hours and get help if you need.
Her lectures are boring and she is very hard to understand. She doesn't explain concepts very well. If you haven't taken statistics before it can be very hard to get into the swing of things.
If you work hard enough it's not hard to get an A.
best teacher in the department , engaging lectures and very funny , you could also TA for her.. it will definitely be worth the experience. very kind and sweet person overall and easy to talk to
Very reasonable and understanding. Not a super difficult class.
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Luis was great! Very easy class to get an A in, and a good lecturer. She's also really understanding and is willing to accommodate your needs as long as you communicate. 10/10 would take a class with her again!

Professor Lupis was really nice and a very accommodating + "putting student mental health first" professor. Class content was straightforward and lectures had their fun moments, assignments were graded easily. Easy A.

Funny teacher who makes learning enjoyable. she brings her quirky passion to adolescence psyc. The class is straight forward. YOU must attend discussion and do the two assignments and then will get an A. The midterm is take home and mc and short answer not difficult at all. the independent project is fun to do and doesnt tae much time
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: She is really caring, witty, and accessible. Her class is an easy A. She takes pride in knowing that her students succeed in her class. She gives a lot of opportunities to succeed and her class is a great way to complete the Group 2 requirement and oral communication requirement for the Psych major. She reads slowly. Her grading is very generous.

Sarah is very caring and accommodating. We needed a textbook for her class, but I never used it and still got an A. Her class is really easy, but you still learn a lot from her lectures. I hope she teaches more classes in the future because she has become one of my favorite professors in the Psychology department.

Easiest class I've ever taken. A great class to take in a semester when you are taking a lot of difficult classes. She's a really nice person who is really interested in adolescent psychology. I didn't learn as much as I expected to because the class is just so easy... but I'm definitely not going to complain about an easy A :) (she likes cats!)
One of the most amazing people I've ever met! Highly recommend

There's a textbook but I never used it. It was a very light workload and the assignments were very flexible (you get to choose your own topic). There were a lot of small group discussions and activities, but as long as you participated a few times you're good.
I think she is genuinely a nice person, and she is willing to help the student succeed. In saying that, I dont believe she is the greatest professor, but she knows her material!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: This professor is an accomplished practicing professional sharing his expertise with the next generation. He makes himself available with zoom office time and is genuinely interested in making sure his students understand the course concepts. This was hard work, but YES I would do it again in a heartbeat. Take this course with Professor Malik!
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Amazing! Take the class!

He is the best. You can send him things to look over and will give honest feedback to help your grade. He does discussions and projects only which is perfect for completing the class while working full time. The books were not useful, his notes were all you really needed.

By far, Prof Nadeem has been the best. His explanations are thorough, he is available in virtual office (which no other prof were ever available) to guide the students on assignments, the course needs extensive reading, he provides constructive feedback and his experience based knowledgeable provides valuable information.

Nadeem is a terrific instructor. Provides thoughtful and thorough feedback on all assignments, even discussion feedback. It's clear that he's put a lot of effort into preparing all materials for the course which inspires the student to do the same. Course work is not easy but if you put the effort in all will be well.

Nadeem gives really good and specific feedback on homework and larger assignments. He is a very clear communicator and willing to help students understand the material. I sent him my final project to look at before I submitted, and he made some great suggestions which helped me get an A.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Nadeem made the class a wonderful and fun learning environment.  It wasn't easy, but it was doable.   He is an effective communicator and articulates very well.  He understood my ideas and provided great feedback that will help me in my life and career.  He never made me felt like my ideas were out of this world and bad.  He is one of the best.

If you have plans to take Foundations of Project Management, take Nadeem. He is a great instructor to begin the MSPPM program with. He has clear grading criteria, he is genuinely passionate about what he does as well as his students and he is available (which can be really helpful in an online format). Take him - avoid Hassey!).
Professor Malik was very good and I learned a lot.  I would take a class from him again!
Difficult course for anyone that is new to Project Management and MS Project, but instructor provides the information needed to succeed. It all comes down to how dedication.

She doesn't prepare for class, her "lectures" are videos that she prerecords from a script. She does not explain concepts well and is incredibly picky. If you ask for clarifications on anything she gets herself confused and you walk away worse than you started. Has a nice person attitude but clearly is not invested in students learning.

Professor Lam is a great professor. She is knowledgeable in her field and is willing to help when you need to understand something. She lets you have a cheat sheet and depending on how well you do your cheat sheet, you will get a good grade. She grades harsh and especially strict on how you word things on the test so make sure you focus in class.
If you listen during lectures, homework assignments are easy enough. Lam is super knowledgeable and loves interacting with students.

Dr. Lam is VERY energetic. Classes are usually interesting as lectures are given for HW. 
Material is relevant and interesting. 
Exams are stressful and difficult and grading is very nitpicky on exams and HW.

Her class is very organized, which I appreciate. She is very caring, but she also has her favorites. The tests are pretty long for the time given, and I've noticed most students rush to finish her tests on exam days. She didn't have a final exam, just a group presentation, which was nice. Content itself is not too hard, but you still need to study.

Lectures are organized and very straightforward. The test and homework material is fair and is related to what is taught in class. The professor is very passive aggressive and has her favorites. The feedback you get is valid but is feedback presented in a rude and nonconstructive format.

Shes friendly but grades homework very harshly (-2 pts for rounding errors, etc) and the tests are far too long given the amount of time (0.5 cm thick packet to complete in 80 mins). Questions are always linked to previous answers so if you miss one the rest of them are incorrect. Lectures are prerecorded scripted videos of her reading from slides
rating_tags: Tough grader--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: She's very knowledgeable but every lecture is just prerecorded videos of her reading definitions from a script/slides, word for word. Homework is time-intensive and graded harshly but would be easier if class time was used for normal lectures instead of constant group work. Activities with peers don't teach as well as a professor with a PhD.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Group projects

comment: Yeah her homework is pretty hard and she barely goes into the material that is required to do it. Makes you do a lot of awkward group work during class but doesn't enforce any way of making random people interact.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Great class! We had some trouble with students talking back, but she can control a class and get you to understand the material. Makes you work hard, but really is helpful. Lets you use a cheat sheet, and there is a project to replace you r lowest test grade.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: I took this lab a few years ago (2014), but Qb lab was probably the most useful course that I have ever taken, while at Brandeis. Strongly recommend her course to all graduate students.

Her tests reflect nothing to very little taught in class and portioned so that one question is worth 10-20 points with no partial credit (depending on her mood).  Her lectures are very convoluted to the point where she stares at the blackboard confusing herself.  Let's be real here she's a nice lady and everything but its not worth the struggle.
I enjoyed working with her and the projects were interesting.

Professor S is clearly someone who loves Physics and that passion translates well both in lecture and out. As a novice teaching a large class, there were some growing pains, but what is encouraging is that she clearly learned from her mistakes and is going to become a great teacher. She was always available; I took advantage of that constantly.

Dr. Samadani is a passionate lecturer who cares about students understanding physics concepts rather than reciting back equations. She's very available in OH to work problems. There are some wrinkles in the class structure that were ironed out as it was her first semester teaching the class, but overall did not detract from the learning experience.

She was always available for office hours and repeatedly tired to tailor the course to fit the student's needs such as: take home exam, open note tests, dropping one exam. She put the students first and tried to help everyone get a good grade in the course. Many students found the material hard, but she tired to help everyone succeed.
Great Professor! Great lab course!
She is clearly passionate about the subject material and cares about her students. She is always available to help and answers questions

I have never taken physics in my life and as an introductory course it was probably one of the worst classes I've had. She was unorganized and most of her lectures include gaps where she would silently stare at the board to try and figure out the problem. The notes she posts makes sense but when she writes them on the board it is a complete mess.
Great Professor!

As my introductory teacher in Chinese, I was quite impressed by his didactic abilities. He was amusing and a genuinely nice person and you really get the sense that he cares a lot about the students. He is also fair in general and if he does call you out its very likely you were quite out of line. For a language course, it's moderately challenging.
He is super kind and has a lot of knowledge on religion! He teaches very effectively and always encourages students!

Come to class, do homework and review knowledge before classes/ exams and you will do good. There are many quizzes in class, don't miss them. He also has an efficient way of teaching Chinese to students. There are review sessions to help you remember what you have learned in class. Professor Feng and the TAs are very helpful.
rating_tags: Participation matters--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Amazing lectures

comment: Feng is a well natured man with a heart of gold. He cares about his students and the material (in my case it was buddhism). Hes a bit repetitive and some lectures can be boring but all in all it was a good class and I found his lectures to be if not interesting at least relaxing. Note that he does have a strong accent but is by no means incoherent.

Professor Feng is one of the leading professors in East Asian Studies national wide. He has profound knowledge in East Asian religion, people, culture, history, politics, Chinese pedagogy and even film. He is a very patient teacher, treating every student utmost help and kind. A must take! Even you are not a East Asian Studies major!
This is the best teacher I've had so far. Laid back, seems to love his work, encourages the students, and has a positive attitude. Also has lots of stories about living in China.
Hes a great teacher, wants you to do your best.
Really entertaining and interesting professor. Going to his office hours are also useful when you don't understand something. His tests aren't hard, unless you don't come to class or don't care.
Professor Feng is an excellent professor who truly cares about his students' learning.
No Comments

The class is unecessarily theoretical and boring. My biggest issue is homework timing he assigns it with a week to complete but teaches key content throughout the week, often covering essential material the day it's due. Why not base assignments on the prior week's content? Plus the homework instructions are poorly written and confusing.
One of the best professors I've had at Brandeis. Fai and Keith are probably my two favorite math professors. He always gives plenty of examples and keeps the big picture in mind.

The best Math lectures I've had at Brandeis. He does a great job of keeping the big picture in mind, and always ties the theory we learn to concrete applied examples. The course is definitely not easy, but he makes the coding part very manageable for non computer science majors (like me). I really enjoyed this class.

I had Thomas Fai for a differential equations class. He adapted so well for virtual classes during the pandemic. Many other professors did not take a good approach to virtual lectures and underestimated how much trouble students would have with using their pre-quarantine approach during quarantine times. Thomas Fai made it fair for everyone.

**Was taken remotely The material was very straight forward and interesting. Hw was really not very hard if you skim the textbook and attend lectures. Very reasonable person and very sweet. A little disorganized notes-wise during lectures but the textbook was super helpful if anything got confusing.

This class does require coding. If you don't have any background it can be hard at first. I think Fai is very nice but the TAs were much more helpful for hw coding and problem help. There are no tests, and one required mathematical paper to read and a final project. Very reasonable amount of hw per week. Lectures kind of boring but interesting.

Prof. Dr. Thomas Fai was amazing and so helpful. His lectures were riveting like I was in a Christopher Nolan Movie. I now want to be a mathematician, though when I started this course I wanted to be an economist. He really showed that mathematics can be so beautiful. Would recommend you take this course.
When you encounter any coding problems in any assignments, lol, u r on you own.

First, he tells you this class doesn't need any coding background. Then all HW, lab, and Projects are fxking coding heavy. Maybe he's too smart for our regular students and thinks we can become python master in days. Not recommended unless you have taken high-level python course. You gonna read tons of Ph.D mathematical and computer science paper

This guy is the worst creep. He always talks in a monotone voice and starts laughing when he starts stumbling over his words. He'll often ask "Can I look over your shoulder", I guess he just wants to watch you work. The class is basically a bad introductory coding class since he doesn't teach you all the coding parts you need to know to finish hws.
His exams are very difficult but he is really nice.

Professor Krishna was tough but fair. Lectures were a good supplement to textbook, and there was always an interesting tangent / fun little pattern or two. Take-home exam questions went far deeper than text; however, grading was curved.

Very hard class. To get a good grade, expect to work triple a normal math class. A lot of time of feeling hopeless and depressed when completing hw+take home tests. The lecture material was incredibly dense and way too much for a undergrad intro to proofs class. Would not recommend unless you have a lot of time on your hands and hate life. Sorry :(

Rahul is constantly saying things are "obvious" which then makes it impossible for students to ask questions without feeling stupid. We only made it through 2/3 of our scheduled material, but he still put things relating to that last 1/3 on the final exam.

His class is very hard. The contents are not supposed to be covered in this proof class. However, he is willing to help in and outside the classroom. Just try you best and be serious to this class, you will learn a lot and get good grades.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: A lot of class time is wasted on group discussion of the problem sets. Problem sets are extremely hard! Prepare to spend a whole day or two. Extremely stressful while taking the class! Tests are taken home but there is no outside source to consult. aka no Chegg. Topics he teaches are so advanced. No zuo no die do not try.

I had a very difficult time understanding him. If you don't read the textbook, you won't pass the class. We learned a lot of things that were far beyond our level, such as quotient spaces and the first isomorphism theorem.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Took linear algebra with him. I don't think he is a very good lecturer. He's not good at explaining concepts. I highly recommend you read the textbook chapter before coming to class to understand anything of whats going on. He is not eager to answer questions, and he seems frustrated when kids don't understand things. Not mean, but not a warm guy.

Professor Rahul was a really dedicated professor. Despite the fact there is a lot of students in the class, he tried his best to remeber all the students. Do attend to his office hours, it is super useful since he could elaborate on some of the materials. This was the hardest math course I've taken though.

He's a really nice guy. But he's class is hard. If you want to challenge yourself, definitely should take his class. He will help you to get an A, if you can understand all the class materials, homework and practice exams.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: He was pretty good, very kind and taught well.

GIS course 
Didn't learn to use the software in this class. I clicked buttons and watched online tutorials.
We went from having 30-page lab instructions to a 6-page summary. That is to say we had no idea what we were doing the whole semester. 
He gave us extensions though.
Took forever to grade assignments.
