Class isn't really great, its not too hard but attendance is required. Final paper was time intensive. You just won't get anything out of it, professors alright but the course content doesn't teach you anything valuable. Waste of a class, but I don't really regret taking it.

Although many course topics were interesting for understanding how race and racism are a direct cause of "whiteness," the professor clearly expressed bias throughout the semester for particular groups of people. Grades depended on understanding what sociologists meant in their research and later writing papers for the professor to scold your work.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Group projects

comment: Math9b is a very interesting course. This course is about a variety of math puzzles like 7 bridges and handshake puzzles. It was a very relaxed and enjoyable class. The professor's quiz was also very similar to the problem sets. So as long as you participate in class and do your homework, you will definitely get a good grade.

He lectures slowly because he wants everyone on the same page. And this will be a very easy class as long as you attend and do the problem sets. His tests and problem sets are very similar. I would definitely take his class again.

Vino is aggressive. She was mean to students and not willing to solve students' problems. She will attribute the cause of all problems to students, and believe all the decision she made is right. She disrespect students, if you have tiny grammar issue while talking to her, you may unable to speak a complete sentence during the discussion.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Vino is such an incredible mean person who only believe what she considers is right and never cares what students think. She considers herself as an expert of educating international students from China but what all she knows is stereotypes and even racism. Among all the dishonored and disrespectful things, the gateway program is the worst.
Mayada is very nice and not a very tough grader. As long as you do the journals you will get 100/100 on them, and the homework is mostly Latte posts.

She's such a sweet professor and willing to help her students. She's very creative with her lesson plans and engaging. Tasks such as group work and essay writing are fairly challenging but she's very helpful and accessible. Recommend her internship class to all pursueing health field.

His courses are reading-intensive, yes, but we're still only talking about around 50-100 pages on average per session, and keep in mind the class I took was on literature. In contrast, he grades fairly leniently so it shouldn't be too hard to perform well in his classes! He is one of the most caring and erudite person I know. Take his class!

Prof. Matthew is very friendly and knowledgeable. Come to his office hours, and you will learn a lot! However, the workload is heavy. There are a lot of readings and writing, and short assignments. You have to read assigned texts to participate well in the weekly class discussion.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: Not a good teacher.  She began the first class by announcing that she had 2 PhDs and recently authored a book that was "really long, over 500 pages." All reading came from a packet she assembled, which contained a series of bullet points without any context. The lectures did not cover essentials concepts well. Not a college-level class.
No Comments

awesome guy. many quizzes but only 1-3 questions on each. when I took this, there was a tricky end-of-semester quiz where only 2 people got a passing grade, but never mind, you can drop some lowest grades on your homework and quizzes (nevertheless, you need to put in your efforts to big tests) Most amazing class I've had ever since my stay at Bran.

The professor is patient, helpful, and even inspirational: sometimes he gives an interesting non-credit problem at the end of his quizzes, sometimes he provides passages about interesting math facts. The only thing harder in the class is that quizzes are more frequent and shorter, and that they're about the next chapters that you should preview.

Matt is a phenomenal instructor here at Brandeis. He integrates his specialty, philosophy, into every class and provokes learning growth in his daily lectures. Although UWS courses have quite an extensive amount of work, with Matt's guidance, I was able to succeed in this course.
It's a lot of homework.
Great, tough and knows his stuff. Very modest and to the point.
No Comments

women and gender studies was definatly not my fav subject but amy really made it bearable.sometimes she doesn't tell when things are due till they are due and she has a weird voice. as long as she stops teaching early morning classes, i'd recommend her. Also super helpful in one on one meetings although sometimes you walk out with a brand new topic

FANTASTIC UWS professor. She really knows how to help students with papers. My meetings with her made me a better writer and her input was always right-on and useful. Her classes are well structured. She is a bit unorganized and sometimes forgets to tell her students about assignments/due dates but overall I'd recommend her.

Professor Carver is truly a very sweet guy who is great at making his students laugh. Also, the cases he picks out to look at are very interesting as well. However, his grading can sometimes be unclear. He also did not for a sufficient amount of time to complete the midterm. Overall, however, he is a good professor.
Prof Carver is a very nice professor. He is really good at encouraging students. He is good at all those software and websites. There are lots of lectures.

Subject matter is interesting, but Professor Fishman's treatment of it is superficial, at best.  Perhaps one of the problems is that while she teaches American Jewish Sociology, she is not a sociologist by training.  In fact, her Ph.D. is in literature.  Perhaps related, she is terribly biased, and there seems to be a political (conservative) bent.

Professor Fishman taught what she does best: sociology of American Jews.  Though the class was made up of mostly either graduate students or undergrad sophomores, it still felt like I learned a lot at every class.  The readings were fascinating and the final project allowed me to really apply what I learned and broaden my horizons.
Course was ok but too much reading. But this TA is the one to take. She is very helpful and explains things that the lectures leave unclear.
Best TA of the bunch.  She really teaches and helps you understand readings and lecture notes.  Very knowledgeable for a TA and very accessible, too.

His classes are the worst ones you could possibly ever taken in your college life. Grading makes no sense. He gives horrible grades to students and ruin their gpa for no reason at all. His lectures are ambiguous and have no focus. He doesn't encourage students to come up with fun ideas. He prefers dull topics and repetitions.

There are like 8 assignments + a final group project. Assignments are fine but really need a lot of work and they give really weird grades (the average is like 60%). Class material is boring and I have no idea why I took this class... There is also a final group project which takes 1.5 month class time and extra work...
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: SUCH a great professor!! She takes complex topics and breaks them down. It's a shame she only taught in the Fall. Attendance is important, and it's important to keep up with the assignments.
Awesome professor and keeps the material interesting. Would love to take another class with her again

Very hilarious. Effective at introducing students to Stata. Although he does not cover complex models, the introduction he provides can help those interested in exploring advanced econometrics topics. Just make sure you Ace his mid-term, it is also the final grade.

Teaches all stats at Heller and some at IBS. Decent teacher and classes aren't impossible if you attend. Uses online texts. You must learn Stata pretty quickly to pass the class, which is standard for Brandeis although SPSS is used more so IRL IME. Will holler if you are late to class b/c he wants to finish on time. Lectures aren't boring.

Amazing professor. His lectures are very entertaining, always making funny remarks. When teaching a smaller class, he gives in-class writing prompts related to the discussion. As it comes with a small class, participation is more important with fewer students. If it's a larger class, however, he makes sure to keep the students engaged.

Great professor, he's Brandeis alum so he knows the culture of the school and has an easy time relating to students. Specializes in Homeric myth and is able to easily communicate tough concepts to his students. Really cares about the material he teaches as well as creating an environment conducive to open discussion. Would definitely recommend.
Nice professor. Care about students and willing to help you outside of classes. Tests are kind of hard but he will curve the grades.
Honestly, the class I took with him was one of the hardest I've ever taken, but that's not his fault. He does his best to help you learn the material.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tests are tough

comment: Such a nice professor!! During COVID times professor Shapiro has been the nicest and most compassionate professor who truly gets it!

Tom Shapiro is a very distinguished professor who is passionate about closing the racial wealth gap in the US. He is inspiring and I think his class is useful for everyone regardless of their field of study.
Dr. Sliwoski is a true blessing to academia. 10/10.

I did Fit Camp with Jason, and it is very chill. As long as you show up and do your best, you pass. The workouts are hard if you make them hard, or easier if you aren't at that level yet (customizable).
Very easy class. Light on lectures, papers are short. 99% of the discussion took place in small groups and he traveled around to check in.
BEST professor I have had so far at Brandeis. Caring, interesting lectures and readings.

Most boring professor I've ever had. Only did as well as I did because I took AP Stats in high school. Knows her topic, has no idea how to teach. Take good notes or you'll fail. Does allow an index cards worth of notes for tests and a piece of notebook paper of notes for the final, so not a total wash.

Her lecture is awful. Explains things not well and most of time you dont know what she is talking. She sounds so weak. The class itself is very easy and you can study by yourself. Homework and test questions are in exactly same format as example questions she did in class. Just copy that and imitate the steps of problem solving, you will get an A.

Amazing professor who truly wants you to learn about the topic at hand. His lectures give so much context and background information - he is clearly an incredibly knowledgable person who is passionate about what he teaches. He'll try to recruit you to history of ideas - I'd recommend you say yes because it's worth it!

Very though provoking and encourages creativity, also willing to work with you if/when something goes wrong. Wasn't great about establishing expectations or keeping a steady in-class schedule, but provided us with study notes and flexible deadlines.
rating_tags: Respected--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: not crunchhy

Dr. Xu is very knowledgeable and passionate. This is the first time the course was taught.
Class was incredibly difficult and was graded on just a few homeworks, a midterm, and a final.
Grading turnaround was long, grading was unclear. 
With a better structure and more feedback / more checkpoint grades a course with Dr. Xu could be more enjoyable.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment:
Class is a requirement and is extremely hard. Ben is invested in having you succeed but Brandeis needs to take it easy on the rigor. 

Have a good stats and econ background before taking this course
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Professor Koskinen is one of the hardest graders I have ever experienced throughout undergrad and grad school. Class your grade is computed using 4 total assignments. He is a very fast lecturer so if you mess up on a line of code be prepared to be lost for the rest of the class. He thinks that every student is already an econometrician. Don't do it
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Very knowledgable and interesting. Learned a ton in her class. Take one if you have a chance! She is also very accessible outside of class and can help you with your own research.

Loved this class. She was amazing. We learned so much about race and ethnicity and all the complexities that lie between. Her class was discussion based but it really helped bc you absorb the readings. She does a great job of guiding you through them as well.

Sarah is an awesome lecturer. They are accessible to students outside of class. The projects in the class make the course less stressful. Sarah is very friendly and cares about their students. Sarah is great with helping students transition from High school to College. Sarah puts in time to have a positive classroom

Sarah, is an awesome lecturer. They are accessible to students outside of class. The projects in the class make the course less stressful. Sarah is very friendly and cares about their students. Sarah is great with helping students transition from High school to College. Sarah puts in time to have a positive classroom
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment:
She is having problem picking up questions from students, and said unhinged stuff in class: N is more electronegative than O; L is lysine; misspelled aldol; hemiacetal formation is condensation. She expected student learned physics instead of organic chemistry as prerequisite for this class. 
Did give extra credit, and quizzes are easy.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: Worst professor I've had. Rude to students when they ask questions/for help and demeaning when students answer questions wrong. Changes the course and grading structure on a whim (at least once a week), exclusively gives less than 1 minute per question on exams/quizzes. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: LGLS 129a is a fairly easy class made very accessible by Prof Stimell. We were graded on four 750word papers and a final group project. The papers help with the project and if you do all of the work you'll probably get an A-. There were lots of guest speakers from experts in the field. Stimell is understanding and gives decent feedback.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: Prof. Stimell is a really amazing woman who knows what she's talking about and cares for her students. She has great connections and many of her students ask her to help them decide on  internships and jobs. She is tough though, and she loves group projects. My group was awful, but she recognized that and gave me the credit I deserved.

Great professor. Lectures are interesting and homework is graded fairly. Just show up to class and do the assignments, and you'll get a good grasp of theory and notation. And if you don't get something, he's always willing to help out of class or during breaks.

Good professor. Easy to understand and explains theory concepts well. Very chill and the homework sheets take maybe 30 minutes to an hour at most once you understand the theory. Just show up and pay attention, it's that easy.
Took me a while to get her sense of humor, but after that we got along well and I enjoyed the class
Interesting professor and course. She's a bit snobbish and has dry humor but otherwise approachable once u get to know her (and she u). looking forward to taking more courses with her.

Puts people down. "Reviews" material in class, assuming you know everything already. Class is basically going over homework. There's never a point where you feel like you're learning anything. It's very disconcerting just being in her class. She's very available to talk to, but when you do, you come away more confused than you were before. Avoid.

I know Brandeis doesn't offer classes at 6 am, but if I had to choose between having her class at 10 (which I did) and having this class with a different professor every morning at 6, I would chose the 6 am class. Avoid at all costs.
Disorganized lectures.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Had her for Biochem 101.  Not always the clearest (messy handwriting), but knows what she's talking about and is always willing to explain more.  Listen in lecture and copy down everything she writes and you'll be fine.  Expect weird examples of protein function and hilarious stories.

Jason was a great teacher, and I'd love to have him again someday.  He really knows his****, and he made what could be a boring topic really fun.  He expects a lot but is always there to help you out.

This is a difficult course, but Jason was very honest and down-to-earth about it.  He was constantly seeking to explain the information in a way that made sense, and the annoying weekly tests were the only reason I kept up with the material.
Amazing lectures! I learned a lot. Attendance is not mandatory, you can pretty much skip the entire semester. Pretty flexible grading.

Professor Cline is a fantastic lecturer and extremely inspirational. His vocabulary alone keeps me intrigued in class. The class wasn't particularly difficult, and he encourages students just to think and ponder various ethical questions above all else, and is genuinely interested in the thoughts of his students

Great professor was able to communicate the material effectively. Was available outside of class for students that need extra help. Will recommend her for any other students looking to take her class.
Really bad teacher. Talks at the board rather than presenting a topic. She does not give much practice in class. Also, doesn't talk very clearly. She is however available outside of class.

He's very kind and caring to his students and greatly accessible. He went above and beyond my expectations as a professor and has been a helpful resource. You will learn a lot, just remember to take notes and attend office hrs!

Such an amazing professor. He was very kind and respectful to students and pushed us to learn and ask questions. Very accessible and recommend going to his office hrs specifically for hw and essays. His health econ class is fairly challenging but the material is worth it.

Loved his class when I took it freshman year. Lectures were super interesting and well-delivered- especially since I had little to no experience with music! He was also a very approachable and understanding professor. (he also brought us sweets during our finals) Learned a lot and had fun too. Would love to take another class with him soon!
He has interesting lectures. Very knowledgable about music. There is a bit of writing to do in this class, but it's a pretty easy class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: I highly recommend this course; I would take it again. It provided really helpful guidance on my UWS essay.Highly recommended, would take this again. Constructive guidance on my UWS essay.
It was an amazing class, really chill and relaxed. Attendance is required. Learned a lot. ReallyCaring!!!
There's a decent amount of writing in this class, but by the time you're done, you don't have to do any drafting for final assignments, which is really nice.

This course was reading and writing heavy, but I would recommend that any future healthcare workers take it. It's not an easy course, but it's entirely worthwhile. It completely transformed the ways in which I think about healthcare equity and deepened my understanding of feminist bioethics as a necessary tool for achieving that equity.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Excellent discussion leader. Attendance technically isn't required, but you're not going to get anything out of the class and will probably fail if you skip regularly. One of the rare classes where you actually do have to do all of the readings and bring them to class- no skimming.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: I took several classes with M. Randall and he was by far my favorite professor in undergrad. To tell the truth, I graduated in 2014, but when I came on here in 2021 and saw he had no reviews, I had to put my 2 cents in. You will learn French in his classes. Its not an easy A, but he is fair, and he wants everyone to do well. I miss his classes!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: He's a nice guy and I did alright on most of the assignments except the first. The lectures can be a bit boring but he means well and makes them funny sometimes with analogies to the real world. I think it would have been beneficial to get more feedback because I was able to do better on the later assignments but I'm not exactly sure how or why.

A kindhearted guy who is responsive to questions and is always willing to listen to our perspectives. I did well on every assignment, but I did not get comprehensive feedback so I'm not sure if I learned properly. The lectures could be a bit dry since Prof. E would talk a lot, but he would connect to real-world scenarios which was appreciated.
I took Professor Murphy for History of American Capitalism. If you are looking for a very easy and boring class then this is it. Otherwise, I would not recommend.

Professor Murphy was great and very caring about students. He was always available outside class and there to talk. Work load was not bad at all, would for sure take again. Had great lectures and cared about student input. Great professor, great class.
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: The best English teacher I've ever had. His feedback is actually very helpful and is the perfect balance of honesty while delivering it in a nice way. Really cares about his students and is so kind and really engaging in class. I'm so sad he doesn't teach any more classes.

Prof. Dale's UWS class was great. He's a PhD candidate in game studies and musicology, so he has great experience and insight on the subject. He also gives actually useful feedback on essays. He's also very relaxed with deadlines. Overall a caring, thoughtful professor, and he clearly wants his students to succeed. I wish he taught more classes!

I took Workers' Rights in the US with Prof. Kaye in Spring 2024. Lectures, field trips, and guest speakers were all incredibly engaging. Offering ample extra credit opportunities, generous assignment submission windows, and thoughtful feedback, Prof. Kaye clearly wants her students to succeed.  I *need* to take another class with Prof. Kaye.

Super boring but super easy. Not sure why a NEJS professor was teaching LGLS class on worker's rights. Didn't seem to know what she was talking about sometimes and acted like we were middle schoolers. Take-home final was ridiculously long but you could Google most of the answers. Otherwise one essay and read the news. Basic material, easy A class.
rating_tags: Participation matters--EXTRA CREDIT--Graded by few things

comment: He was very inconsistent and unclear. He did not seem to understand the material that well and kept making mistakes while teaching... I did like the material and the textbook though...

Quantum chemistry. Agar is pretty much the man. Probably the most fun I've had in any class during my time at Brandeis. He isn't an amazing teacher but he wants you to do well and will reward you if he see's that you're working hard. The man should consider doing stand up because he is too hilarious.
very confusing, tries to get through material without teaching it. if you meet with him after class hes actually helpful. other than that pick another teacher for the class
Very helpful in class, goes out of way to explain stuff, definitely recommend

While Professor Canella is a very nice and respected professor, he doesn't teach you how to model and then expects you to pick it up on your own. The entire grading for the class is based on homework assignment which if fine except he told tells you how to do them after you turn it in. Definitely would not take another class with this professor.
Great Professor, has a very specific style.  He is a wealth of information if you do the work and are intellectually curious. Highly recommend any class with him.
Very friendly and helpful
Very knowledgable and easy to deal with. He explains the concepts very well and is always there to help. I would absolutely recommend him.

Really great and knowledgeable for being so young. Could have been a little clearer with feedback on assignment. Encouraged me and my group to take on a very ambitious project and believed in us, ultimately leading to results I was proud of. Highly recommended!

Took an experiential learning course as part of the first year honor's program. Professor Arad was really great, super engaging and into conversation. A little slow on grading but makes up for it with caring, bringing cool speakers and curating reading materials.
She is a really nice person, but an awful lecturer.

The professor claimed that this is a science course, but it's not. The class is based on facts and details rather than logic and rationales. You have to type every words she said in class, because you won't have any useful slides and recordings that you can use to prepare for exams. She tested a lot of class details that were outside textbooks.

Nicole is a gem. She really cares about the subject matter and wants all her students to succeed. Her essay feedback is extremely helpful, and if you fix everything she says to fix, you will get an A on the paper. Easily one of my favorite classes at Brandeis. This should be your #1 UWS pick.

She is the most adorable professor out there! She cares about her students, listens to everybody's needs, caters to everyone, and makes sure we all end up in the finish line together. She is very funny too and gives very useful feedback on essays
A joke.

Carina is an awesome person with an astoundingly vast knowledge of the entire curriculum at her disposal. There are a LOT of readings, and as much as you'll want to skip them, DON'T! This class was really informative, even for a non AAAS major like me, and I greatly recommend this class and professor, as long as you're up for a challenge.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Has so much experience and teaches in an interactive setting. He lives his material. Only a few minutes of research will show his high standing in his field. He is a wealth of knowledge and easily one of Brandeis best professors

Amazing professor. He will change your views about so many things. He is quite hard, but if you work you can do well, and everything you learn is completely work it. TAKE A CLASS WITH THIS PROFESSOR IF YOU CAN
ALYSSA CANELLI IS TERRIBLE!
Alyssa Canelli is violent and should be banned from all campuses.
Most funny class I had ever take in Brandeis. Lots of presentation but not boring !

Wittenberg was clearly very interested in our presentations and was invested in helping us improve. He gives lots of great feedback. The only downside to the class is that it's on Zoom, and he makes you practice with random partners who might ghost you. But other than making presentations there's little work.
Readings and then writing. Not too much work, but it is UWS, so writing essays will happen.
She is pretty straightforward, but also sees things as black and white which can be very frustrating at times.

Easy A but she is not a great professor. Spends most of class talking about things unrelated to the material and is always a bit "out of it" and gets weirdly jumpy in class. Just reads off the slides and never responds to emails. TAs are slightly more helpful but also not great. Very monotone when lecturing I almost fall asleep. Seems sweet tho ig.

I absolutely loved professor Tuson, but so many of the assignments and quizzes were created and graded by the TAs that I had many issues with this class that were completely unrelated to the professor. She's so real and funny in her lectures and clearly so passionate about what she does. Hard and frustrating class, but not because of the professor.

I really liked the class I took with Prof. Tam! It was very discussion-based, so it was always interesting. I thought his grading was fair and he was always willing to meet to discuss papers outside of class. He does give pop quizzes, but they're easy.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: i took an AAPI related course with him and his class was very discussion heavy. he will make sure you participate in class atleast a little. super nice person, cares about his students and what he teaches.
Prof Tam needs to chill out! He gives way too many assignments and the pop reading quizzes are so condescending
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes--So many papers

comment: If you want to experience a slow death and get a bad grade for doing a lot of assignments, go for it.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Good luck.

I did not put any work into this class besides doing the required homework an hour or 2 before it was due, so my grade is not reflective of much. Job is the freakin best. Very patient, caring, and is a great teacher. Explains things well and in different ways if need-be for different students. Super funny and I loved going to class.

He's pretty hard but he tries his best to help. He goes off of his own notes (not in the book) for certain topics so make sure to take notes in class. Sit in front because his handwriting is horrific.
She is very nice. She is also very organized and good at explaining. She tries really hard. Very hardworking. Very good for a young professor.
Very nice professor. Grades fairly, if not a bit easy. Enjoyed the class, but she has a Women and Gender Studies view of it, so if you are not a fan of that lens, don't take the class.
Good professor hard to understand at times

Really really nice person. Her lectures are too fast and there are somethings she could spend more time on. She knows her stuff. very knowledgeable and patient. She doesn't curve the grade but when determining the final grade if you are a little below the line, she will grant you the grade in your favor.

He also teaches econ stats and right away, it's evident that he gives a lot of homework. Lectures are dry, but laptops are allowed to follow along. Attendance counts but only if you're in between grades. Econometrics in general is difficult and you won't be prepared unless you do all sorts of problems and READ the textbook (or cheat but nahs).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: I believe this was the first course he's taught, and he did well! Class was generally entertaining, and he struck the right balance between discussion and lecture. Sometimes you could tell he was new, but he seemed to find his stride. Pretty funny and in general, class was entertaining. A lot of reading, so come prepared.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: If you are studying Master level courses, don't miss his RMGT 101. It's an eye opener.

Professor Desmond is scary in that way that she knows literally so much about what she's teaching that it's kind of intimidating. She's a great teacher though, and a nice person. Just beware, the textbook readings are long-winded and incomprehensible. Don't study it too hard, just get the tl;dr and you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: If you're interested in User Centered Design this class is a great introduction for you. Sarah is a great professor and runs the class very organized. Great group work to apply real world situations

Prof Simon is an excellent professor: believes in the concept that students should be taught for the sake of being taught, not for compensatory grades. He rarely tests, but he does assign readings. The readings aren't do or die, but they definitely help understand more about what is going on in class. Overall, he is very insightful and caring.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: We watch a lot of movies in class as inspiration. He pauses them and adds his own ideas and analyzes shots & such. He also opens our work to the whole class and we have a whole class feedback session on our work, which I found rly helpful. He's a really easy-going professor, explains everything well, and will work w/ u individually if u need help.
Professor Warfield is so sweet, and most of the class is just spent working on different group projects which are pretty easy.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: This class was basically introductory statistics. She was very by the book and quite knowledgable on the subject matter. She was also a very nice and chill person in general and tried her best to teach the class. You should/better know your stats by the end of this class. It didn't hurt that she was quite attractive as well.
you'd need to be a masochist to take her class and enjoy it

Dr. Ackley flaunts his classes as having the most consistent, highest enrollment of any classes at the entire university. As a person, Taylor sets each of his students up for success as long as they go to class and stay engaged. I will be desolate walking by the Music Center everyday knowing that the administration is letting him go to save money.

very interesting class and overall a great lecturer. the lectures and textbook aren't ever super relevant to the assignments, but it's worth going for attendance and to hear him talk. he's clearly passionate about what he does, and it's so worth taking his courses
This is the best professor I've ever met and his always supportive and patient to your questions.

Prof. Mitra is an amazing professor, an even better person, and an expert in her field. Prof. Mitra has high expectations for students, and you will have to work for your 'A,' but Prof. Mitra is super engaging and gives great feedback. You will learn a lot if you put the work in, and maybe even find that disability policy is your calling (as I did)

Prof Miller is very nice + available outside of class for help. Lecture content could be scattered and difficult to understand. Some coding background helpful (intro to python). Tutorials can be frustrating and time consuming but cool, working with classmates made it better. Majority got A, can't say I retained much, cool to learn MATLAB.

Vasiliy has the potential to be a great Math professor. Although his lectures are boring at times and there is little practice given during class. I do however like the outcome based grading system he employs for his class, so you have an increasing number of chances to raise your grade in the class.

Will C. is the most caring and thoughtful professor I have ever had. He taught me the value of creating invitations for people to share their stories and listening actively when people choose to open up. Playback Theatre can be emotionally intense but it is also a lot of fun and 100% worth taking.

While Curi clearly cares a lot about her students, her grading system is incredibly confusing. She will only give a few sentences for essay requirements, then take off points based on extremely trivial reasons. Even when giving feedback, she won't point out all the mistakes in your paper, leaving you to lose points later.

DO NOT TAKE HER! Yes the class was interesting, but that does not make up for her ridiculous and unclear grading criteria. She was incredibly particular about the format and content of essays, and if you didn't mention one thing (even if unrelated to the prompt), you would lose points. She also didn't add anything in class that wasn't in readings.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Super friendly, and makes classes the perfect balance between discussion and lecture. Content is interesting, and is a great class for anyone interested in HSSP or public health in general.

I'm a history majored student, and I have taken many higher level courses. BUT by far this is the hardest. Don't get fooled by the Brandeis ratings. A lot seniors & juniors drop with me because the essay grading is just soooo confusing. I do not know what she want after reading the essay comments. ps, she writes emails asking students stay. DON'T!!

Rob is an amazing professor. Regardless of your major, he will make the class fun, engaging, and will try to connect with you. He is very accessible outside of the classroom through email or scheduled appointments. For Stage Combat though, the midterm and final fight scenes don't have a rubric, but are graded based on what he thinks you deserve.
She's really nice, you will be regretful if you don't take her class.
Good lectures so that you can get by the homeworks without really having to read the textbook. Good at explaining concepts.
Gear Professor! She gives good lecture, and very accessible in office hours! Explains concepts super good and is a nice person.
She was nice enough, but seemed kinda pretentious and didn't really feel like she respected students' past experiences, knowledge, and points of view when it came to theater and art

Jasmine Johnson is the best professor I have ever had. She really makes you work for your grade, though, and will call you out if you don't. This means that there is a lot of pressure and late nights, but the reward for doing this work is all the better.   Quick note: the readings are essential.
she is not helpful at all, bad apple
Lectures were boring. Problem sets were manageable as long as you work with people. Exams are a piece of cake.
he want you to think but think correctly points off for wrong thinking, homeworks graded harshly, need to participate a lot more than required
Love prof Alon! Def an asset to Brandeis. They need more prof like him. He def care for his student's academic achievement. I would take his classes again and would recommend to everyone!

Great professor. Really knows her stuff. Attendance is mandatory (miss five classes, you fail the course) but with her you really want to come to class - she engages her students. Not easy, but fair grader. Material is dense at times but comprehendable. Brandeis would do well to keep her around.
a nice man
A great person and teacher. Really funny and bubbly.

This professor knows the material well but he does not know how to teach. He can't explain well enough. His class is going way too fast and assume every student gets what he is doing. He often lectures for the whole class and it is very hard for students to keep up. My advice is to try to avoid this class and this professor.
Amazing professor. You must work really hard to do well, however. Read the textbook and you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Mr Noonan grades the hardest out of all Health Informatics Professors. In his own words, he has never given out a 100 for a grade. Normal levels of discussion are worthy of around a 90. Look elsewhere for your electives. Majority of the grade (60%) comes from two assignments, due in week 8 and 9. One is a group project.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Group projects

comment: I had Professor Frey before she went to Brandeis. After class was canceled for snow, she invited our small class to her house for class and gave us pizza during class. She's nice, caring, and completely interested in her students and their thoughts, not to mention an expert in her field. Worst part was the long readings.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: Not good, don't take

Professor Hadi is difficult to understand at times and has no control over how his TA's grade your programming assignments. Class averages for exams were consistently in the 50s. Everything turned out fine when he curved the class by 2 letter grades.
His class is mostly lecture based.  He's super smart and the readings are mostly pretty interesting.  He is patient during discussions and grades fairly but not generously
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: powelstock's class is a lot of reading. he makes you read like half a book before the next class and his papers are weird and honestly more demanding than they need to be. on top of that he denied me an extension on a paper despite me proving i desperately needed one. honestly unless you're really into the topic- not worth the effort he requires
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--So many papers

comment: Discussion-based class - fairly easy, though there were lots of papers due at the end of the semester (3/4 were long-term and could be done at any time, so it's my own fault tbh). Most texts can be found at the library - you don't need to buy/rent them all
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Easily the best teacher I've ever had in my life. Dr. Goldstein is the real deal when it comes to Buddhist and South Asian studies, but he's also an incredibly caring person. Lots of reading every week, and very dense (yet fascinating) lectures, but his passion for teaching is infectious. Very flexible grader. Take his classes if you want to learn!

Worst class ever. Millions of work each week, she has high expectations for students but low expectations for herself. Never give timely feedback but always gave students bad grades. Never took Econ59 from her.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Very great professor! I love Prof. Jee. Good lecture, fun and easy class, and very accessible outside of hours. She answers questions really good, probably better in office hours than lecture.

Beware of this class. You'll get half hour to 45 hour recordings to watch outside of class on top of your regular class. So much work for little payoff. It was exhausting to be in her class. Never again.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment:
Requires high levels of participation.
Content was valuable for a business major
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Poor excuse for an educator. Knowledgeable about course, no ability to communicate. Passive aggressive style to get himself across. Is not able to transfer much of his theory over to tacit knowledge. Unclear expectations and there were multiple instances where he was challenging and engaging students in a disrespectful manner.
Really interesting readings and lectures. Completely discussion based. Sorta hard grader, but if you put some effort into the essay will do well. Funny
fantastic teacher, lecturer

Lipsett is incredibly helpful. He comes to his classes prepared and gives organized lectures/notes. He makes himself available during office hours, or stays extra time if need be. He is a really nice guy and very approachable. Also has a sense of humor while teaching. The work load isn't too bad either.
wonderful teacher, caring, knowledgeable. sets a great balance between singing technique and performance. i regret not being closer to continue working with her.
By far the best professor I have had so far at Brandeis. Amazing Math teacher, and an incredibly caring guy. He is also incredibly knowledgeable and passionate about the subject.
Professor Leu is very helpful and patient. He makes the investments class easy to understand and makes sure everyone understands the material.

Really like her class!! Dr. J is so inspiring and she really changes the way I write and makes me less afraid of writing!! She is super, super, super smart, humorous and knowledgable. She is always so energetic with big smile!! Words fail me to describe how good she is and how wonderful her class is!!
He tries to remember everyone's name in the class and he actually does. Nice teaching style, hot accent, and cute personality. Sometimes I find myself gazing at him instead of the blackboard.
sweet and caring
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Yu-Hui is wonderful. Full of life, knowledgeable, and best of all she's kind. She makes the 1.5 hour long class go by so quick. A good grade is still a challenge, but she's great at helping you out when you're stuck.

This course is a good one to satisfy the writing intensive requirement. If you're a graduate student, you'll be required to write three papers. For undergrad, that's two papers and a final exam. The final is not hard if you pay attention to his lectures and readings.

Pretty easy class graded on a few simple things. Lecture heavy and your engagement level is up to you. If you do engage, it can be pretty interesting, but it isn't required. Readings aren't required either. You just need to take decent notes and write a good paper for an A. Very kind professor.
One of the most passionate and kindest professors I've had, considered becoming a NEJS minor just to have an excuse to take more of his classes

For the entire semester, always takes a long time to reply to emails and even with 4 TAs getting back grades took an unusually long time. 2 weeks for a final exam in a 5 week summer class. Lectures are informative but boring, be prepared to take a lot of notes on your own
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment:
The class was helpful and I gained plenty of knowledge for a job I would start. 

However, I think the professors grades you according to how much they like you, and you guys hit it off. I genuinely don't care about it, but it was my lowest grade of the semester while enrolled in much more advanced classes. Save time and take another elective.

I had Dr. BH for Roman/Byzantine Egypt (CLAS 156B). It was a great, thorough class. She has high expectations but is also very helpful, giving an incredible amount of useful feedback on assignments. This course is reading heavy and a writing intensive. She is highly knowledgeable and skilled in her areas (Egypt, Byzantium, and archaeology).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: I had a pretty tough semester but Professor Aaron was really understanding and accommodating. He's clearly very smart and really passionate about the material. Textbook was useless but you do have to come to class because the quizzes are open note and he bases them entirely on content from lecture. Would definitely recommend
Boring Professor
Didn't exactly learn much but I managed to pass the class with very limited spanish knowledge.
Cool dude with irish accent. My friends who BSed all their assignments got better grades than me LOL.

Prof. Johannes is a nice person, however, the lectures are not very engaging and make it difficult to learn. I would prefer more of a discussion-based class structure to better grasp the material. The grading consists of 2 exams, 2 essays, and 9 assignments. I would say they are of average difficulty for a college course.

For people who get through 127B (DBMS), this is a research-based class in data system design. The class is driven by paper readings (mostly on LSM-trees), which motivate the lectures from Subhadeep and from guest speakers. You get what you put in, since there are not many graded assignments. I recommend if you are self-motivated.

Definitely the most professional professor I have ever had. The lectures are very informative and engaging. The entire course is extremely well-organized, from the slides to the class page. Very accessible and patient in office hours. I would recommend this to anyone who is ready for a challenge.

Prof. Dean is a great teacher and mentor- and truly cares about the students understanding the material. She gives very detailed feedback, something that I grew to highly appreciate. Her courses are perfect for someone who is passionate about economics and wants supplement the theories with real-world examples.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Crazzzzy harrd bro. Had to sweat so hard to get an A in the class. The final was worth 55% of my grade?!? Crazy surprisingly clutched up. Lectures are way too fast paced if it weren't for the TA's reteaching the content in their free time I would have for sure failed.

She seems sweet, but she speeds through content too quickly and is disorganized with her slides. She posted the midterm review guide just a day before the exam. I want to like her, but this is the hardest class I've taken at Brandeis, and it's only been a month. Most of the class is struggling.

She is a very engaging teacher. It's a philosophy class so it does get repetitive and boring at times, but she does a good job at making it interesting. For example, she'll present the information in a way that's fun and relatable even if it's a philosophical idea from hundreds of years ago.

She is always there for her students outside of her class. Excellent teacher. Extremely passionate about her field.  Gives great feedback.  Respectful of student ideas.  Not an easy A, but well worth it.  Read the assigned book for full appreciation of class.  She really cares for her students.  A true acting teacher, fully immersed in the art.

he cares deeply about his students learning the language, and learning it well very funny in unexpected ways knowledgeable about a ridiculous range of topics really understands not only arabic language, but its connections to other languages, how it developed, how to learn languages, and so on very clear teacher, classes are well organized

Very engaging lecturer, kind, and humorous. Strong in certain topics. Propagated wrong or misinformation on many occasions, which left me not very confident in his teaching. Only grades exams so he does not know how you are doing until exam time, but he is extremely approachable and does want his students to succeed. Welcoming to go to forquestions
Be prepared for test questions not covered in class and feedback that makes you go "huh"
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Your best choice
the class is very casual and conversational. it is not a lecture which is something I loved
A professor who expects you to know material without teaching it? You can imagine how painful it is to work with Tom.

Professor Feldman is engaging and extremely knowledgeable. I would recommend his courses to anyone. He assigns large papers (10-12 pages), but they are doable and he is not a super harsh grader. He will make you work a little though in a good way.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: Just a very boring teacher. I was interested in the topic, enjoyed the readings quite a bit, but he was just so dry. Luckily he doesn't lecture much, he tries to switch things up, show videos, have his TA talk for a bit. There's a lot of discussion. But I just found myself groaning on the walk to class. But good guy who obviously cares about you.
Skipped half the semester. Had quizzes about topics not covered in class.
rating_tags: Tests? Not many--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Prof. Morrison was the worst professor I have encountered in the Brandeis English department. My final grade was based on one single paper given back a month after it was originally turned in and then two other assignments from the last week of classes that probably were never even graded. He gave no feedback on the paper and argued with students.

It was clear that she loves her subject and teaching, so her enthusiasm is a plus. But she is a tough grader because she expects her students to arrive at abstract conclusions with little to no guidance. Great as a person with amazing Powerpints, but tough as a teacher and grader.

Her lectures were really interesting and very helpful. Lots of reading but if you do it all you will do well. She's really nice and I would suggest everyone take a class with her if they have the chance.
what a nice guy. he is always ready to help you.

Professor Boswell lays out a clear syllabus and grading rubrik for assignments and examinations. An 'A' in his course is achievable, but you must put in the effort. He presents the material effectively so all students not only understand but maintain interest. He's a sharp professor and a great guy!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Marina Victorovna is an extremely easy grader, but she's super super mean. So you get good grades, but you feel bad about yourself. Someone sent her an email asking a question, and she absolutely reamed them in her response. You gotta take her class to continue Russian, but you're basically going to be teaching yourself.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Patterson is one of the best professor I've ever met in Brandeis. His lecture is super organized and you can tell from his board writing. He will give you the definition and follow up with inspiring examples to help you understand better. He also has great knowledge checklist to help you review after every class with the homework.

She's very kind and accommodating and willing to work with students to help them pass. She does, however, have a lot of mandatory outlines for papers, so if you're a procrastinator or a write it in one go person, it's a little taxing.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--So many papers

comment: Professor Hassenfeld is amazing! She cares deeply about the topic and her students, and lectures in a very engaging way. The readings can be complicated but she always walks you through them, and if you do them and pay attention you will learn so much from her. 100% would take again.

Professor Hassenfeld is brilliant. She cares deeply about Education, literacy, and instilling knowledge and critical thinking skills in her students. There is a good amount of reading, but all the articles are assigned with the assumption that they are challenging to make sense of. Do the reading and put in the effort and you will learn from her.

May brings his experience as a writer for the NYT and the Boston Globe into the classroom. Through attending school events, students do real reporting and then get thorough feedback. The class size allows us to all sit around a round table and evaluate every person's article (in a not scary way) and openly discuss modern applications of journalism.

Terrible, unqualified instructor (PhD in early childhood development). Class is more dumbed down than any at Heller. Curriculum includes bar graph v. pie chart, data placemats, and Trello. No actual M&E. Waste of time! Laura spends more time complaining about how little she is paid than teaching. Class should be replaced with data analytics.

Professor Heck is an awesome teacher. He really took the time to get to know our class and was always asking for our feedback and opinions. Especially in the subject of History, it was refreshing to express to a teacher our want to learn more about other cultures and have him listen and adapt the syllabus. Very fair tests, but lots of reading.

-Extremely, extremely unorganized, last-minute, and all over the place
-30-45 minutes late to almost every class, sometimes without warning
-Changed course direction frequently
-Just an overall bummer for a class whose subject matter itself is otherwise very interesting -- huge let down

Professor Pollack is a phenomenal professor! He always put student mental health first. Although we sometimes had to take the class virtually because he had to deal with clients out of state, his zoom lectures were just as engaging as his in person ones. I would highly recommend anyone interested in environmental law or politics take this class.
Class does get overwhelming at the start but eventually, if you do the homework, it gets very enjoyable. Math heavy.

Took this class as a first year with no background in anthropology, and no formal background in gender/sexuality studies and found it difficult. New readings each class (least amount was maybe 15 pg, longest was around 90), discussion-based, two essays, no tests.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: UWS itself was not helpful for me, but that's the curriculum, not the professor. Dr. Heath-Stout is amazing and incredibly equitable

PhD student, so she's a little underconfident in herself. Readings are fascinating, but you'll be discussing them with your peers in small groups, not with her, so you'll probably miss out on their full potential.

A very nice professor and fair grader. Just be ready to participate in class, and do all homework assigned. Also there is a quiz or test every week so it requires a lot of work. Other than that, if you put in the effort and attend all classes you will do good.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: I. Love. Prof. Singh. Literally cannot say enough good things about this woman. She is so kind and genuinely cares about the wellbeing of her students. She gives daily homework, but its short (never more than 15 mins) and actually helps you learn. Attendance and participation is super important, if you skip class, you WILL get behind so don't.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Woodcut + relief was a really great class, Sonia is a super nice person. Had 3 projects in the semester and they were graded pretty easily--even if you're not a studio art major/minor. Assignments + carving with lino + wood were a lot of fun and really enjoyed working in the studio. Very satisfying medium and rewarding to make your own prints.

You can tell he is passionate about the topics and cares about students, but he just dosen't know how to teach. He seems to complicate the easiest topics and it is often hard to follow him in class. Attendance is mandatory but I honestly would've learned more by just using the textbook.

Many students didn't like Dev, but I think as long as you pay attention, ask questions when you have them, and do the assigned homeworks, he is a pretty fine professor. The homework isn't graded, so unfortunately the only contributors to the grade are the weekly quizzes and the exams, but the class was pretty easy and he knew the material well.

Dev explains material clearly enough and seldom expands further than what he remembers on his slides straight out of the textbook. He clearly does not want to be here teaching the class, in fact he said as much once. But this is pretty average for a Brandeis STEM lecturer.

A hard-A class when I took the class, but the professor was really kind, patient and helpful. Although she's not very good at expressing the concepts, she's diligent enough to write down the details on the blackboard and try her best to explain. Tests were a little time-intensive, but it wouldn't matter much if you are well-prepared.
Hard subject. Great teacher.

Not too bad of a professor, can be enthusiastic, if you are fine with a teacher who gives you 1 example Q then expects you to understand how to do it on a worksheet or an exam, Very helpful in extra help sessions, but has a heavy Chinese accent, and reeks of menthol. You have to have prerequisite knowledge of calc, or you will be completely lost.
Excellent professor! She cares a lot about both the subject and the students and her passion comes through.  Really creative, helpful, and genuine.

I tried to communicate with her, but I'm not sure she's a good listener. She kept misinterpreting (we'd have to elaborate or clarify).  She also had trouble communicating what she wanted for assignments, and the class was disappointing. She's knowledgeable and has a lot of experience, though. May have liked her under different circumstances.
She grades homework depending on how much effort you put in (her word). The class is easy, but A requires 1-2hr outside class work. She is nice.

The thing about Professor Troen is that he is intentionally divisive. He operates within  a facade of open conversation, constructive debate and conversation, however he is a clever and manipulative polemicist. He does not teach but rather professes his politics. He hardly prepares for his classes, preferring instead to speak in anecdotes.
only OK
Amazing! Learned how to think rigorously about math, and my mathematical writing improved.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Class was very confusing at first with an unclear syllabus. Prof. Sheridan was very responsive to feedback and over time the class discussions became more clear and focused, however, there were times when I was still confused. Very friendly and always open to new ideas.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Dmitry's class was an introduction to theatre for me, and a great one at that. While he can seem scary at first, one quickly learns that he is tremendously knowledgeable and knows how to lead great discussions in class. I loved my class with Dmitry and am looking forward to taking another class from him in the future, he is a great professor.
No Comments
She's amazing!

Laura is a great professor. She truly wants you to succeed and if you ask for help she will help you in any way possible. Highly recommend going to her office hours or setting up an appointment it is very very helpful. She's also hilarious and class discussions are interesting and engaging.
He's really fun and detailed and respectful.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Great writing adviser. He helped me with my essays greatly over the course of the semester.
goat

overorganized but never in a way thats helpful. everything is on the syllabus instead of course page, so its a hassle to manage assignments as theyre being updated. the majority of classes are inorganic discussions. hes pretty knowldegable and clearly puts effort in. just next time do it in a way that doesnt set off my fight or flight please

We had Dr. Heyman her first semester teaching at Brandeis and she was absolutely great! Total expert on child and adolescent mental health, and had a great balance between lecturing and student engagement, with a straightforward group project and interesting policy proposal assignments. She's so friendly and brought donuts on the last day too :)

I'm not sure if he'll be teaching again, but honestly, he was a pretty good teacher.  UWS isn't a great program to begin with, but it seems like he tried his best.  He was always very accommodating and would let the class decide if he would wear a mask, every single class.  He's a really great guy but his teaching can be a bit boring sometimes.

I really enjoyed the class I took with Professor Weiss! I thought the amount of work assigned made sense and felt easy enough to get done. We had an option for a creative final project in my class, which I enjoyed. Professor Weiss knows a lot about the material and made class interesting.

lectures a little hard to follow because he doesn't have any visuals, but he also encourages student comments and discussion, granted this was a small class. assigned us a group research essay and required that we use like 20 different sources, but honestly it wasn't that bad. chill guy, if you can form coherent thoughts you'll be fine

Subject interesting but Connelly made it boring. She is rude and mean to students in class, often publicly calling them out for minor offenses. Additionally she forces sick students to come to campus to interrogate them all without providing them a seat. Her class is an absolute nightmare I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy-except her. DO NOT TAKE!

He's just a chill guy. I'm glad I took him for HWL since I enjoyed every class.
We got to watch few movies scenes in class and that was fun.

This was a really cool way to be exposed to new math concepts. The class started off pretty difficult with hard readings and assignments, but Theo is very easy-going and adjusted as the semester went on. If you are motivated and enjoy puzzle solving, then this can be fun. Our topic was geometric combinatorics, which is Theo's area of research.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy
